text: Here we have the first barleywine weve rated on here somehow and its a good one. Pours a nice dark amber brown with a thick malty foamy hoppy head. Lovely brutal hop lacerations tantalize while the malty undertow reels you out to sea. The 11% is well hidden, but the effect are not. Good for playing alternately poorly and very well at pinball while contemplating the sandwiches to come.
Very nice. Rich mohagany red pour with minimal sticky head. Aroma of rich sweet dark fruit. Taste follows nose with plum and raisin forward. Carmalized malt and an alcohol burn.

Minimal beige head cover finely carbonated mahogany coloured body.
Stewed fruit & sugar roma.
Medium Bodied. Airy. fine carbonation on the palate. Cloying.
Sweet stewed fruits to the fore with lots of sugar. This is followed by a bitter back of citrus, hops & clove with long grapey finish.
At four years old this tastes like it is past its best & at three years old was at its premium.
Bottle at One Pint Pub, Helsinki. Colour is deep reddish orange with small white head. Sweetness, dry fruits, hops and malts. Pretty good.

On 2/17/17, opened a bottle from 2013. Initial thick head that turns to lacey; nice copper hue; nose of sweet malt; Nice smooth warming mouthfeel; Taste of sweet woody orange citrus malt with some bitterness followed with a lingering finish of bittersweet candy malt.
Bottle at tasting. Aroma of bitter hops, citrus, pine, caramelised malt and ripe fruit. Taste has caramelised malt, bitter pine, ripe fruit, booze, citrus and yeast ester. Smelled better.

(Bottle, 0.65 l - BB 12 Oct 2021, at Kittys, 20170215) The beer poured mahogany coloured and clear. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had malts, molasses ,grass and sweetness. Palate was full bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were malts, grass, molasses, pine, sweetness and bitterness. Aftertaste was malty, hoppy and bitter. A good malty brew with hop bite and it hid its high ABV well.

65ml bottle @ Kittys. 
Poured mahogany color with a thick white head. 
Aroma has bready malts, some earthy notes, toffee, fudge notes. 
Bready malty, toffee, sweetness, caramel. Hides abv nicely. Superb drinkability.

13.02.2017, 0,65l bottle @ home:
Big slightly fizzy-creamy longlasting head. Aroma is sweet fruity, leafs, minerals, fruit stones, caramel malts, grass, dried fruits, raisins, alcohol, hops, bark, citrus peel. Taste is sweet boozy, weeds, leafs, alcohol, minerals, harsh hops, fruit stones, sugar, bark, dried fruits, hay, sawdust, cardboard, soil. Longlasting harsh bitterness, boozy mouthfeel. Fair enough.

2013 vintage. Smells super fruity (fresh & juicy). Flavors are a combo of dark fruits with toffee & caramel syrup in the middle. Finishes with citrus hops & booze. Very warm & long finish. The trifecta of fruits, hops, & booze is well balanced here.
22 oz bomber pours brown with an off white head. Aroma of caramel, toffee and a hint of pine. Taste is toffee, chocolate and a bit of warm alcohol
Golden amber with white head. Fruity, toffee and milk chocolate. Rich, sweet hoppy and dry finish. Good.

Drinking the 2013 vintage on 1/05/17. Deep Amber/copperish hue with a thin ivory cap. Bright earthy toffee and bitter leafy hop aroma with a boozy English malt tone. Bright leafy piney hop bitterness on the flavor with a big boozy Barleywine background with nutty toffee and warming alcohol phenols. Smooth and earthy hoppy bitter profile with a warming malty finish.

bomber @ Beer Trappe / Lexington KY --- 2014 --- Aroma of dark malt and toffee. Hazy amber brown color, ivory head that slowly drops to a full cover, sheets of lace. Taste is rich toffee malt, medium fizz, and light hops that never conquer the malt. Some alcohol warmth at the end. A big-bodied, solid Barleywine, easy to drink, and easy on the gut. I like it.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2016 Poured from bottle best by 11/15/16 looks like iced tea with a thin beige head. Aromas of dark fruit caramel brown sugar toffee. Taste is slightly sweet fruit toffee caramel and a lingering alcohol finish. Wow.

Alcohol, caramel, orange jam, grassy, pine, light grapefruit, spicy, light roasty coffee notes.
Deep amber colour, dense medium sized, beige head, good amount of lacing.
Big assertive bite, big sweetness, lightly salty, deep caramel and rich resinous pine, ABV evident, but not boozy, luscious.
Fullbodied, soft carbonation, sticky feel, rich warming, bitter and sweet finish.
Sublime.

appearance: deep clear copper, creamy tan head, no lacing.  aroma: 	raisin, caramel, stone fruit, pine resin, cattails, caramelized peaches.  taste: burnt wood, caramel, vanilla, raisins, figs, pine, grapefruit, booze	.  finish: lingering alcohol heat, syrupy caramel sweetness balanced by assertive piney, dank-ish hops. notes: Not my favorite style but well-executed. Big, boozy, sweet, and hoppy.  Bottle from Sarah for Beerthday 2014, aged 2 years.

Dark amber/cider color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, caramel, hops, fruit, & some citrus; Flavor of sweet malt, pine hops, dark fruit, caramel, molasses, and spice; Warm finish; The alcohol was present in both the aroma & flavor; Nicely balanced & complex; Quite good.

22 ounce bottle, 2014 vintage, label says enjoy by 05 DEC 2019. Served in a DFH snifter, the beer pours a hazy copper/burnt orange color with about an inch tan head. Head retention and lacing are both good. The brew smells like toffee, molasses, brown sugar, earthiness and dried fruit. Taste is similar to the aroma, but theres also some citrusy hops, bready/grainy malt, booze, stone fruit and pine noticeable. Nice amount of bitter and sweet flavors in this barleywine. Mouthfeel/body is medium/full, its a bit creamy and coating with a decent amount of carbonation. I thought it was a good overall brew, definitely worth a try! Picked it up on closeout a few months ago for $2.99 a bottle at DEPs. Great deal!

Bottle (22 oz), split 3 ways. Deep copper with a medium off-white head, good retention, leaving little lacing. Aroma is earthy and caramel forward with resin, alcohol, brown sugar and vegetal notes. Taste is quite sweet but its balanced by alcohol and a rather strong earthy and resinous presence. Theres plenty of brown sugar and caramel along with some spiciness and a medium bitterness. Full body. Medium carbonation. Syrupy mouthfeel. Warming finish. Though its really not a style I am fond of, I have to admit its really well-executed and I would even say quite enjoyable as a sipper. One of the really good American BW.

65 cl bottle vintage 2013 @ home
Aroma is sweet with fruity hops and caramel. Flavour has alcohol, sweet caramel, some harsh malt and toffee. Alcohol warms nicely in the finish. Quite nice slow sipper.
From a bomber. Pours a dark orange with cream head. Smells like grapes. Strong booze flavor but pretty smooth.

650ml bottle from Woodmans in Waukesha. Cellar aged 3 months, served at cellar temperature and shared with bananabi11. Orange pour with a white head. Aroma has sweet & stone fruits. Very hop forward. Taste is of tangy fruits, pine, citrus, toffee, peach. Medium to full bodied. Blend is solid. There is an alcohol presence. Carbonation is solid. finish is sweeter than bittersweet. Solid hoppy example of style. 14.4

Served at 57deg from wine cellar. Pours a rich Amber and head dissipates quickly. Citrus and caramel with long finish. Malty sweetness taste and nose but not cloying. I really like this. 22oz bomber. Will buy more and drink over 3-4 years.

Rot box special, vintage 2014. Pours a murky Amber with a tan head. Bottle from shelf aroma, toffee, sticky butterscotch. Hops are pretty much gone. Some cardboard, sweet. Thick and sticky. High boost. Chugged the 650ml in under a minute. Ok.
Bottle from Summer Secret Santa a while back. Sticky dark golden pour with a decent head. Tons of pine sap, hoppy, caramel, dark dried fruits and some vanilla. Sticky texture. Good!

Bottle thanks to Bursprak. Pours hazy amber with a beige head. Aroma of caramel malts, hops, toffee, earthy notes and ripe fruits. The taste has pine, hops, caramel, bitter hops and pine notes. Pretty bitter barley wine but a nice one indeed.

Bottle thanks to Bursprak. Pours hazy dark brown/red with a medium offwhite head. Aroma is full of dark fruits, malts, caramel, subtle hoppiness, fresh citrus. Taste is malty, hoppy, caramel, red berries, bitter, orange, piney.
Bottle @ Fermentoren, Aarhus courtesy Klimaet! Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are rich hops, caramel, fruits, malt and has a long bitter and sweet finish. Full bodied.

Bottle thanks to Bursprak! Pours a hazy, reddish amber with a medium sized, long lasting, off white head. Aroma has intense hops and sweet malts, that together gives an intense berry-fruity sweetness, intense malty, spicy, piny hops, some caramel. Taste is sweet, toasty, malty, pretty fruity, and finishes off with a big, but balanced bitterness. Average carbonation, full body without being sticky. Nice and balanced for the style!
GABBF, dark amber, little head. Aroma raisin and fruit. Taste tropical fruit, spice, spruce, vanilla. Pale rich, carb moderate.

1PT 6FL OZ bottle. 2013 Vintage. Pours amber with a faint haze and an orange hued tan cap. On the nose, resinous hops, golden syrup, tropical fruit, and pecan pie filling. Sweet Jeebus this smells glorious. The taste is of course on the sweeter side with raisin, resinous hops, light molasses, and faint spice that leads into what I would describe as beefed up IPA territory. Lots of caramel malt, resinous hops, raisin, light citrus, and a good bitter finish. Barley wines when done correctly make me forget about every great beer Ive had. Man, this is beautiful stuff. Ive had nothing but top notch beers from this brewery. Thank you Victory.

Aromas of deep malts, peanut butter, caramel, nougat, nuttiness, oak, sugared plum and some malted barley. Pours a cloudy amber with a crimson tint and a thick tan lacing and tons of lace. Taste is moderately bitter upfront followed by a creamy mouthfeel. Notes of butterscotch, caramel, sugar cubes, liquid malt extract, some golden malts, melted butter, toffee and sugary, toasted tangerine. Finishes sweet with notes of caramel latte, apricots, hop oils, resin and subtle vanilla. Overall, a very unique take on a barley wine. Flavors almost seem a bit of a mess but it somehow ties together well.

650 ml bottle at the Hoppy Pub, Thessaloniki, courtesy of Constantin. Dark amber color with off white head. Malty aroma, caramel, citrusy fruity, orange, alcohol. Sweet and light bitter taste. Medium oily body soft carbonation.

Pours a cloudy, dull, thick orange-amber with a well-retaining, orange-tan head. Toffee and a strange perfumy aroma. Thick mouthfeel. Barleywine-type sweet maltiness. Toffee flavor. A peculiar, sharp, somewhat harsh hop character.

650ml bottle. 2014 vintage that had been in a fridge since it got to the store. Lightly hazed pour. Aroma is captain crunch berry cereal. Flavor is similar, quite hoppy still, candylike, over the top.

650 ml bottle 2013 vintage, from a trade with Sebilinz, thanks Erich!
Deep copper body, wih a medium, fluffy, light beige head.
Aroma of grapefruit, resin, orange, some pine, caramel, some candy.
Taste follows this, surprisingly hoppy, with some more booze.
Medium, slick mouthfeel, with a moderate carbonation
Finishes bitter-sweet, a bit alcoholic, hoppy, zesty, a bit piney, fruity, also sweet malty.

Very nice. Surprisingly hoppy after 2 years. Pretty strong hop bite in the taste and finish, even a bit harsh. Overall more a Double IPA than a Barley Wine in my opinion. Not my favourite beer from Victory, but really characterful and enjoyable.

0,65 l pullo @ Werkmeisters place. Hiukan samea, meripihkan ruskea. Tuoksussa alkoholia, brandya, makeaa mallasta. Maussa humalaa jotenkin väärällä tavalla liikaa, makeaa mallasta, alkoholia. Karvaus muistuttaa mangoldia. Huh.

Really nice hazy cooper/amber colour with very fast disappearing off white head. Aroma: strong alcoholic, honey, pines, herbs, spices, caramel. Tastes very alcoholic and hoppy, there is little sweetness but quite a lot bitter. The smell is really nice butthe taste is too harsh, not as sweet as it smells, a little bit disturbing. Still good beer.

0,66l bottle at home shared by Saeglopur, big thanks. Vintage 2013, no obvious BB date. copper hazy color, small off-white head. smells light veggies, spices, light wood, grass, tobacco, some pines. full body, soft carbonation, slick mouthfeel. tastes again light veggies, spices, grass, tobacco, oranges, pines, alcohol, herbs, marzipan, nuts, almonds, finishes with alcohol and oranges and some herbal bitter notes. decent, a bit underwhelming, has some veggie notes, not too distracting, but apparent. overall quite good beer but the other ratings would suggest better, a bit boozy.

0,65l bottle (2013) shared by Saeglopur @ Werckmeister?s place. Pours cloudy copper with a low off-white head. Aroma is sweet malts, dark fruits and alcohol. Flavor is sweet malts, dark fruits, alcohol and loads of hops. Good, not quite great.
2014 bottle. Deep copper color, slight haze. Light orangish head that dissipates fairly quickly. Dark fruit aroma, with a hint of booze. Smooth, sweet flavor. Warming feel. Well done.
Bottle in Brussels. Nice red amber body with slight head. Nose of caramel, malts, toasty, fruits. Taste fruits, toasty, pines and bitter. Quite a lot of hops. Really nice warming finish. Well done.

This was poured into a chalice.
The appearance was a nice looking hazy dark amber to brown color with a one finger white foamy head that dissipated within less than about forty seconds. Lacing was gripping nicely to the glass.
The smell started off with a sharp sweet citrus rolling over tobacco notes and a light sticky caramel and slight toffee. 
The flavor was semi-sweet with a strong sticky dry tobacco to caramel maltiness running into slight toffee tones. A dry caramel to toasty toffee aftertaste leads to a quick dry sweet finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fairly decent sipping quality about it. Carbonation runs really low key allowing the "tobacco" to harsh toffee tones to be the bitter balance that runs the gamut on my tongue.
Overall, this was a really nice American Barleywine that I would have again.

Bottled. 2013 vintage. Pours sort of murky bronze copper, off-white head. Really nice. Aroma is figs, raisins, definitely get some of that citrus hop character which has been subdued by that age. The booze and heat is there. Some slight oak, and some toffee and malt. Flavor is toffee, some fig (or maybe raisin), honey, little bit of orange and lemon peel, a delayed citrus hop finish. Really exactly what youd expect from a Victory Barleywine with 2 years on it. Lots of good hop character, but its subdued so quite a good amount of malt presence w/o delving into the style of an English Barleywine.

Bottle, vintage 2011, thanks to Tim! Appearance is dark brown with light white head. Aroma is figs, brown sugar, and caramel. Taste is light bitterness, brown sugar, and butterscotch. Solid barley wine

Backlog. 22 oz bottle from Biggie Wine & Liquor. Deep amber appearance with a lingering head. Aroma of bitter hops, caramel, toffee, light fruity esters and touch of alcohol and resin. Heavy, almost harsh bitterness at first that smooths out as it warms. Full body. Much better after it warms up a bit.

Pours a very cloudy reddish brown color with a small yet dense light khaki head that reduces to a thin cap that leaves spotty lacing on the glass. Aromas of caramel, raisin, fig, prune, apple, molasses, brown sugar, toast, leather, floral, pine, and earth. Taste mirrors the aroma with a slight earthy pine bitterness on the finish. Light-medium carbonation and full bodied; with a creamy, fairly slick, and lightly sticky mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is well hidden with only a small warming noticed after the finish. Overall this is a excellent barleywine. Great balance and complexity of malt flavors; and very smooth to sip on. A highly enjoyable offering.

Bottle from BrewDog shepherd Bush. Pours cloudy glowing amber with a fine, yellowish head. Dark fruits, raisins, nuts nose. More fruits in the mouth, good bitter balance, ending on a dry note. A great barley wine.

Bottle to glass. Pours a clear amber light brownish-orange color with a light tan head. Aroma is boozy, malty, molasses, touch of hops. Flavor is sweet, malty, heavy. Boozy. Overall a very nice barley wine. Would love to see a BA version of this.

Aroma caramel, bread, alcohol, 
Appearance amber, clear, tan foam, 
Taste medium sweetness, lightly bitter, 
Palate medium body, lively, 
Overall I would suggest this beer to a friend
Old rating. Solid barley wine. Dark fruit, caramel, piney hops. Sweet and boozy but neither too much. Good stuff.

Bottle aged 18 months. Scent is a wonderful blend of brown sugar, pine hops, plum and other dark fruits, some booze and a hint of honey, all with a noticeable amount of malt. Smells sweet with a little something lurking behind it. Appearance is an easy 5. Beautiful amber color with a bright white head of foam that recedes down to nothing instantly. Taste is boozier and hoppier than the aroma and appearance would suggest - this is a big boy, for sure. The aftertaste belies some of the brown sugar sweetness, but it also brings a pretty substantial alcohol burn. This could have used even more aging than the 18 months. Palate is a little light for such a strong beer. Overall, its a good strong barleywine; not for the faint of heart. Victory is taking some chances with this one.

Purchased at Ale Yeah - Kennesaw, GA. Beautiful amber pour with 1/4 inch foam head into a snifter. Rich peach and floral notes, with a very nice clean finish. Malt is present with a minor amount of hops.... Booze is very well camaflagued. Recommended very highly.

Pours clear coppery brown with a fairly thick golden tan head. Strong, sweet aroma has notes of caramel, malt and apple. Flavor is fruity and not quite as sweet as the aroma, adding some hops to the caramel and malt notes. Alcohol bite is strong enough to warn that this is a high-grav, but not overpowering. Texture is a tad thin but fairly fizzy. Sip it slowly or youll be horizontal.

March 18, 2015 - 2013 bottle picked up at MGM today, which was a nice surprise. Brownish orange pour with limited head that faded quickly. Aroma was caramel, fruit and alcohol. Taste was consistent with aroma and had a mild bitter finish. Full bodied and smooth drinking.

Vibrant amber, light grease and eggshell ringed head. Minty white grapefruit and oaty hit booziness. Initial taste is brisk minty malt, unrisen sponge cake. Faded hoppy citrus and creamy mouthfeel. Finishes sweet burnt caramel and a lean cakey sweet linger. Not as hot as the nose suggested.Bottle, Cheers BenH, TAD Tasting
Bottle thanks to Mike. Amber with white head. Resinous aroma, caramel, toffee. Taste of caramel, toffee, dried fruit. Quite sweet and bitter.
Bottle at tads. Pours deep amber, nose is caramel, toffee, fruity, taste is similar, quite hot, dry.
Bottle shared by BenH! Aroma is caramel, toffee and earthy malts. Taste is caramel, toffee, raisins and moderate hints of vanilla and oak. Full bodied with a slight hint of warmth.

Bomber. Pours a deep amber, generous off-white head with phenomenal retention and lacing. Nose is malty, mildly herbal hops, peaches, candied orange rind, caramel and band aids. Mouth is super sticky, pronounced sweetness and a mildly bitter undertone, lots of orangey notes, some candy sugar, burnt caramel. A traditional barleywine and perfect for an exceptionally (and unseasonably) cold March night here in the City of Big Shoulders... and while I may hate the Steelers, Flyers, Penguins and Nittany Lions I do love me some Victory beers.

Bouteille datée de 2013. Bue après 1 an. Arômes de pamplemousse, caramel, canne à sucre et soupçon de poivre. En bouche, beaucoup de saveurs se croisent: Agrumes, canne à sucre et alcool. Bel équilibre entre le sucré et le houblonné. Le taux dalcool est bien caché pour 11%. La finale est amère et fruitée.

22oz bottle poured into a snifter. Wood and peach aromas start off strong, but fade. The mellower wood remains and combines with sweet citrus and floral notes as well as spiced apple cider. Aromas of caramel come on strong and late. The beer is slightly hazy and effervescent. It gets hazier near the bottles end, but retains an oily appearance. The hue is a honey copper copper topped by a fuzzy, foamy, off-white thick ring with a heavy, dusty surface coating, and it leaves an above average, dense lace. The taste is a medium high sweet and medium high bitter; mostly balanced, but perhaps slightly more bitter than sweet. The foamy carbonation cuts through the viscous texture nicely. The medium full body holds citrus and caramel sweetness, with resin and burnt bitterness, and a subtle candy sugar note. The finish is butterscotch and roasty with a mellow alcohol warmth that leads to a spicy, mostly clean, bitter aftertaste that has a light burnt and wood lingering quality.

22 ounce bottle into snifter, bottled on 10/26/2013. Pours slightly hazy deep reddish copper color with a 2 finger dense and rocky light khaki head with great retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice dense soapy lacing clings around the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of grapefruit, orange zest, raisin, plum, fig, caramel, toast, toffee, brown sugar, floral, grass, pine, and floral/toasted earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of citrus/pine hops, dark fruit, and dark/bready malt notes; with good strength. Taste of grapefruit, orange zest, raisin, plum, fig, caramel, toast, toffee, brown sugar, pine, floral, grass, and floral/toasted earthiness. Fair amount of pine/grassy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of grapefruit, orange zest, raisin, plum, fig, caramel, toffee, toast, brown sugar, pine, and floral/toasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Very nice complexity, robustness, and balance of citrus/pine hops, dark fruit, and dark/bready malt flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Light-medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a smooth, fairly creamy, and lightly slick/sticky mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a small warming present after the finish. Overall this is an excellent American barelywine style. All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of citrus/pine hops, dark fruit, and dark/bready malt flavors; and very smooth to sip on for the big ABV. A very enjoyable offering.

Tasted from bottle. Pours a cloudy dark reddish amber with off white head. Good lacing. Great aroma. Caramel, toffee, nutmeg, spices, dark fruits, bourbon. Taste is very complex. Spicey flavor with overall moderate to heavy sweetness and mild to moderate bitterness. Toffee, caramel, molasses, raisins, plums, earthy flavors, bourbon. Definitely hides the 11% well. Very well done and interesting tasting barleywine. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bomber. Bright mahogany pour with a small off white wispy head. Aroma was rich dark fruits, brown sugar, caramel and toasted nuts. Flavors were right in line, lots of caramel and dark fruits. Bittersweet finish with a grassy and floral hoppiness that lingered. Moderate carbonation with a slick and slightly viscous mouthfeel. A classic barley wine.

2013 bottle, 650ml, 13C. Copper with a beige head that lasts as a coat. Aroma of toffee, some butterscotch, raisins, dried peach, orange peel. Rich and sweet with toffee, peach, hints of dried fruit, a brandy-like booziness that fits fine. Strong, lasting bitterness with bitter oranges. Still pretty hoppy. Like it a lot now, certainly has the structure to go a few years but maybe the malt side of things is not interesting enough to dominate the show. Nothing fancy, just very good.

Look: pours deep bet. Slight haze. White head. Thick lacing.
Smell: blueberries. Sweet candy sugar. Cherries. Red Apple skin.
Taste: hops. Hot alcohol. Cherries. Blueberries. Sweet syrup.
Feel: hoppy dryness. Leaves a thick film on the mouth. 
Overall: great beer. Love the hops. Super sweetness comes out and helps balance it out. 
First drank; home 1/18/15
Vintage: 2014

This is one of the better barleywine ales that I have had. Aroma is of caramel, toffee, roasted grain, brown sugar, plum, booze. Drinks amazingly smooth for such a high abv, nice balance of sweet malt and hops, the hops are not too astringent or resinous but smooth and fruity. Has kind of a grassy and piney effect from the hops. I really like this one, would repeat.

This is pretty magical. Aroma is lots of roasted toffee, burnt sugar... and just toasty aromas.... taste is toffee, raisins, and lots of malts that finish smooth and lingering. It has a bit of that burnt sugar that seems aged or slightly rancid--in a good way. Finish is a great lingering body that is full with a soft and comfortable mouth feel as the 11% passes your gullet... haha! This is a good one!
UPDATED: JAN 13, 2015 Medium bodied beer with a pleasantly sweet malty taste. Slightly fruity, sweet, and warming. Great barley wine. Definitely one of my favorites in this style!
A rich, malty, high alcohol beer in which you can taste too much booze and has too much carbonation. Medium body, rich caramel aroma, nice creamy head and great lacing and a very long bitter finish.

Aroma excelente. Notas herbales en dónde destaca ampliamente los aromas a pino.

Color rojizo, claro, carbonatacion baja, cuerpo medio, corona de espuma prácticamente nula.

En boca deliciosa, notas frutales, final herbales, buen equilibrio.

Al paladar es una cerveza sumamente compleja. Notas frutales, principalmente frutos rojos, higo, pasas, con final herbal proporcionado por el lúpulo. 

En resumen una deliciosa cerveza, bien equilibrada y con aromas y sabores excelentes.
On tap at lures, pours a low carb brown. Aroma is sweet malts and dark fruit. Taste is sweet malts and fruit with a semi dry finish

Pours a finger and half of head on clear dark amber body.
The aroma is mild pine and grapefruit with some wet grain in the background.
The taste is fruity mild sweetness, turning to pine bitterness and finishes with a flat sweetness.
The texture is thicker.
Tasty.

Bottle thanks to Casey, with Peter, Ben, and Travis. Bottled 1/11/05. Pours a clear golden with lots of maltiness in the nose. Also some breadiness and figs. Some raisins. Very smooth on the mouth. Clean finish. Really nice beer. Thanks so much Casey!

This was an extra from emacgee, thank you! Deep reddish golden. Generous head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is full and intense, fruity, peach, apricot, and lots of malt, honey. Taste is sweet, with a little bitterness in the finish. Smooth. Rich. Complex. I love this. Just what I hope a barley wine will be.
Bottle. Deep amber color, clear, cream colored head. Aroma of dark fruit, toffee. Taste is mixed winter fruit, butterscotch, alcohol warming. Very tasty.

650ml 2013 bottle in hotel from brewdog Newcastle
Fruity red berry, caramel, stewed grain and pine on nose. hazy dark ruby brown.Full bodied, gentle carbonation, pretty pithy bitterness, saponic on tip and edges of tongue. Some marmitey autolysis. Slightly plasticky in finish with lingering bitterness.

12oz bottle. Pours a dark amber color with a very slight haze under a light brown, very thin head. Big fruity nose with some sherry over malt. Very big, chewy malt on the palate that starts sweet with molasses, brown sugar, and bourbon joined by plum and fruit becoming bitter with big alcohol flavors on the finish. Full bodied with medium low carbonation.

This barleywine has a malty pine brown sugar with a touch of booze aroma. Roasted barley and subtle chocolate nuances are swamped by brown sugar caramel malt and spruce hoppiness. Long bittersweet finish with a warm alcohol finish. Not overwhelming. Abv is woven into this nicely.
Tap. Red amber with minimal head. Malty and sweet. Moderate hops. Very big beer.

Julie. Not impressed it is too hoppy. She gives a 2

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2006 bottle shared courtesy of a good friend. Pours a murky copper brown with a ring of bubbly off-white head. Aroma is big on sweet malts, like a sherry or port wine almost. Taste follows, big and sweet, dark fruits, rich plums, caramel and toffee, intense but smooth. Pretty amazing, still decent carbonation, held up extremely well.

Clear deep mahogany color with a one-finger tan head that leaves minimal lace. Aromas of dark and dried fruit, candy sugar and molasses. Raisin, date, caramel, plum and tobacco flavors highlight a complex flavor profile. Full bodied, thick creamy mouthfeel, minimal carbonation, and a pleasant dark fruit sweetness in the finish
Bomber dated 8/24/13,poured into a tulip glass..amber/copper pour with a fluffy white head..aroma of caramel,grapefruit,toffee..smooth mouthfeel with good hop character..really good.

Aroma is pineapple, grapefruit, citrus hops, and sticky sweet malt. Taste is packed with citrus hops and fruits with a prevalent bitterness and a grainy malt taste. And it is boozy ladies and gentlemen. Palate is full bodied and mouthfeel is thick as a brick and sticky. Finish is medium and bitter. This is a heavy barleywine and very full bodied. Not your easy sipper by any means but a good representation of the style. There are other barleywines that suit my taste better but this is by no means a bad beer.

650ml botte, pours dark brown with just a little lacing. Aroma is rich, caramel and toffee malt giving way to citrus hop, orange and pineapple come through with a pithy bitterness and dry finish. heavy sweetness, medium bitterness, full body, thick, sticky, oily feel, soft carbonation. Very good barley wine, very drinkable, more than a slow sipper.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2014 This is a really pungent beverage; its sweet, its hoppy, and its boozy as hell. The hops give off a sweet, tropical vibe, and the malts bring up molasses. Then the booze arrives and reminds you youre about to get slightly impaired. The taste is shamelessly bitter and alcoholic, with a sweet, malty background that keeps the whole thing on a leash. The palate is medium to thick, which, coupled with the sweet malts, makes for an overall syrupy impression. The beer is a deep, yellowish, coke brown without much of a head. Good and with much depth, but definitely a sipper.

Bottle from Brewdog Edinburgh shared with BenH, James Tulloch and allmyvinyl. 
Appearance - golden amber with a decent head. 
Nose - burnt orange and honey. 
Taste - marmalade and honey. 
Palate - rich in body and texture with a sweet finish that is still in balance.
Overall - good example of a well made barley wine.

Bottle at Brewdog Edinburgh. Pours dark amber, thick off-white head. Boozy fruitcake aromas, mixed dried fruit and demerara sugar. Something nutty too. Nice. Taste is rich, light spice, light booze and then an orange peel bitterness at the end. Smooth, oily texture, long finish. Good.

Poured from a bomber into a snifter amber red with a golden head which laced nicely.
Aroma is hoppy tropical sweetness.
Flavor is caramel, pineapple, piney hops. Really nice blend to the palate. Top Notch American Barleywine. Really.

Poured from 22 oz. bottle. 

Clear, toffee color with a 3-finger khaki head and good lacing. 

Aroma of caramel, alcohol, papaya and pineapple. 

Taste of caramel, tropical fruit, alcohol, plum, citrus, pineapple and sweet golden raisins. 

Medium/full body and low/medium carbonization.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle poured a hazed orange hue w/ enormous long-lasting beige head and sticky lacing. Big Malty and spicy aromas. Initial flavor is moderate sweet w/ moderate bitter long lasting finish. Taste is malt forward w/ earthy spices. Full bodied and a hot finish.
Draft at Hopcat in Grand Rapids. Pours a clear reddish brown color. Aroma and taste are dark fruits and caramel.

Truly a superior barley wine. Pours amber with good head and lacing. Lots of hops, booze and caramelized malt. Citrus, candied plum and pine. Pours cloudy brown with good head and lacing. Finishes bittersweet. Soft carbonation. Tap at Smoke and Barrel.

Year 2013 22oz bottle. Dark copper with red hue. Aroma is licorice, nutty, citrus, dough, alcohol. Flavor is very malty up front, medium hop flavor, medicinal finish with a little alcohol bleeding through. Smooth, full bodied, sticky. Overall a nice beer for this cool rainy July day. Ill put a few of these back for winter.

Pours an amber-brown with a thin white head. Floral notes are weak but still present. Bitterness is middle of the road for a barleywine. Body is heavy but mouth feel is appropriate. Booziness is nowhere to be found. So good.

22 oz bottle purchased at State Line. Pours a clear bright copper brown color with ruby hues apparent on the glass. Aroma is caramel malt, leather, dark fruit sweetness, slight citrus via hops, Flavor is same notes as aroma with medium to full bodied mouthfeel and complex sweet fruity finish. Solid.

About to go for a walk (Dave is still peeing).

The beer is dark orange / copper with a half inch of tan head. Smells hoppy, boozy, malty. Big beer. ¿Que hora es? Citrus soaked in alcohol. Notes of pine with some alcohol sugars. Good flavor, but the alcohol is too forward. I have trouble appreciating beers of this ilk, where both the malt and hop profiles are so grand that they seem to compete for dominance, rather than dance in harmony. Hop bitterness and alcohol longer on the palate. Overall, good, though not my cup of tea (beer).

Bomber with a very microscopic date printed on neck. Bottled sometime in 2013, smeared print, but bottle conditioned, and at 11% abv it will remain fresh for years. It pours dark amber, fairly clear, with a small creamy head as most large abv brews have. It leaves nice lacing by the time you finish the bottle. It smells great, some hops, some Belgium yeast, and plenty of bready malt.a massive taste, full bodied with huge malt and sweetness and the alcohol hits slightly later. An excellent barleywine and will be remembered as the real deal.

Clear deep mahogany color with a one-finger tan head that leaves minimal lace. Aromas of dark and dried fruit, candy sugar and molasses. Raisin, date, caramel, plum and tobacco flavors highlight a complex flavor profile. Full bodied, thick creamy mouthfeel, minimal carbonation, and a pleasant dark fruit sweetness in the finish.

Bottle from Winestyles. Pours a perfectly transparent amber with thin beige head. Aroma isnt as strong as I thought it would be, just faint hints of caramel and booze. Taste of dark fruits, a more pronounced caramel, and a lingering booze.

Hazy dark red with abundant lacing, moderate carbonation and a thin but creamy head. Lots of dark fruit notes in the nose, with caramel malts, and some citrus hops. Flavor is very powerful but otherwise pretty much the same as the nose but with more of a resiny kick to it, particularly in the aftertaste. Thick body and moderate carbonation. Pretty good overall.
Pours faintly hazy gold with a small but fluffy head. Very good complexity and balance.

Bottle shared at 2014 Pittsburgh Barleywine tasting. Pours a clear golden color with a slight white head. Slight grassy aroma with a sweet taste. Some retro-nasal caramel/toffee notes. Really good barleywine for the price.

BA transfer - Poured from bottle into chalice glass

Appearance - A Nice deep red/brown color with a haze that faded. A Very wispy head was present when poured which dissipated quite quickly.

Smell - Not all that potent, but some sweet notes of dried fruit.

Taste - A sweet taste hits your tongue immediately. Cherries overwhelm the taste pallet with a nice malty flavor developing later on. This is then followed long after by a very subtle yet pleasant alcohol taste. Good for the style.

Mouthfeel - Nice and creamy with not too much carbonation.

Overall - A very good brew. A barleywine I would recommend over others I have had. Its too bad Victory did not continue brewing it this year.

Bomber.  2013 bottle poured into a snifter.  Aroma is complex with nutty sweet caramel notes, fig, smoke, and citrus and hops.  Taste is very bitter up front with hops.  Mellows out a bit In the middle to reveal caramel and toffee flavors with a hint of dark fruit.  The finish is back to the bittering hops with some spice and a lot of alcohol.  Based on the reviews I've read I was hoping for a smoother barley wine, probably needs to age a bit.  Decent yet a little disappointing.

On tap at the brewery, served in a tasting glass. Pours clear copper with a small beige head that mostly remains and leaves a small amount of fine lace. The nose has big malty, toffee and caramel notes, along with raisins, figs and a complementary piney hop note. Wow, the flavour is an incredible, complex mix of toffeeish, biscuity malts with raisins, figs, a touch of molasses, and perhaps even pear and peach notes. Towards the end, hops reemerge, imparting a nice spicy, peppery quality to a finish that is long and balanced between fruity, toffeeish malts and a nice piney bitterness. On the palate it is full in body with a smooth, syrupy texture and soft carbonation. Overall, a truly great barley wine. I would love to compare to the oaked version. 2014-05-01
65cl, Vintage 2013, at 11%Vol, American brew, thx to Ethan!, complex brew, malty/sweet and slightly alcoholic/fruity/bitter, very balanced, clear, small head, very good Winter brew
Bottle. Very sweet, but there is a load of hops keeping the sugar under control. Herbs, chocolate.

Tasted at Victory with ML. Clear mahogany pour with fine off-white head. Aroma is sweet malts with notes of caramel, toffee, vanilla, molasses, dark dried fruit, pear, and apple. There are also hops coming through. Flavour follows through with great balance. Medium to full body. What an awesome American Barleywine.

4/30/14. Bottle. Pours translucent amber with a fluffy, off-white head. Aroma is earthy, caramel, citrus, vanilla, grass, light fruits, white grapes, syrup. Taste is dark fruits, light citrus, red apple skin, earthy, herbal, caramel, toffee, nice balance; finish is fruit skin, caramel, dark fruits. Dense lacing throughout. Very full bodied. Warming. Medium-low carbonation. While the alcohol is fairly well-hidden, this is a dense, rich, heavy beer. Not a criticism, just an observation. Really nice!
Big big big flavors happening here in a very good beer. 22oz bottle shared with friends poured into 7oz glasses. Lively carbonation, great lacing. Bitter and earthy hops, caramel and fruit.

2010 vintage, poured into a snifter. Ruby brown, with a light tan head.

Age did this well. Nose is dark fruits predominantly, with a hint of hops.

Dark fruit, toffee, and a bit of bitterness in the back end swirl around. Very balanced, very delicious. Almost no booziness in what is a pretty high gravity beer.

Good carbonation bite.

This is a good one. Im sure the aging mellowed it out, but its extremely flavorful and tasty. I like.

The nose is hop forward - tropical fruit is the predominate aroma followed by toffee and caramel. A clear mahogny/copper pour with a white ring and minimal lacing. The palate is tropical fruit, toffee, and a nice hoppy bitter finish. To me, the alcohol is well hidden. Medium body and medium carbonatin. Overall, an enjoyable and excellently crafted Barley Wine. I had it with some Stelson cheese and WHOA! Next to Stones Old Gauradin this is one of my favorite Barley Wines.

Bottle. Amber/copper with a fluffy head. Aroma is caramel, sweet candied sugar, peach, and earthy dank hops. The taste starts off on the bitter side and adds butterscotch and citrus fruit notes. The sweetness overpowers everything else. Thin, light consistency. Alcohol is decently hidden. Medium carb. - Pretty good, but lacks balance. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Clear reddish copper with a fluffy off white head. Still with lots of lacing. Aroma is light grassy hops, green apple, apricot, peach, caramel and melted Jolly Rancher. Taste is earthy and bitter to start with some lingering fruity sweetness in the finish. Light citrus notes throughout. Sticky, chewy mouthfeel with little carb. Solid but unspectacular.

Floral aroma with hints of fruit. Medium bodied and smooth. Slightly sweet and peary. Finishes with some citrussy hops

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Had this back in December 2013. Nice dark pour with slight brownish/tan head that didnt linger very long. Aroma was not very strong, earthy, raisin, with a chocolate/coffee. Taste was a mix of caramel/raisin and a roasted coffee. Taste was much better than the aroma. Great mouth feel with good malt backbone and a very mild hop mixed in there. Overall a good tasting Barleywine style.

Delicious aroma of some soft fruit. Nice foamy head on the pour, hangs in there as well. Color is a dark hazy amber. Alcohol is present on the pallet though it remains smooth and rich. Stunning barley wineVictory is a great company and this offering does not disappoint.

Ruddy brown, absolutely crystal clear with a thin, off white head that fades quickly. The smell draws you in with deep caramel notes, toffee and brown sugar. Taste follows the smell, lots of caramel, sweet butterscotch notes, lightly bitter on the back end. Fairly viscous with a medium to low amount of carbonation. This is an extremely drinkable barleywine. It doesnt taste like it could even be 8 percent alcohol let alone 11.
citrus smell to it, taste is too hoppy for me, especially for a barleywine! I appreciate different takes on the styles but this is too much!

Victory are prolific. They put out saisons or ipas that are usually good. And to see a barleywine in their stable is a breath if fresh air. Plum hue. Mild head. It is boozy but not prominent. The wash down is a bit dry. Plus I wish it had more body. Its good but not Rogue Old Crustacean Barleywine good.
On tap. Dark ruby red color. Caramel aroma. Boozy taste. You can really taste the alcohol in this one. Nice beer.
Caramel, sweet aroma. Taste, exactly the same, caramel, sweet fruits. Alcohol present but also hidden well.

12oz bottle thanks to Sean. Best by 11/15/14, so 4+ years old. Smells like a semi sweet caramelly barleywine. Taste is very balanced. Has a touch of the hard ribbon candy i expect from a barlywine but Im assuming it mellowed out nicely. Mouth feel is velvety smooth. Never had this fresh to compare, but this is one of the best non BA barleywines Ive had.

Pours a really nice amber that looks like brandy in the glass once the head dies down. Aroma is rich with caramel and molasses. Taste is sweet and rich up front, into a hop balance and plenty of boozy burn. Aftertaste is syrupy sweet, mixed with bready malts and hops. Very nicely balanced. Rich and smooth overall.

Bottle aged in cellar for quite a long time (5+ years). Was surprised I hadnt rated this in the past, as Ive had this brew fresh in the past and thought it was very solid. Anyway, aged bottle review - bottle still has some life, which is a good thing - dank brown pour with no head to speak of - thin white ring clings to the edges. Aroma is inviting - loads of caramelized malt, some resinous hop notes, hint of chocolate, toasty, some booze, splash of dark fruit. Flavor is smooth and sweet - caramelized, toasted malts rule the show, but there is still a healthy amount of hop bitterness to make this an excellent barleywine after all the years. Dark fruit and some spices round things out. Palate is somewhat oily, moderately thick, and oxidization is minimal. This turned out very nicely after a long cellaring - I think Im out, but wouldnt complain about enjoying another after a few years!

Poured into a tulip glass from a bomber. Pours a clear light copper with a huge khaki head that lasts a long time and leaves good lacing. Aroma is hops. Taste is caramel, molasses, and malt, with a pleasant clean hop finish. Im not a hops fan, but this is the best-balanced barleywine Ive yet tasted. Outstanding.

It has a rich aroma of caramel, plums, and other malts. It is a ruby red with a thick, frothy head that is off white. It has a rich malt flavor with flavors. Most barleywines are strong to the point of being overbeering, but this one has a well balanced finish. The flavoring and the combinations and well blended.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2014 On tap at George Keeley, NYC. Dark brown ruby. Aroma is hops! Taste is the same with lovely caramel malts. One of the better American Barleywines going around. Hops very present but dont over dominate. Finish is a lovely sweetness and mild bitterness. Overall, bit more malt caramel than Old Numbskull (not as much balance), but in the same sphere of BWs.

13 vintage bottle. The color is a rich deep copper/amber with a thin white head. One of the best Appearance beers I have seen. The aroma is carmel and toffee mix, with prominent hops. The taste hits you up front and almost burns a little, or a lot. Then the booze hits you on the back end. Hit the style spot on, and this would seem to age perfectly.

Rich, deep caramel color. Dense foamy beige head. Well, the atoma is mostly malty and rich. I mean its all malty and rich. The taste is smooth, strong, boring, uneventful, and mellow. This is a great beer for one thing... forgetting...

Clear orangeish-reddish-amber with a frothy eggshell head. Aroma of toast, toffee, raisin, resin, and citrus peel. Its a tad mild though. Fruity sweet taste with some decent bitterness and a touch of booze. Medium-full bodied with soft carbonation and a somewhat syrupy feel.

Ive been looking forward to this for a while. 22 oz bottle into a pint glass.

A: Pours a clear dark amber color. The head is a two finger off-white shade. Its texture is excellent, and it has good retention as well. Lacing left behind is rather plentiful.

S: Its actually not quite as sweet as I thought it would be. The hop notes here - as expected - are piny and resinous, balanced by its malt sweetness. In particular, it brings caramel, vanilla, and toffee. Its definitely a quality aroma, if a bit more standard than I was expecting.

T: The taste works better, I think. Piny hops hit the palate first - there isnt much harshness, and the pine flavor is incredibly vivid. It becomes sweeter after the midtaste and especially on the finish, while its hop flavor becomes almost salty to my twisted palate. The harsher elements of the alcohol are hidden very well. If I have to complain about something, its that the sweetness here isnt well defined - sure it brings plenty of caramel, toffee, and earth, but not much in the way of dark fruits or candy. Theres just the subtlest suggestion of the latter, unfortunately it isnt quite enough. Every once in a while, theres a gentle wisp of chocolate that hits the palate.

M: This seems to be even softer than others in the style. Of course, being a barleywine, its still sweet and heavy. The finish is, naturally, superbly long and mildly bitter. Its more salty than anything. Nonetheless, Im really impressed how well the booze is hidden.

O: Give this a year or two in the cellar and this would kick ass. Right now, though, its still drinking pretty damn well. If the sweetness was more defined, then it would be killer immediately. As it stands, Im really enjoying the hop profile but wished the malt component worked a little better.
22oz bottle pours a reddy brown color a bit of head. Sweet malty goodness. Mild hopiness. Smooth.

Growler. Pours a clear orange/amber with a thin head and excellent lacing. Aroma is a candied sweetness, caramel, a hint of hops and booze. Taste is predominantly a candied sweetness and strong malt with some hops in the background but they are overpowered. Medium to full bodied with a somewhat dry finish. A decent barleywine but too sweet for my taste. Ironically this used to be one of my favorite beers which just goes to show how tastes can change over the years.

This poured a brick orange color with a slight haze and soft light that exudes form the body of the beer. A fat off white head of orange tinged foam to top the beer and it fell lazy like it had all day and left great lace and alcohol legs. Nose is fantastic. Its candied orange peel, malty caramel with a bit of nut and butterscotch, fresh orange to go with that and a little bit of hop presence. 

Taste is all that and more. The caramel is smooth and buttery with a hint of nuttiness. The fruits are lively and fresh with a bit of fresh orange to really juice things up. The malt sweetness has something buttery on ti and that is like candy. The mouthfeel is full and sticky and has a bit of pine resin to coat the throat and let the solvent like alcohol just graze your palate before the finish. A bit of warmth and you have just had one exciting ride. 

Super. Just super.

Bomber. Dark coppery crimson colored with a hearty layer of beige foam. Lots of herbal hops, dark sugars, pine resin and ripe citrus in the aroma. The taste is dominated by caramel, hops resin and candied citrus peel upfront along with some dark fruits, persimmon and pine. Naturally thick and creamy body with more sugary malts and alcohol in the finish. Great example of an American Barley Wine done right.
22 oz bomber pours a dark amber color with a nice off white head. Aromas of dark fruits, pine, resin, caramel malt. Full bodied, sticky and sweet, a great example of an american barley wine

Draft. Pours a clean brown, thinner looking than one might expect for a barleywine. Nice velvety mouthfeel, with a fairly sweet finish. Hops come through nicely in the aroma and on the palate, eventually balancing the sweetness. Very nice.
Bottle. This is a big burly BW with lots of great malt and hop flavour and plenty of warmth.
Nice bold taste, lingers on palate. Despite high ABV there is no hotness to taste.

22oz bottle - pours a deep rusty copper with tan head . Bready aromas with some dark fruit . Sharp piney hop note is balanced out by some raisiny sweetness . Moderate alcohol on the palate . Pretty drinkable for 11% and like the $ point $8.99 . 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2014 Heavy toast aroma from a typical American barleywine. Thick lacings rim the glass of the hazy copper ale. Hot alcohol burns through the strong caramel flavors. Malt flavors do not clean up in the finish.

Clear red orange pour with a beige head that fades down to a film. Strong fruits an caramel aroma with some booze. Taste is pineapple cake, caramel, and alcohol. Alcohol is a little on the hot side. Slight hoppy bitterness but sweet overall. Slick chewy texture. Slow sipper.

Hmm, this is an interesting one. Dark amber, somewhat clear, a finger of beige head. Fruity nose, fruit cake like. The taste has a fairly harsh bitterness followed by an almost cloying fruit cake sweetness, a little weird. This is definitely more of an American style Barleywine, which isnt my favorite style. Its alright, but no the best Victory offering by any means.

Poured from a bomber into brandy glass. Light golden brown appearance. Flavor was classic american style barleywine. Noticeable hops, but not overdone like some. Large malt character with toffee chewiness and a good mouthfeel. Very solid beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from notes. Loved this stuff being year round out here. Just like Bourbon County in 2008 and drinking bottles of it in a cemetery while watching movies in LA. Pours a deep brown to tan. Aroma of barley chaff and booze. Taste is boozy IPA with some orange in there.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: Bottle courtesy of cards04. Spicy aroma, hops, pineapple. Complex flavour - hops, citrus, black pepper, caramel. Very tasty.

Amber body white head. Hoppy aroma for a a barley wine also dried fruit. This comparison won't mean anything to most of you but it tastes like last years demeters harvest not third years. A hoppy barley wine. Nice.
A really nice barley wine. Nice hoppy and fruity aromas. Nice malt flavors at first.. Honey and tropical fruit. Bracing hop bitterness. Loved this. Drink this!

Deep red-brown, no head. Roasted nuts, grain, some hints of pine. Both sweet, caramel and bitter quite quickly. Fairly present alcohol, heavier body. Quite good.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
pours mohagany amber, cream hued head that reduces to a nice cap. big biscuit nose. buttered biscuits, cracker, toast, mild bitterness. slightly drying but full body.

Dark red-brown, small tan head. Aroma brown sugar/caramel, piney hops. Full body. Alcohol is there but more of a warming presence than interfering with the flavor. Up front sweet malty flavors, molasses, finish is fairly bitter and hoppy,

Bomber->snifter. Orange/amber with small fluffy offwhite head. A: malty, with caramel, brown sugar, molasses, amd nice pine hops note. T: tangy spice amd malt combo, with definite hop presence. Very tasty.
Bottle. Pours brown, lots of red hues with off-white head. Smells like lots of barley, sweet. Tastes rich, bitter for a barleywine, interesting. Dont think its that great.

Bomber poured into snifter. A deep mahogany color with a quickly dissipating cream head. Smells of bitter hops, plums, caramel, maybe even a little cherry. Tastes sweet in the beginning, with a sugarplum, toffee and syrupy taste that is matched by hops to balance it out. Booze is considerably hidden, given its content. The bitter half takes over the palate, almost dominating the initial sweetness. The opposite of a sour patch kid. Solid barleywine though, I see why they call it old vertical.

Poured from 22oz bottle. Beautiful syrupy amber with an aggressive head Which dissipates quickly. Fruit favors and booze dominate the palate.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bomber thanks to Repo. Deep amber color. Sweet hop and candy aroma. Taste is very hippy with nice bitter balance for a barelywine.-- rated with beerbasher
Bomber thanks to Repo. Clear amber with a beige head. Candy and fruit aromas. Similar flavors and surprisingly light.

Bottle. Pours a clean amber with thin, diminishing tan head and some spots of lace. Nose of caramel, cherry, plum, brown sugar. Medium body, sweet but not much alcohol warmth. Some herbal and earthy hop notes.

Dark brownish amber color with no head and no lacing. Aroma is malty with deep fruit notes. Flavor has strong caramel, cocoa malts, with a bitter kick and slight spicyness with a bit of hop bitterness. Its not sharp and astringent like most other barleywines- this is smooth and very drinkable

Taken me awhile to find this one, bomber into snifter glass. Orangy-amber color with light tan head. Aroma of citrus/piney hops, big caramel malt and some fresh fruitiness. Taste makes a much larger appearance with some hop bitterness, toffee, sugar, berries, light cocoa and booze. Heavy body, moderate carbonation, slick, soft, oily with slight bitter finish. Very fruity, soft barleywine. Enjoyed!
Nice copper color with a white foam head. Smells fruity and somewhat like brandy. Taste is fruit and medium hops. Very good.

Poured to NB globe.
Best by: 11/15/15

A: Pours a nice orange, amber ale with excellent clarity and a single finger peanut colored head which dissipates quickly to leave a sheet of foam on surface.

S: Bell peppers dominate the nose initially. Some green apple skins, caramel, toffee, earthy hops with hints of citrus in there.
Occasionally, I get some woody smells in there, piney, resin.

T: Bitter, sweet, warm. Plenty of bittering on this barley wine. Nice, sweet malt backbone, but it doesnt really marry completely. the ABV show through (expected at this age).

M: Medium heavy feel with medium high carbonation. Slicks the palate. 

D: nice beer. I was caught off guard by the nose profile on this one. Its atypical for a barley I think. The bell pepper is what I like in young, immature Cabernet Franc vines, and this reminds me of this profile. I want to grab a couple and age them.

Serving type: bottle

02-08-2011
Really wonderful sipper. Warms your throat, but remarkably drinkable. Lots of hop flavor but really takes the back seat due to all the syrupy flavors.

It appears that Ive wiped the dating off, but this is from the fresh 2013 release.
Appearance: The body is beautifully clear with a red body with pink tones through it. The head is short and dense with good retention, slowly settling into an off-white dusting on top with a bubbly ring.
Aroma: The nose gives off juicy grapefruit hop aromas, but its not pungent while hints of sweet caramel and bready malts back it up with a light booze presence. The aroma is a bit weak though.
Taste: The intro is very unassuming of the mildly aggressive bitterness that awaits. Bready malts and a mild caramel presence act as a base for a strong floral and grapefruit bitterness that peaks on the finish and lingers for a while. I get some raisin undertones by the finish, slight musky aromas as well. I didnt remember this being so hoppy.
Palate: Full-bodied and moderately carbonated, a bit snappy on the finish.
Overall: Im not sure how I feel about this beer. On one hand I find it to be a step above most American barleywines, and on another hand I find that American barleywines teeter on being a imperial IPA. I tend to like my barleywines in the English style, sweet with a complex malt base. I dont get much here other than a huge hop presence, especially by the finish. Where is the deep and complex malt base here?

Deep muddy-brown body, medium sized light tan head, spotty lacing. Big caramel, toffee, and dark fruit malts, grapefruit, pine, and resinous hop notes Medium to full bodied, with gentle carbonation, moderate sweetness and complimentary bitterness in the finish.
A very disguised barley wine that packs a punch in ABV, but has a wonderful taste unlike some high octane barley wines I have tasted.

Bomber shared. Pours a deep clear amber color with egg shell head. The aroma is citrus of a mystery grapefruit and or pineapple. You do get a little hop in the nose. Some sweet malts as well. The flavor is unique for so young a barley wine. You actually get a swirl of the citrus and the alcohol which was amazingly good. Not sure what aging would do for this but it cant hurt. Impressed as usual with victory.
Poured from a bottle it is an amber Colorado with a flight head. The aroma is is of pineapple and it tastes of citrus and had a bitter after taste

From a 22 oz bottle shared at home. Pours a clear amber with an ecru head. Nutty aroma. Flavors of citrus hops with some vinous notes. Medium full bodied, moderate carbonation, bitter and boozy finish.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2013 This one was either taken out of the Atlanta market for years and its just now returning or it just made a comeback this year. Either way, I have been wanting to drink this guy for a while and now its back in 22ozers. Would have been cooler in six packs. Pours clear medium amber with decent light beige head. Smell is sweet malts, caramel, bright fruits, floral hops, bar cherries. Taste is sweet bright fruits, mixed fruit cup, cherries, hops, caramel, touch warming booze. I love it. Damn wish I would have picked up a couple more. Nice medium full mouth with an almost creamy finish. Blew me away.

Pretty sweet, but certainly drinkable. I had a bomber of it. Probably could of had a 12oz bottle after that, but that's it. Then again...the bomber did the trick anyway. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Fresh 2013 bomber. Pours a clear copper color with a very small head that quickly fades to a ring. Aromas are juicy citrus hops, caramel, cherries, apples, molasses, and flowers. Taste is full of juicy sweetness up front, cherries, apples, grapefruit and flowers too. Finishes with a moderate bitterness, lots of caramel, and a little pine. Huge warming in the finish too which is just awesome. Really good barleywine at a great price.
Draft - nose is resin. Golly geez this is dandy. Malty and oddly refreshing. Slightly boozy. Caramel makes an appearance. Well balanced.

Pours a glowing ruby orange somber. Large creamy beige head. Nice hoppy aroma, Grapefruit, citrus. Moderate balanced malty backing. Caramel. Hoppy, sweet and malty all nicely come together. Flavor matches perfectly. Medium to full body. Excellent bitterness that is kept in check. Creamy and Super smooth. More pine in finish. Very hoppy. Very good. Did not find much alcohol, except some nice belly warming. Well-made.
Sweet fruit, grapefruit, hops. Taste is smooth, very hoppy, but sweet. A little straw, bitter finish, tiny bit of alcohol in the aftertaste as well, but not too much. very nice.

Tap at Victory, Downington, 27/11/13.
Dark amber with a moderate light beige covering, good lacing ensues.
Nose is dark toffee fudge, dates, raisens, dark brown sugar, light boozey vein.
Taste comprises sweet cake mix, hoppy backnotes, light tropical fruit medley, dates, brown sugar, sticky stewed grapefruit, raisens, caramelised sugar, toffee fudge.
Full bodied, soft carbonation, smooth on the palate with a touch of booze in the closure.
Decent enough Barley wine, doesnt carry as much depth as the oak version but the 11% is well masked.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Draft to taster. Looks solid; a transparent copperish orange with sticky off-white lacing. Smells sweet and malty with notes of juicy hops and caramel. Tastes like it smells with a nice mouthfeel thats fairly smooth for the abv. Enjoyable.
Sweet barleywine goodness. Chewy and sticky. Lots of complexity. Really enjoyed this and looking forward to finding another bottle. Sooo tasty.
Pours mahogany with off white head and no lacing. Aroma of sweet candy malts and some grassy hops. Taste of caramel malts, dark fruits, chocolate, bitters, and booze. Very good.

Bottle. Aroma is sweet malt, caramel, citrus hops, and alcohol. Appearance is bronze with great clarity. Light tan head. Taste is caramel, bread, pine, booze, and honey. Medium body and good carbonation. Excellent beer.

Pours a slightly hazy caramel red with a fluffy off white head. Huuuuge hops on the nose, mostly ripe fruit and lots of citrus, a little sticky resinous pine, caramel and molasses, dates, dark cherry, and a hint of milk chocolate. Nice caramel and dark fruit sweetness up front on the taste, huge bitter hops, lots of citrus then into massive piney and floral hops, a little alcohol is noticable, somewhat sweet, and a little hot. This is a delicious barleywine, but its almost more like a huge DIPA at the moment. Id really like to set one down for a year or so and see how it settles down.

22oz bottle, 2013 release. Shared with Annie and co. Mostly clear red orange color. Thin khaki head, leaves plenty of dots and short ropes of lace. Big body, kind of creamy and chewy, with a lightly dry finish. Lighter, smooth carbonation. Moderate sweet taste, good hop bitterness in the finish. Light alcohol warmth, but its all appropriate and works well. Good caramel, lightly spicy malt profile. Some dark fruit, some tropical hop. Good light pepperiness. Light hints of darker malts, maybe a bit of chocolate / lightly toasty malts. A big, complex rich meaty flavor overall. Very impressive big barley wine. Well-integrated.
4 oz. pour at brewpub side by side with Oaked Horizontal. Pours murky brown. Pine, molasses, caramel, alcohol, dark fruits. High sweetness, moderately bitter. Full sticky body. Not a big fan.

Great beer too bad they don't make it anymore. I have 6 more left and can't wait to try them 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Older bottle tasted Oct 2013. Best by date is Nov 2014. Six years old? Seven?

Murky brown pour with an off white head into a tulip glass. Powerful, delicious aroma, oranges and brown sugar, aged hops and toffee and spice. Surprisingly bitter flavor given the aroma with not nearly as much sweetness as expected. This is nice, bracing -- may take a few sips to get used to. Grapefruit pith and bitter nutmeg and cinnamon stick and very chewy brown bread, burnt brown sugar. Wow, I cant get over how bitter this one remains after all this time, but its almost in a good way that makes the beer very sip-able. Warming late is pretty much the only direct sign of the high alcohol content; the booziness is long gone. This is one Ill enjoy quite a bit as I stretch it out over the coming hour.

Refrigerated 12 oz. brown bottle poured into a snifter. Pours clear crimson with small off-white head. Aroma is dark fruit with a hint of alcohol, medium/light body, and no carbonation. Taste is dark fruit and booze. Not too bad, but I am not fan of the booze.
September 2010. From bottle. An awesome barley wine. Complex and balanced with dark fruit and brown sugar flavors. Wow!
Candied hops and brown sugar toffe malt with a touch of chocolate in the flavor. Beautiful red orange pour with everlasting lace

Have you ever rip-started a lawn mower? I have. And Id equate that experience to drinking this beer. Full, IYF (if yo face) assault on your senses. Oh, were you just saying you need to update your resume later? You also probably need to apply to a number of philanthropic jobs at some point in the next two days. I do too, I love dogs. BUT you cannot do that because the VICTORY brewing co. just took a major rain (shit) on your parade. Delicious light cinnamon and figs, old oak and dark as fuck berry fruits. Not so sweet, but then again that may be good so it won t fuck your little sister. All in all, if this beer was a person, itd be Dave Duchoveny because its hot on the outside and just as good while its in you. BUT....you wake up knowing you got worked.

Pours hazy brown with ruby tint and a small off white head. Nose is fruity, peaches, raisins, light citrus, caramel, toffee and some light spice. Taste is sweet with great bitter balance. The mouthfeel is creamy, clean, heavy body and a long do finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from 2008. Pours clear deep reddish brown with a large creamy beige head that leaves decent lacing. Room filling aroma of caramel, toffee, whiskey. Flavor is about the same, medium sweet with a bit of orange citrus in the mix..Lightly zesty finish, a bit acidic. Medium body, bubbly champagne like mouth feel. Quite nice.

Draft at Fermentation. Clear copper pour with a frothy white head. Big, sweet caramel driven aroma with underlying dates, figs, brown sugar, banana bread with notes of piney hops. Flavor is caramel malts, fig, dates, french toast, and hints of hop bitterness in the end. Big, bold beer thats on the sweet and boozy side.

12 ounce bottle.  Pours a dark amber with a nice biege head.  Aroma of malt, dark fruit, and hops.  Taste is caramel malt, raisins, prunes, toffee, chocolate, and hops.  Some alcohol warming.  Very good!

Pours amber-red with a minimal head. Aroma is heavy malts - almost like animal feed (not in a bad way) & molasses. Taste is light molasses, maybe a faint citrus, & mellowed malts. The alcohol is well hidden. This is like the candy of Barley Wines. Awesome!!

Bottle. Slightly murky amber pour with a soapy head - looks like it has some heft. Fruity sweet and malty nose. Full palate. Taste is malty with sweet caramel and fruit. Very nice. Some alcohol burn is present on the finish.

2010 batch on draft at the pour house nj. Pours ruby red with a solid white head. Aroma is banana bread malt and vanilla with a healthy hop dose. Taste is caramelized sugar, toffee malt and floral hops. Rich and complex, lives up to the hype.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2012 From 2010 bottle. 2 years old. Appearance is a dark orange/ruby. Lots of yeasties floating around in the brew from its long aging process. Tiny lip of white head. The aroma is strong and wonderful: caramel malts, orange, and cherries. No signs of oxidation in the taste. The sweetness of this beer is still well balanced by what must have been a substantial hopping. Another six months and I feel this beer will strike the perfect balance. Mouthfeel is spot on for the style.

One year old bottle poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a miniature snifter. Pours a darker copper color with a beige head of foam and not much retention. The aroma has dark fruity notes playing along with some floral, fruity hops. The taste has some bitterness initially, but I think they are mostly dulled from the age. They are still there, but just not that strong. The malt is the dominant player here giving way to nutty, roasty, caramel notes. Thick and chewy mouthfeel. Another nice sipper.

Bottle.  Deeper hazy dark copper with a slightly off-white head.  Nicely bitter citrus hops, some herbal notes as well, then a very rich dark fruit and malty aromas come in as well.  More restrained in the hop department than other US barleywines, but still nicely bitter (rated a fresh sample) with drier toffee, some dark malt sweetness, and some fruitiness and citrus.  Warming medium to thicker body with solid carbonation.
Orange/amber. Nose is perspiration, port, sherry, sugar, orange. Taste is port, orange, booze.

Backlog late 2011/early 2012...bottle...Pours a nice ruby color with a medium lt tan head.  Aroma is malty with candied fruits, some spicy notes, and earthy hoppiness.  Flavor has dark fruits, breadiness, toffee, and spicy/earthy hoppiness...nice bitterness comes through.  Mouthfeel is medium/full and the finish is warming and dry with an earthy/woody note.

1/16/2010 - A little alcohol goes a long way on a shivering, cold winter night. It reasons that a lot of alcohol goes an even longer way, and better used for even more frigid evenings. This bottle of Victory Old Horizontal was deployed for one of those well-digging cold nights, and it suited the climate very well. Caramel colored with gradients of red and brown, muddy, and nothing on top but a light gray fuzz, the Old Horizontal pours a ponderous beer. The aroma is thick and clotted with chocolate, chalk, a pleasant edge of alcohol, and freshly chopped almonds and hazelnuts - almost as if the brewers added a tablespoon of Nutella to each bottle. The taste features the same menagerie of chocolate and nutty flavors, but the alcohol really shines here, poking through the dark chocolate haziness. The aftertaste is short, begging the drinker to take another sip to garner that addicting chocolate and Nutella flavor, but the alcohol tempers the pace. The hazelnut makes this brew special. but I also appreciate how a high alcohol content, for once, enhances the beer, rather than spoiling its other virtues.

12 oz. bottles shared by Dan- thanks again, Dan! 2005, 2006, and 2008 lined up side-by-side. Pours a cloudy amber color with no head, although the 2008 has some bubbles. Notes of brown sugar, caramel, dark fruits, nuts, toast, and sweet bread. Medium bodied, with a malty mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. Solid barley wine that was fairly consistent across the board, although I did prefer the 2006 and 2008 to the 2005. Still, it didnt quite live up to its reputation and therefore my expectations.
Bottle, had this one a little while ago, it pours a nice dark and its pretty smooth and it also has a nice punch, good offering

33cl bottle @ Monks Cafe Wallingatan, Stockholm. Unclear red color with floaties in it. Medium sized beige head that leaves a fair lacing. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, raisin, plums and lightly alcohol. Taste malts, raisin, plums, alcohol and a bit sweet-bitter towards the end. Strangely enough I get some hints of chocolate as well. Medium to full body, medium carbonation.

Bottle from years ago. pour is deep copper/ brown with lots of floaties and a very thin layer of bubbles. Not much head at all.  Aroma is toffee malt, butterscotch, faint brandy notes, light spice, hints of fruit, and light  Christmas cookie. Very little oxidation.  Flavor is also loaded with spicy toffee malt. Also hints of alcohol, faint spice, and light oxidation. Carbonation is light but more than enough to sustain this one.  Creamy palate.  Light notes of fruit and brown sugar in the finish.  I think this is from around 2007 or 2008. Still drinking beautifully.

Pours a murky reddish brown with a non-existant tan head. Aroma is an onslaught of caramel malt, toffee, butterscotch, with a hint of vanilla and pleasantly surpressed alcohol. Taste opens sweet with the alcohol somewhat present before turning into a pungent, sticky bitterness. Finish is long, body thick and creamy.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours cloudy brown with a Jon bubbly head. Aroma is sweet and hoppy. Thin but soft on the palate and a bit fizzy. A bitter barrel aged taste. Good selection by Victory. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPad
This is my go to brew from Victory Brewing Co. Makes a perfect growler. This is a must try for darker ale lovers.

1998 bottle drank yesterday with Keith, Kev, and James. Mourked out brown pour, no lacing or head. Aromas of plum, caramel, wood, roasted malt and spices. Rich and frutiy hop taste with tons of dark fruit and brown sugars. Complex as hell from the 15 years of age. Awesome barleywine.

2012.05.13 - 12oz bottle in tulip glass.  Pours deep amber orange, mostly opaque.   Two finger off white bubbly head settles slowly.  Aroma is earthy and hops, maybe some raisin as this reminds me a bit of the aroma of a few years' old Dogfish Head Raison D'extra.  Taste is complex.  Front end is spicy, giving way to more earthy warm alcohol.  Not bad, a bit heavy for a frequent drinker.

355ml bottle pours an amber orange color with a small white head that leaves some thin spotty lacing.  Aromas of fruits and mild hops with some alcohol and grains.  Taste is delicious fruit and malty sweetness with some toasted notes and a mild hoppy bitterness.  A truly outstanding barley wine that I will definitely try again in the future.

Pours an expected cloudy dark amber orange with thin off-white head, minimal lacing.  Aroma of caramel, toffee, slightly nutty, toasted malt, citrus, and vanilla.  Flavor matches well, but doesnt have the depth that I look for in great bws.

2009 vintage bottle.  Pours a brown caramel color with a small off white head.  The aroma is rich malts, caramel, dark fruit, raisins, and booze.  The taste is malty, sweet, and fruity.  The bitterness is firm and the boozy finish is a bit harsh at first but really mellows as the beer warms.  Very good overall.

Hard Liver.

Pours peachy orange with decent head and retention. Malt and sugar in the smell, bit of straw. Taste is dry, bitterish, grainy. Light to mid bodied. A bit bland.
Pours a red amber with a tan head. Very nice lacing. Smell is of toasted malts, cherries, caramel. Came on very strong, candy/malt opening and middle, with a with a hop bite finish.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2012 Draft. Pours a mahogany brown with a small head. Aroma is very bready with some dark fruit (plum, fig, raisins). Taste is bitter and sweet with some booze on the finish.  This was a 2007 vintage draft at Victory that was pretty smooth but I imagine there was a little more bitterness when this was fresh.  Cant wait until they resume brewing this annually.

Bottle 33 cl, trade. pours brown amber with a great creamy beige head leaving lace. Aroma fills the room with sweet caramel, raisins, fidges, fruits, malts, some yeast and red berries.Fantastic. Flavor is excellent; fantastic malt base, great balanced bitterness with nice citric touch, fruity, malty, vinous, raisins, fidges and all that a good BW should have. Finishes bitter and sweet malty.

Bottle @ Monks cafe Wallingatan. Hazy murky brown to copper pour with a tiny off-white head and some large yeast rocks. Aroma is very fruity and malty with sugary and spicy tones. Very full bodied flavor with loads of malty goodness and a very well balanced rounded flavor, quite sweet and a bit alcoholic, but very good.

Cloudy brownish-orange color with two fingers of light tan head. There is a decent amount of lacing for a barleywine. The smell is fairly balanced; some malt, some hops, and some alcohol. A nice aroma. The taste is malty at first, with some sugary sweetness and some honey. The finish is nice and hoppy with some alcohol warmth.

sweet hoppyness in the nose, old malt essences as well, somewhat cloudy medium amber hue lacing head, hops hits first in this battle, then the malty richness, which lends to carmel notes accumlating into a very well balance american barleywine! overall best barleywine Ive ever had, Iam gonna miss your loving late in the midwinter season baby!
user_location: @RED BHUT JOIKIAS!, Paulsboro, New Jersey, USA

text: Bottle. Lots more butterscotch in the sweetness to resinous ratio than other barleywines. Plenty of boozy warmth in the finish. I thought this was a little off balanced in favor of malt, but I actually prefer that in barleywines.

(From notes) Tap @ 38 Degree Alehouse, Alhambra, CA (end of 2009). Red brown color, small creamy head, off white. Aroma: roasted malts, hopbitter, sweet. Flavor is sweet & medium bitter. Strong alcoholfeel (warms the throat). Finishes quite bitter, with still some malty sweet for balance. Good.

2009 Vintage Bottle pours a reddish brown with small light tan head.  Aromas are caramel and dark fruits and some bitterness.  Taste is caramel, cherry, raisins, and some nice bold hoppiness that keeps this from being too sweet.  Body is full, carbonation is average.  Finish is long and bitter after some sweetness up front.  Overall, a very nice barleywine with great rounded edges (thanks to the aging).

8-oz draft @ Pony with Paul. Pours a mirky amber-brown. Sweet, sugary aromas and a complex, fruity, bitter palate with medium mouthfeel and good drinkability. Really solid take on the style - a well-rounded, classic barleywine.

Since Im not a huge barleywine fan, i didnt expect to like this...and I was wrong. Great beer!! Huge flavor without having the "wine" kind of flavor to it. For an 11% barleywine I couldnt be more surprised with how good this was!

Purchased at Armanettis in Chicago, IL; enjoyed while watching week 13 Sunday night football.  Appearance is a cloudy, murky brown with a thin off white head, looks a bit sludgy but nice.  Aroma is very malty, mostly caramel, sweet with a unique fruit smell, doesnt smell too boozey but it is prevalent.  Taste does hit you with sweetness, like a syrupy cherry/plum flavor.  Heavy body with medium carbonation.  You get hit with the booze but it doesnt taste like it, hid nicely.  Good barley wine.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2012 Happily stumbled across a lonely bottle of this stuff. Nice reddish-orange pour with minimal khaki head. Aroma of sweet fruits. Taste was massively sweet with a tingling bitter hop presence. Palate was surprisingly not too heavy at 11% ABV. Victory isnt releasing any Old Horizontal this year, so I lucked out finding a bottle from last year. Lots of big flavor and a nice slow sipper.

12oz bottle. Pours a clear, reddish-brown color with a light tan head and some lacing. Aroma is fruity, cherry, plum, a little bit of alcohol. A little heavy on the palate with average carbonation. Flavor is sweet, malty, fruity, raisin, a little boozy, with a sweet, boozy finish. One of my favorite barleywines.

When I bought this, I saw the 11%abv and braced myself for a rocky ride.  The taste has practically no wine-o skank, yet all the flavors of a ballsy brew.
