The multiple layers hit quick and linger with a satisfying finish. This stuff was awesome, big barley-fruit taste, smooth, poured with an amber fog and light amount of foam.  Delicious.  Grab it when you see it.

Another high ABV barley wine that I cant taste a boozy finish at all in.  This one could really catch up with you.  Nice sweetness with flavors of dark fruits and earthy notes.  Tasty stuff from Victory.

12 oz. Hey-o a beer that I can buy in a local store. Its missing that rare taste. Light barleywine flavors, so many of these big ones are tough to drink, delicious but tough to drink. This one is a highly drinkable well carbonated barley wine. Bam great beer. nuff sed.

Bottle/12oz - Pours a darkis burnt umber in color with a small tan head.  Aroma is malt with caramel/toffee, some dark fruit and a bit of the booze.  Flavor is fairly strong of caramel/toffee with dark fruit, a small amount of citrus and some vanilla.  A bit boozy at the end, but not enough to detract from this excellent beer...
Bottle. Pours a dark orange/brownish. Nice size head.caramel, roasty, floral, vanilla, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, average carbonation, long finish,  nice beer.

pours dark amber with a nice tan head. Smell: Toffee, chocolate, cherries, booze and maybe a hint of tobacco. Taste: Caramel, cherry, chocolate, raisins, and booze. Thick on the mouth coats it nice. Finish long and sweet with a nice hop bitterness
UPDATED: DEC 24, 2013 Warm flavorful ale, very strong with many taste changes as it warms to the room. At room temperature it is a lot better than the 50 degs I keep it at.

2010 vintage pours dark amber with a halo of tan head. Smell: Toffee, chocolate, raisins, cherries, booze and dates. Taste: Caramel, cherry, chocolate, raisins, grapefruit, pine and booze. Thick on the mouth. Finish long and sweet with a nice hop bitterness.

Pours a dark brownish-red, thin head that leaves some lacing.  Aroma is predominantly sweet; orange, caramel, malt.  Tastes of orange and caramel,  with a hop profile that emerges at the end of each sip.  A slight alcohol burn, which is fine for 11%.  Very delicious.
What a nice barley wine. Brown pour with nice tan head. Very sweet and fruity with not much alcohol taste, surprisingly at 11%. Very nice caramel and toast after taste.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2011 Aroma of floral, dark fruits, orange creme?,.  Pours deep orange with a half pint head.   Tastes of floral, spices and citrus.  Taste is complex with orange peel, barley and some malt.  Amazing and complex barleywine.
Rerated a 2009 draft @ pourhouse.  Little more alcohol kick but still well-hidden.

At a tasting, thanks Troubles, pours stunning red with a nice head, aroma of caramel, toffee, wood, vanilla and some hops, flavor of marmalade, strawberry, vanilla, grapefruit skin and some woody notes, full bodied, nice

Bottle sample at a tasting. Thanks Davids friend! Clear deep red color with an off-white head. Aroma of resinous hops and caramelly malt. Flavor starts sweet and malty with caramel and a bit of fruitiness and continues resinous and hoppy with moderate bitterness. Medium to full-bodied.

Clear reddish brown color with off white head and little lacing.  Aromas of caramel, vanilla, molasses, alcohol, and spices.  Sweet taste with light bitterness.  Some brown sugar taste.  Palate is average carbonation with nice dry finish.  Overall, this is really good.  Alcohol hidden well, smooth finish, and nice flavor.  Victory does another awesome beer.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Snifter.

Appearance: Cloudy red that really glows in the light. Foamy head at first that settles back but leaves nice lacing.

Aroma: Caramel, the ever mysterious dark fruit, cherry, spicy hops, figs, and a strong alcohol punch.

Taste: Very rich and sweet malty character upfront with caramel, cherry, butterscotch, figs and dark fruit. Turns somewhat spicy and bitter toward the end, but much less so than many American Barleywines.

Palate: Moderate carbonation, thick syrupy body, somewhat dry at the end, and very warming.

Overall: I really like that this has a little less assertion in the hop department than many American Barleywines - like it already has a little age on it. The only issue I have is that it is very alcoholic.
a very decent brew. The booze is hidden very well making this an easy drinker fresh.

Purchased at Remeke/Biggs in Cincinnati, Ohio - The twelve ounce bottle poured a very dark mahogany hued brew with a complex, delightful malty grass aroma. Tastewise, this is a great beer, a wonderfuly complex, rich brew with somehints of datrs to its flavor. Great stuff!

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2014 12oz bottle.
Amber orange pour with some off-white head.  Citrus hop aroma with some dark fruit and toffee.  High ABV definitely shows with some heat - lot of hops in the flavor with some caramel malt.  I bet this would be much better with some age.

This is not my style of beer, but as far as barleywines go, this one is drinkable.  Big, bold, full-bodied in your face barleywine.  Fruity flavors that help balance the taste of alcohol, bitter finish, that gives you the warming sensation.  I wont drink too many of these, but a must try for beer drinkers.

Bottle poured into snifter.  Clear, dark amber color with a two finger beige head that reduces rather quickly into a thin film.  Aroma is malt, brown sugar, molasses, hops and alcohol.  Excellent mixture of flavors including dried fruit, molasses, roasted malt, and a touch of vanilla.  Nice sweetness followed by some lingering bitterness in the finish.

very rich as the label says but very easy to drink. Took my time with it, as it is 11% but also wanted to really enjoy it. nice burnt amber color, aroma is of dark fruit and syrup. taste is pretty much the same, a little abv burn, but the sweetness eases it a little.

Bottle --> Goblet. Pours a very faint and slightly hazy orange, with a quickly fading head. Aromas are sharp of hops, twizzlers and brown sugar with an indefinite spice of alcohol. The taste was strong of hops and alcohol, with undertones of caramel and ripe fruits. Finished warm and bitter.. Elegantly in the most robust way possible.

Im loving these barley wines! Aroma was seductive, hitting notes of cherry, vanilla, butterscotch, caramel, spicy hops, and alcohol. Awesome! Poured a dark amber color with light-brown head. Nice taste of caramel and cherry, with a ghostly vanilla character. Very warming alcohol. Victory is always impressing me.

A: The pour is dark amber, perhaps copper, with a finger of off-white head.

S: A surprisingly sharp grapefruit aroma to this one with a lot of floral notes to it as well.  Some slight booze, but otherwise a nice malt character.  A bit of brown sugar, toffee, and caramel.

T: Some citrus hop notes up front with a mild bitterness, but this is a pretty sweet barleywine.  Lots of toffee and brown sugar sweetness with a slight creaminess to it, maybe a bit of molasses.

M: Medium bodied with a medium level of carbonation.

O: A pretty nice barleywine, especially for one that is pretty much always available.

Appearance is murky ruby, little to no head and with lots of floating yeasties.  Aroma is dried fruit, earthy hops, and caramel candy.  Taste is very much like the aroma with dried fruits, caramel, and a lasting hop sting.  Body is medium full with lively carbonation, sticky mouthfeel and a lingering bitter finish.  Overall, a good barleywine but not great.  It is somewhat one-dimensional compared with others I have sampled.  I just like a little bit more complexity in my barleywines.

Bottle to snifter. (most likely a 2010) pour is clear dark amber with a foamy off white head that fades to nothing on top. Aroma is sweet brown sugar caramel with some spicy hop notes. Taste is more malt sugar and caramel  and spices. Palate is full sticky and finishes chaulky. Solid barleywine!

12 oz. from Bruisin. Best before December 15, 2015. What a fantastic barley wine. The emphasis is obviously on the malt and yeast character. There are notes of molasses, tons of fig, berries and a spiced finish. The good thing about Old Horizontal is that while it is sweet and full bodied, it never gets too sticky or too heavy. The palate and balance are just about perfect. A few more sips let some vanilla flavor peek out beneath the fruity notes. This is one of the better barley wines even though there are no real surprises to be had.

This is a big delicious beer. Extremely heady. Its like a beer shake. Drink once in the morning, and once after you workout. One of my favorite beers and if youre lucky to come across it, theres no question you pick up the six pack.

1997 vintage courtesy of miller2244. wow. just wow. this is amazing. almost no signs of oxidation, the little bit that is there very faintly detectable is very developed and full and smooth after 14 years. i dont know why i dont see more hype about aging this one, it holds up insanely well. reminiscent of hardys ale. pours a dark hazy copper with a small off white head that leaves good spotting for its size. aroma is slightly funky cheese and concord grape juice upfront, mellowing into sweet dusty malts and creamier brie like cheeses. the flavor is amazing, really tastes barrel aged almost, tons of wood, oak maple, sweet cereal and dusty old oatmeal, some gym socks, butterscotch sundays, toffee, just amazingly delicious. the mouthfeel is thick and full, oily, salty, very little sign of the abv except for a slight warming in the chest, nothing in the mouth except stinky candy! yummy! proper carbonation level, this is a severely overlooked world class brew. this bottle is actually less cheesy and stinky than one thats about 5 years old. if the grape juice like areas of this increase in 10 years it will be pretty similar to a hardys, which i had a 1986 only a couple weeks ago. far and away victorys best brew. always iso.

Vom Geruch her ähnelt er stark dem vorher getesteten Mikkeller Stateside India Pale Ale, der Geschmack ist aber eine ganz andere Sache. Das Bier startet schon alkoholisch, im Nachgeschmack steigert sich dieses Aroma noch. Im Mittelteil ist es dagegen eher hopfig und leicht herb, wohinter sich der alkoholische Teil zum Glück recht gut verbergen kann. Geht in Ordnung. 	 
Test vom 8.8.2006, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 8,10,8,12,6,9

3-4 year old bottle from dmac(thanks!)  Very dark amber/brown pour, a little carbonation and sweet prune & spicy malt aroma.  Flavor is slightly oxidized brown sugar, more prunes, a little herbs and a finished dry and with a little pine bite on the aftertaste.  Very good beer and even better with some age one it.

12oz bottle thanks to grub. Enjoy by Nov 2015.
Appearance : clear amber with a medium foamy head.

Aroma : Fruits with resinous hops. Light licorice. Opens up a bit more after warming up a bit. Great sugary notes, nice sweetness. Some herbal hops.

Taste : Great fruits with nice sweetness. Some resinous hops. Warm and bitter finish. Very soft carbonation, maybe a bit too soft. 

Overall : This started a bit boring but it was way too cold. Got much more interesting as it warmed up. I really liked the sugary sweetness very "barley sugar" like. Nice fruits. Hops are not very aromatic but give quite a sharp and bitter finish (maybe a little too much). Quite drinkable considering the abv.

On tap at the blind tiger. Pours a reddish copper with a big billowing white head. Could smell the taster in the guys hand who was sitting behind next to me which prompted me to grab a glass of this one. Aroma was full of thick toffee, raisins and syrupy malts. Super sweet taste but still loved this one. Sweet honey and toffee mix with complex fruits. A unique beer of its style. Loads of hops. Fantastic

Poured a redish brown with little to no head as expected.  Nose was certainly hoppy and sweet.  Taste was a little hot but as hoppy as the nose.  Had some good syrupy toffee and complex fruit notes with loads of maltiness.  Not bad.

aroma is piney hops,citrus,darker fruits,yeastiness and spice very inviting..reddish amber brown with very thin head that leaves lacing..tastes like it smells refreshing to have a hop balance and tingliness to what is usually a sweet or smoky style but plenty of fruitiness and spicy/sweet flavors as well..well carbonated for the style..tingly and bitter finish with a bit of alcohol warmth..overall..one of my favorites for this style very nicely surprised love the additional hop character

Poured a hazy reddish brown with a bubbling off-white head.  Some alcohol in the aroma with lots of syrupy malt flavors.  Fruit aromas with some raisins.  Taste has lots of fruit with alcohol and caramel malts.  It is quite complex with raisins, and bitter grassy hops at the finish.  Slightly earthy, and with an almost chewy candy flavor in the finish.  Overall it is quite complex and well balanced.

Bottle, expires in 2015.  Nice initial head with a lace thats lasts throughout on edge.   .  Fruit flavors of sour apple, cherry, sweet slight bitter hops,  caramel,warming finish, sticky.  Good balance of sweetness and hops for a smooth finish.  11% very well maked.
Aroma of caramel, some malts and raisins.  Flavor is more hoppy and pale ale like to balance the sweetness.  Good balanced mouthfeel and finish.  I could have a couple of these no doubt.

Bottle. Hazy dark copper with beige head. Bottle conditioned. Aromas of caramel, toffee, cereal, cherry, wood smoke, spice. Flavors of caramel, toffee, cereal, cherry, wood smoke, dank, alcohol, spice. Slightly sweet finish with hop attenuation. Full body with thick mouthfeel and moderate carbonation.  Dangerously drinkable.

cloudy, amber.  Very sweet, caramel, bready.  Despite the overall sweetness there is a slight taste of soured fruit which I am not sure I like so much.  Overall ok but would like to re rate when not part of a larger tasting of top notch barley wines.

Bottle pours a dark amber/ruby with spare off-white head.  Aroma of breaded malts and alcohol.  Flavors of grapes, raisins, allspice, pepper, and ginger.  Heavy alcohol presence.  Heavy hops which, to me, is unusual for this style.

Reviewed from notes. Bottle was 9 months old.

Pours a moderate copper brown with a very alight head that quickly receded. Nose brought sweet dark fruits, caramel, and a bit of citrus. Taste was mostly sweet malt with some booze. Mild fruit throughout. No specifics really detectable. Medium body and a bit boozy. Drinks pretty well at this age bit it could definitely use a bit longer.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-20-2010

12 oz bottle. Pours a ruby red amber with an off white head. Fresh and hoppy balanced by notes of sweet and sour candied fruit. I am enjoying the hops but I cant wait to see how this ages. The body is thick but still soft and smooth, leaving a bit of a stick. Mmmmmmmm!

Aroma: smelled like someone was making caramel in the kitchen.
Appearance: Dark Amber Clear, Head was light color and didnt last long. 
Taste: This is where it got interesting. I bought a six pack because a rep at a liquor store told me it was pretty good. I had never heard of this beer but Id tasted the V-12 and love that one. So I gave it a try. I took my first sip and was blown away. This beer was a perfect standard of a barleywine style. Even for being fresh and not aged, it was perfectly balanced and well rounded out with the perfect amount of hops and malt. Not too sweet up front like the smell suggested. The finish was a bit sweet but that didnt linger too long. Just went right for the next sip!
Palate: Mouth feel was big and malty, but refreshing with slight citrus overtones from the hops.
Overall: This is one of my newest favorites! The new gold standard for Barleywines!
Bottle.  Pours clear amber with a fizzy white head.  Aroma is subtle hops, citrus, caramel, herbs.  Taste is bready with a slight hops finish.  Satisfying.
Very little aroma. Taste is nicely pungent - good representation of a barley wine. not overly impressed with the finish, which seemed to fade quickly. Nice beer.
Dark orange color with almost no head. Bitter, hop flavor with a lot of alcohol. The finish was a slightly sweet caramel. Its OK, but not something I would try again.
Draft at the brewpub: pours a dark amber, hoppy aroma, strong flavor of dark fruit with a bitter hop bite in the finish.
Draft. Very fruity. Brown color nice head. Delicioud aroma. Taste very sweet. And sticky, but grerat overall. Wish i could elaborayte more but its good! Believe me

Copper/caramel a bit more redness than the standard. nice foamy head, sticks around a bit into clumps of suds with some bigger bubbles swirled in. 

I have a hard time smelling much of anything. A bit of cherry, some brown sugar, black/bruised/old banana, no hops to speak of, no alcohol really either, which could be a good thing I suppose. an almost funky stale smell as well.

taste, very much like it smells, weak, really weak. I dont really get anything from this. some toffe and mushed old banana with dried cherries. ends with the pit, bitter. not a good pine bitter or citrus bitter. just straight bitter finish.

soft smooth attach, not oily, not enough hops for that, rigid on the end from the bitterness. slightly thin, but not enough to be watery. slightly below style.

Pours ruby red with slightly off white head. Aroma has notes of big toffee, molasses, dark fruit, some spices, touch of hops.  Taste is nice and full on the palate, thick buttery hops up front blend well into dark fruit, caramel and toffee notes, some spice and dark fruit, finishing bitter and slightly sweet with even a hint of vanilla.  Some nice fruit flavors lie in there as well.  Excellent beer!

A 2009 bottle from my basement. Pours cloudy brown with redish hue, the nose is perfect for a barley wine with a little bit of age on it. The smell of fruity ketones dominates. The first sip is sweet and smooth. Malt dominates with just a hint of hops left. Really great stuff.

Bottle says "Enjoy by Nov 15 2015," so Im guessing this was from the 2010 batch?

Pours an orange-tinged ruby with a small head, lacing is fairly mimimal at first and completely gone within 10 minutes. Aroma is dark, dried fruits, and a ton of resiny, earthy hops.  Palate is very sweet up front and quite bitter on the finish. Interesting contrast, with most of the maltiness lending itself towards the dark fruit, rum, and some mild toffee flavors, braced against the bold hopping. Theres not a lot of complexity, and I found the hoppy finish along with the simple sweetness to really become a bit grating as the glass wore on. Maybe some age would settle this one down? Decent, but for fresh barley wines, there are far better out there.

Copper/amber in color with a white, two-finger head.

Nice malty sweet aroma with some grape hints and hops.

Pretty solid hop lead that rests on caramel, butter, and nuts. Very crisp. A solidly sharp barleywine. Malty with a citrus hop edge.

Nice balance of fruity hops and sweet malts. Not super rich and not super sweet but a very enjoyable and drinkable. I look forward to another.
Pours a dark reddish brown color with a light brown creamy head. Aroma is of some sugar and maple. Taste is warming. Some maple sugar flavors with some slightly bitter tones.

Clear deep amber orange reddish pour beige head sticky lacing soapy. Sweet caramel and earthy grainy and bitter hop aroma taste fruits very smooth rich caramel burnt with a grainy malty little bitter hop boozy finish loved it

God I love winter. The best beer comes out this time of year. This has a beautiful amber color and the palate radiates a kind of warmth. I look forward to aging this one and trying it again next winter.
Crystal clear, dark amber.  Thick malt, alcohol at the end with a slightly oily mouthfeel.  Overall a good barleywine.

Pours a dense dark chocolate color with a soft, pillowy head. Thick lacing. Well-balanced smoky nose, with just a hint of grapefruit and raisin. Stunning sour malt backbone, with notes of papaya and old newsprint. Tightly carbonated mouthfeel and bitter finish.

Growler from Whole Foods. Aroma- Malty sweetness slight caramel, hint of alcohol and some fruit notes. Appearance- Cloudy copper almost a muted orange. Thin layer of tan head. Flavor slight sweetness and a hint of caramel dries up into an almost aggressive bitterness with some alcohol warming. A very enjoyable barley wine. Wonderful aroma.

Theres a barely discernable "Enjoy By" date on the front label by the moon. "Enjoy By" 2014 is a candidate for the holy grail; it is perfect and mind-blowing and there is nothing better...cloudy nectarine color, beautiful when you hold it to the light; rich carmel-y, nutty bread dough and pine complexity finishing into something completely different from where it started. "Enjoy By" 2015 is completely average...darker in color and clear, the rich complexity and butterscotch-ness isnt there, and its therefore a short-lived trip. This is a bottle conditioned ale that lends itself to cellaring, so in 12 months time, will "Enjoy By 2015" morph into what "Enjoy By 2014" is now? Maybe. But its hard to imagine it transforming itself to that extent. Buyers Guide: If it appears cloudy in the bottle and the yeast is stacked at the bottom, buy in mass. If clear in the bottle with just a little yeast at the base, avoid if your intent is to drink now.

Pours murky blood orange color with short lived white head.  Smells of booze, grapefruit, caramel, toffee and earthy notes. Taste sweet but balanced by bitterness of hops, candied fruit, burnt caramel, dried dark fruits, and a welcome boozy malt sweetness. Mouthfeel was thick, syrupy, very bitter with a mild prickly carb. Tastey complex beer with a great bitter backbone.

Pours a slightly cloudy ruby, orange, amber color with a bubbly off white head that sticks around for a bit. Smells of piny citrusy hops. A little bread and caramel for good measure. Tastes of caramel malts, crisp citrus hops and a bit of alcohol in there too. Thick mouthfeel and body. Definitely a sipper here. Great thick barley wine.

Pours a dark brown with a light tan head. aroma is cinnamon, caramel, sugar and sweet malts. taste is boozy caramel with decent hoppiness to it. Palate is outstanding. warms you up like no other. Overall a very good brew
Heavy malt aroma.  Red-amber in color with a tan head.  Excellent maty roasted flavors with light berry-like undertones.
tap at RnH - deep toffee malts, fruity strawberry, some spice and a boozey finish.

Nice fruity aroma with whisky hints and some malts. Really well balanced barley wine with a huge alcohol bite that creeps here and there. Decent amount of fruit bouquet in the build up to a whisky like meltdown into a subtle hop balanced malt, sharing space with an Earth like wet-soil and leaves.

Pours a clear copper with a full frothy head.  Rich caramel aroma, sweet fruits, and strong booze.  Extremely rich malt character with caramel and chocolate.  The alcohol can be felt in mid palate and carries through with the hops that lead to a dry bitter finish.

Pour is a mahogany with a minimal head that is reduced to a ring of lacing. Nose if of dark fruits, some apple notes and sugar like notes. Very fruity notes on the tongue, rather sweet. Somewhat thick with minimal carbonation, and an overall rich barley wine.

Bottle.  Medium amber pour, small off-white head.  Nose of dark fruits, caramelly sugars, and some earthy, herbal hops.  Tastes along similar lines, has a dark fruit and caramel front, finishing on a strong herbal, earthy hop bitterness.  Still has a big hop presence even though this bottles over a year old.  Somehow manages to get a watery feel around the finish, which is odd for a barley wine.  Moderately heavy body.

Bottle. Pours ruby-mahogany, small off-white head that reduces to a ring of lacing. Nose is ripe apple, fruitcake, hint of vanilla and wood. Startling hop presence on the tongue, along with dark fruits, a sharpness I cant quite pinpoint (maybe ginger?), slight wood, and alcohol. Warming finish. Nothing to rave about, but very good nonetheless.

Deep burgundy pour with a dense cappuccino head. Strong malt aroma with a ton of dark fruit, possibly plums and cherries. Roasty with just a hint of floral hops. Flavor is malt- and fruit-forward. Caramel and chocolate, with dark fruit flavors accentuated by just enough citrus hops for balance. Pretty boozy, lots of warmth. Palate is creamy with an average amount of carbonation. I really liked the flavors in this, but Id definitely like to get my hands on an aged version too see if the alcohol mellows out. Not sure Id want to drink it fresh again.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2011 Aroma is malt, almost toasted, slight booze, dark cherry. Taste is full malt up front, cherry sweet, alcohol is apparant. Bittering hops are there to add some balance, but its still a malt forward beer. Good beer.
Excellent beer. Really hits the spot after a long day. Lots of notes making this a very complex brew. Worth the money any time its in stock.

Pours a clear brown with tan head that quickly dissipated.  Aroma is spices, bread, caramel, raisins and alcohol.  Taste is sweet and spicey,  the alcohol is hidden well but starts to become noticeable during warmup.  Nice warm finish, somewhat sticky.  A excellent barleywine.
Very tasty.  Lots of roasted malt aroma and flavor.  Surprisingly hoppy (in a good way).

An amazing Barleywine beer! has a taste of raisins, brown sugar, toffee with a nice hoppiness and some malt. has an impressive aroma, which is what got me interested in the first place and is a flavor explosion to the palette.

09 bottle Im guessing.  Attractive brown/red in the glass with steady carbonation.  Aroma is chewy raisin, thick sweet malt, dark fruit, and some slightly sharper juicy plum notes.  The aroma is potent but structured very tightly and not overly boozie or gnarly like many barley wines.  Flavor does not quite follow the aroma.  Up front I get a slight bitterness followed by classic heavy and sweet raisin, malt, and a somewhat dry booze finish enveloped in caramel.  I do not get much of the sweet juicy fruit from the aroma in the taste.  I do appreciate, however, that the flavor profile is relatively tight and even dry for a barley wine.  Good beer.

12 oz. bottle. Best by date of 11/15/15 which means it will age. ABV 11%. Served at cellar temperature. Pours a thin, short lived, off white head, over a dark amber (SEM 12) clear body......nose is heavy caramel/toffee, with dried fruits, including cherry, raisin, plum, fig, light citron....taste is sweet malts to start with layers of dried fruits including raisin, plum, bit of cherry, toffee/ caramel, finishing with pineapple, a soft lingering bitterness, accompanied by a harsh alcohol with terpenes type bite....mouth feel is thick and sticky, alcohol has a slightly hot sensation, carbonation adds a soft foamy quality. This is obviously young, and somewhat raw, but I couldnt wait to try it. I think this will age brilliantly and I need to acquire some more. BJCP 7/3/15/4/7

Pours red-amber with a little light brown head and good lacing. Nose is mostly malt with a lot of grain (Id assume barley) to it and some crisp hops in the background. Flavor is on the sweet side for a barleywine, with lots of malt and brown sugar all the way through and only moderate hops and bitterness. Alcohol is relatively hidden. Good stuff.

My 1000th rating 12 oz. bottle. Colour... copper-amber with no head. Nose... pretty hoppy but the malt is there too. Palate... burst of carbonation and hops, light brown sugar, golden raisins, moderate booze, dark corn sirup, toffee and a creamy mouth feel.

Pours a nice clear brown and whispy head.  The aroma is a nice mingling of hops and malt - sweet, citrus, bready.  Delicious malt flavors - sweet, biscuit/bread - hidden cirtus flavor.  Medium body, moderate hop bitter finish.  Nice American barleywine.

Bottle thanks to Dan! Pours a near clear amber caramel with a grayish brown head that dissipated to the edges. Aroma is full of sweet caramel with some sweet bread and a slight hop backing to balance the sweetness. A hint of alcohol well. Flavor is similarly sweet with lots of caramel, a slight dark fruit underlying as well as some sweet grains. There was a slight alcohol burn in the finish,

Bottle thanks to frostyone.  Dark red pour and a creamy generous head and sticky lace.  Nose is sweet cara and sweet, bready malts and extremely floral hops thats similar to their prima pils.  Taste is similar but not really that toffee or caramel like but really toasty and bicuity mixed with floral hops finishes bitter.  Slick and full body.  Good and a little different than the classic american barley wine

On draft at the Oldsmar Tap House. Pours a beautiful mahagony with a medium white head. Aroma is big with dark fruit, caramel malt, and maple syrup. Nice smooth mouthfeel with a warming alcohol finish. Notes of raisin, cranberry, maple syrup, and caramel. This one is very complex as it evolves with every sip. Im normally not a big barley wine fan but this one is very solid. Great job Victory.
Served too cold at Mellow Mushroom Pensacola FL. Hazy brown and muted nnose. Taste is full of hops and strong alcohol presence. Good cigar and fireside ale.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Deep amber with a very long head. The aroma has lots of dried fruit and toffee. The taste has absolutely no trace of the high alcohol content. It is a perfect balance of the bitter grapefruit from the hops and the creamy, toffee flavored malt.

Bottle pour gives murky cola color with medium beige head.  Aroma malts with floral hops.  I thought damn another US over-hopped beer but I was happily mistaken.  Taste  sweet malts very nicely balanced by hops.  Finish brief and crisp.  Palate thick, bordering on syrupy.  Alcohol evident but not intrusive.  Very nice, glad i tried it.

The aroma is Malts, sweet, licorice figs/dates. Pours a dark copper brown, with an off white head almost yellow, good lacing. The taste is sweet and a little bitter. The body is full, creamy. Very good.

A slightly hazy copper pour is topped by two fingers of off-white foam.  The head persists for the duration.  The aroma is sweet malt and floral hops with a touch of fruit (I suspect comes from the yeast).  The liquor is malty and sweet with just a (well-disguised 11% ABV) hint of alcohol.  The hop malt balance is satisfying (and especially so in that Victorys tendency towards a brusque hops profile is admirably restrained), and as the brew warms the malt defines itself more so as caramel and a pleasing bitterness emerges in the finish.  By way of comparison, this seems modeled on Anchors delicious Old Foghorn, but here there is a tad more hop aroma, a bit more bitterness in the liquor and slightly less sweetness, all of which helps to define this delightful ale.
Perfection. Too drunk right now to write anything eloborate. pretty classic barley wine here. just perfectly balanced. this is a winner.

On tap @ Rattle N Hum.
Clear brown with some white head. Nice dark fruit aroma with some light hop notes and nice caramel malt. Raisins and brown sugar. Full bodied with a bit of an alcohol heat that is hidden well. Nice long finish with a touch of bitterness. Very enjoyable.
2009 Vintage on Tap at Fermentation Lounge. Poured a deep amber with some lingering head. Tastes sweet, caramel, slight citrus hop character, very balanced, hides the alcohol very well. Very nice.

Very Fruity and malty aroma is very tempting. Rocky, whispy, off-white head. Eerie, orange-brown color with a cloudy haze. Creamy and crisp palate. Malty, fruity, and hoppy flavor. Hides 10%+ ABV quite well. Best served around 50 degrees.

A: pours a dark hazy orange amber color with a nice tan head on top with a good head retention for a barleywine. good lacing as well. some sediment as well.

S: smells of sweet sticky malts. some cherries and apricots as well as some raisins. I get a hint of tea as well. Some nice malts come through but nothing very overpowering.

T: alcohol is apparent in the taste off the bat. I am also pulling some brown sugar, cherries, figs, plums, and raisins. the hops are wonderful in this, as they tend to hang around for a while.

M: mouthfeel is thick but expected for the style and ABV. very smooth for the alcohol content. great carbonation level.

D: very drinkable and a very nice american barleywine. very enjoyable.

Bottled, 12 ozer. Pour is dark brown with a deep orangeish tint. Medium head, very beautiful pour.  Aroma is sweet, raisiny, caramel and brown sugar notes, a hint of whiskey.  Feels slick yet full, wonderful sweet and bitter complexities.  Finshes hoppy and with a bit of alcohol. Rich, warming beer, very nice and very intense.

12oz - Ive had a lot of trouble with this style.  This is one of the few I like and appreciate.  Alcohol, citrus, raisins and hops on nose.  Light brown liquid and head.  Creamy richness and booze on palate, reminding me of a Baileys maybe.
Beautiful apple red pour.  Aroma of alcohol, fruits, malts and spice.  Taste is complex.  Candied fruit, caramel, alcohol, citrus, some hops toward the end.  Great beer
Pours a clear brown with a reddish hue. Brown sugar aromas. Bitter and warming. Exemplary barley wine; similar in style to Sierras Big Foot.
Pours a golden yellow color, nose is sweet, taste is quite sweet, hints of toffee and caramel.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2010 Bottle: Pours a Dark Amber - Average whiteish head - This brew makes my head want to explode - Huge malty richness with a touch of fruitiness- and its incredibly boozy as well. In spite of that, the mouthfeel is also incredibly smooth - So on one hand you want to drink this like a session, but you soon realize the error of your ways. Fantastic - I wouldnt call it "luxurious:, I would call it luscious. And when I say it makes my head explode, lets just say that everyone was feeling a little odd while drinking this in my group. "Its like a shot of botox from the inside out." Yes, we were drunk at this point.
A really nice barley wine. Very strong in its malts. Pours dark brown, a bit cloudy, good size head on it. Big nose full of malts. Overall its pretty good.

Victory Brewing
Old Horizontal
Pours copper golden with a medium off white head and good retention. Aroma of caramel malt, booze, and brown sugar with a slight hop bitterness. Flavor is much the same with a pronounced alcohol note (yum) and a lingering hop bitterness that is not too overpowering. Would probably become fuller bodied with some time.

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2010 $12 sixer - Finally broke down and took a gamble on this one.  Let me clarify, Victory is no gamble, but any barley wine is.  Better than the limited number of barley wines that I have tried, but this is still not my thing.  Wont be re-buying, but will be horizontal after I destroy this sixer.
07 vintage from the richmond beer dig Spring 2010.  Pours a clear reddish copper with khaki head.  Very mellow with lots of alcohol warming and very tasty.  lightly dark fruits.  Nice.

Pours dark amber with full frothy off-white head and moderate lacing.  Amazing, strong aroma of citrus hops, pineapple.  Sweet, creamy, full-bodied barley wine.  Sweetness isnt over done, and is well balanced by huge citrusy hop bitterness.  Toffee and a bit of chocolate, alcoholic warmth on the finish.

12 oz. bottle, pours a murky dark amber brown with a small beige head. Aroma of toffee, raisins, candied fruits, caramel and hops. Flavour is amazingly rich and complex - begins with very sweet candied fruits and toffee, with the hops kicking in later, and both a bitter and sweet finish. Full-bodied palate. Carbonation is quite high. Absolutely wonderful.

Thanks to HopHead101 for sending me this beer.

Bottled 12/3/04 and drank 7/14/10.

The beer pours a brown color with a white head. The aroma is toffee, oranges and leather. The flavor is toffee, chocolate, dirt and caramel. There is no alcohol presence. The beer is very mellow and shows no signs of oxidation. Medium mouthfeel and low carbonation.

Bottle pours clear, deep copper with a ruby tinge. Off white average head, not any remnant lacing. Floral hop aromas mixed well with rather inviting sweet toffee notes. Medium-light carbonation, medium to full chewy body with Initial sweet malt and caramel on the palate balanced well with the bitterness. Burnt toffee flavours nearing the finish with bitterness and residual sweetness lingering on the palate through for the medium finish. Very satisfying, although particularly simple, just done well.

Pours a hazed brown with a off white head. Aroma is alcohol, dark fruits, rasins, prunes, figs, brown sugar, yeasts spices caramel. Flavor is spices, intense slightly oxidized hop bitterness, caramel, dark fruits, candi sugar, malt, alcohol. Aggressive, but well crafted barleywine.

Eleven year old bottle shared with coworkers.  Pours a murky and hazy brown with a medium sized beige head.  Old caramel and plums.  A little bit of isopropyl. Lots of plums, caramel, and really thick malt.  Super sweet with even more caramel and plum.  Finishes long with a bit of dark malt, more caramel, sweet toffee and candy.  This held up amazingly well.
Very smooth for 11%.  Was a little sweeter than I expected, but nothing atypical for a barely wine.

An absolutely classic year round BW.  Have consumed this on many occasions in many vintages aged and non-aged and it always stands out as being quite exceptional.  Amazing for such a widely brewed beer now!  Big and hoppy, bold, yet complex and deep, fruit flavors coincide with malt and hop to finish off with a lingering joy on your palate.  Danksauce.

12 oz. bottle from Total Wine in Chesapeake, VA.  Brownish-orange pour with a thick off-white head.  Aromas of tangerines, maple syrup, cherry juice, and rose petals.  Bitter citrus and floral hop flavors upfront followed by a bold sweet malt finish.  Moderate alcohol warming (the bottle I had was listed at 11% ABV).  An incredible barley wine.

Oh good god.  Pours an inky black/brown.  Aroma is boozy, sweet but not overly so.  Flavor is like the worlds best dark candied fruit bread with a sugar crust on top.  Woof, so good.  Laces sticky down the glass.

12oz bottle, 2002 vintage, courtesy of dukefan.  Poured a cloudy amber body that was completely still.  Nice legs on the glass.  Aroma of honey, candi sugar, dark fruits, plums, raisins and a moderate level of alcohol.  Flavor was candi sugar, figs, dates and light alcohol.  Medium body and carbonation.  Very, very smooth.  Great aging on this bottle.  Thanks again Tim!!

Sorry but  meh...

Pours a hazy orangish amber, red tint? nice head.
Not so lacy,  head dissipates.

Aroma..    not much there...

Kinda boozy tasting...   some hops, but  ?
maybe a different kind?   Some fruit   prunes?

not a good after taste..

Hops gone....

Maybe an old bottle,  [NO DATE!]
but Barely-wines usually age OK...

Hate to compare to Big Foot, but...
this was pretty expensive,  shipped across the state,  and well a 6 pack of Big foot,  9 bucks..

Ill not have this again,     unless....

12oz bottle 2007 vintage? (BB 2012 dated)
poured  hazy brown with a big beige head.   toffe aroma with some vanilla  and alcohol. flavor is sweet and smooth with some light biterness in the finish. full bodied with a slighly sticky finish. sumprising smooth and drinkable for such a big beer. very tasty.

2005 Vintage
2/07/2010:  Victory Old Horizontal Barleywine Style Ale...  Aroma:  Lovely caramel and toffee, brown sugar, ample hops that make their presence known and set expecations, but dont dominate; smells a lot like sugary pineapple upside down cake!  Appearance:  Golden-orange color with a deep ivory-colored head that receeds to leave a percolating crown; semi-opaque liquid.  Flavor:  Rich, somewhat sweet toffee that melts in your mouth followed up with a fairly substantial hop flavor (aged vague citrus peel, earthy, subdued floral, aged dried fruit like golden raisin and alcohol-soaked apricots) and moderate bitterness as well as a pleasing amount of warming alcohol (brandy-like).  Palate:  Milky texture but silky smooth going down.  Overall:  In a word, excellent (for an American-style barleywine)!  I like the sweet, sticky maltiness as well as the peppery hop bite that attacks in the finish; this beer has held up wonderfully!
12 fl. oz. bottle ( Alc. 11% Vol. / Bottled Feb 04 05 ).  Rating #1308 for this beer.

12oz bottle in a snifter.  Pours ruby brown with a thick, lasting beige head.  Aroma of floral hops and toast.  Flavors of dark fruits with hints of vanilla.  Aftertaste strong on hops.  Alcohol very well masked in the rich texture and full body.  This beer is incredible.

On tap at the sprawling Victory Brewpub.  I can see why it is called Old Horizontal.  At 10.5% ABV, and with such a nice flavor, it would be very easy to throw back a bunch of these, and end up that way.  Dark amber pour.  A very tasty, hoppy barleywine, with a pleasant aftertaste.  Sweet fruit, dates, a little cocoa, and nice tingle on the palate.  The best thing I sampled that night - very impressive, and it showed just how good Victory can be.

12oz bottle from Archer Liquors.  Pours a hazy reddish-brown (ruby in the light) with a two-finger pillow of cream-colored head that lasts forever.  Aroma is powerful and pleasing, with loads of spicy malt goodness and caramel undertones.

Flavor is suprisingly hoppy up front, mixing through complexities of fresh earth, cigar wrapper, and caramel sweetness.  Finish quickly bites with booze and dries up in a flash.

Although Im not a fan of barleywines, I can definitely appreciate what Old Horizontal brings to the table.
Copper color, cloudy with an orange and brown head. Deep flavor of fruit and malt, strong and warming. Great to sip in the evening and help you finish off the day. Recommended.

Pours dark brown with a decent red tint, large foamy beige colored head (three fingers wide in a snifter), settles much smaller but still nice. A lot of carbonation and sediment. Aroma of light fruits (grapes, plums, raisins) and hoppiness thrown in. Taste is a bit strong on the alcohol at first but it warms you up... then it leads into a bitter fruit finish. Kinda boozy, but very good.
Very rich ale by Victory. Nose and taste are sprucy maple and molasses. Rated 3/16/03
Bottle. Great stuff. Very rich and malty, slightly sweet, and also big on the hops. One of the richest and best balanced barley wines I have tried. Excellent. Slightly chocolaty as well.

Pours out a burgundy dark brown .. medium foam .. medium roast and caramel with some sugar, sticky .. .eric wynalda, please die! .. . a really nice brew.. . Wyler, after all the goddamn shenanigans you pulled last season, you should be thanking God youre still in goddamn uniform, goddamnit!

Bottle and on Draft. Brown pour with a little bit of tan head. Overly sweet aroma with some fruity esters and alcohol notes. Would endorse putting this way for some age if bottled, flavors are loud and there is a bit of warming.
12 ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Pembroke Pines, FL for $2.49 Excellent.

Cloudy deep orange color with white lacing. Aroma is sweet caramel, sugar, and hops. flavor juicy, warm, and surprisingly bitter. Not as malty in the flavor as expected, but t is there in the palate. High viscosity. Bottle from Total Wine and More, Pembroke Pines.

On tap.  Nose is sweet and fruity, hops with stronger than usual malts for a young barley wine.  Some spice.  Smooth and slightly sweet with cherries, some caramel and bread from the malts and a nicely balanced hoppy bitterness.  The alcohol is definitely present, but its not too much.  Pretty nice barley wine.

Thanks to savvy1982 for the share, Pours a burnt orange with a small white head. The aroma is hoppy and malty. The flavor has soft fruit, honey, spice, herbs, cherries and a nice bitterness. Very good.

Murky orange-brown with chunks of dead yeast that eventually settle to the bottom.  A thin white head sits atop and creates some foamy lacing as it disappears.  Aroma of heavy alcohol, toffee, grains and brown sugar, very malty as most of the hops have faded on this two year old bottle.  Taste is very malty and sweet with alcohol, light fruit and hop undertones.

Bottle, thanks to bitbucket for the gift. Thats right, not a trade, a frickin Gift, because Bob is an amazing human being! Pours hazy caramel/amber, thin off-white head, poor/little lacing. Nose is quite profound, with massive caramel, fruit, candy, hops are still rank, despite me getting this from Bob in August, and he had it for God knows how long before... Flavor is rich and fat and surprisingly not as boozy as I had expected, nice fruit and caramel, some tobacco/earth notes as well, some spicinesss towards the finish. Exceptional!
2002 vintage.  Big, big flavors.  Yes, aged, but no signs of fatigue in the beer.  Raisiny, plummy quite solid.  I would say this is peaking, but may have more years in the bottle.

12 oz bottle (drink before nov 12, 2014). Pours dark orange with gigantic cream colored bubbly head, great lacing.  Pine, honey and tea aroma. Great sweet caramel and a huge bitter  great hop flavor. Touch of treacle on the finish but a long bitter fruity hop finish.  Great carb, full bodied with a slight boozy warmth. Would love to see this with some age.

12oz bottle, best by october 2013, so Im assuming its a year and five months in the bottle at this point.   Plays the barley wine part well in appearance with a deep amber to red and brown hue, capped by a small beige head.   The aroma has richly sweet malt, caramel, brown sugar, fruity alcohol, orange marmalade on toast, and actually has some fruity and piney hops in there after all this time.   The flavor immediately shows some mellowing of the considerable bitterness that this stuff has fresh.   You can tell that there was a lot of alpha acid in this fresh, but a large portion of it has dropped off,   Richly malty with lots of toasty grain, and an ample sweetness, though not cloyingly sweet.   What bitterness is left still balances the big malt sweetness well.   There is a touch of apricot fruitiness and warming alcohol as well.   Full bodied with a clean and smooth feel.   Creamy carbonation.   This seems like a good age for this beer, as the balance between the hop bitterness and malt is pretty good right now.   Still some fresh hop character remaining though, which adds some nuance.   I can see this going quite a bit longer, but this is a very good for style American barley wine right now.

Bottle.A deep amber color pour with a small offwhite head , medium carbonation . Aroma of caramel , brown shugar citrus and piny hops . Flavor is much the same , brown shugar ,rasins,figs,caramel , a hint of maple sweetness , nice level of bitterness lots of piny and spicy hops . Full body , creamy mouthfeel , lots of sticky lacing left behind , long slightly alcoholic finish. A very good strait forward hoppy BW quite drinkable and good.

07 and 08 bottles after the Gratitude release.  Both look chestnut brown in the glass but are red when held to the light.  07 really malty, boozy.  Some bitter hops, just dominated by strong malt and fruits like dates and rasins.  08 was great, way better than 07.  Malt a bit more subdued, with a perfect balance between malt sugars, dark fruit notes, and some bittering hops.  08 works perfectly at this age.  Rating is a combination of the two bottles.
golden brown with a huge thick and frothy head.  Nice alcohol bite and rich dark caramel maltiness.  Hops are just right.

Bottle.  Pored a deep amber with an orange hue and a small tan head.  Nose is slightly bready with stron malt and big hop notes also a good amount of alcohol.  Mostly full bodied with a smooth mouth feel an soft carbonation.  Lots of alcohol and bitter hops up front, mid way I got much more dark fruit and malt, finished with more hops bitterness and warming alcohol.

Served in a goblet this beer is glowing ruby red in the dim of the bar. Smells of cherries and sugarcane with big malt character. I let it sit for a while to warm up before sipping. Fruits, candied sugar, and raisons first appear. Medium hop bitterness. After a while strong alcohol subdues some of these flavors from coming out fully. Really luscious texture, full and rich. A warming, delicate sipper great for enlightening conversation.

2007 bottle. Pours a thick copper-brown color with an off-white head that disappears quickly.  Powerful nose!  Hops nose from a distance.  A closer inspection reveals hops, caramel, and dark fruit.  Sweet flavor of caramel malts, plums, apple, and a touch of hops.  Very nice beer for a cold night.

Slightly hazy amber, with moderate bubbly head.  Sweet on the nose.  Alcohol is very evident from the start, also sweet, with mellow flavored hops.  Finish has a slightly unpleasant bitterness of bioled vegetables.  I liked the beer, but I was not too excited about it.  My experience definitely doesnt reflect the other reviews or ratings.  I drank this beer fresh, I would like to try it again after it sat for a while and some of the edgier bitterness mellowed out.  I think this beer has potential to be a lot better.
Not a particularly good barley wine.  A lot of sediment in the bottle, body is too light, and the aftertaste dissipates quickly.

Im not usually a huge barleywine fan but heard great things about this one. Really amazing aroma. Great mix of fruits, caramel, brown sugar. The flavor was good, but after the initial smell of the beer I expected a much more powerful flavor. Ill definitely drink it again, just not quite what i was expecting.

2009.  11% ABV.  Pours dark copper-red with a medium tan head, with a heavy aroma of sweet malt, toffee, and some mild, but crisp hops.  Sweet caramel and brown sugar flavor with a slightly bitter finish and lingering alcohol warmth.  For all of its sweetness and detectable alcohol, this is a bit light-bodied and effervescent - at least for a sweet barleywine.  The touch of bitter bite is nice.  Obviously young, and it would be well worth seeing how this tastes down the road.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours an amber-brown color with a fluffy off white head.  Aroma of grass, sugar, dark fruit, citrus, caramel, toffee, bread, and spices.  Taste is plum, grass, and other floral notes, along with some grapefruit.  Pretty sweet up front but is followed nicely by a hop bitterness that carries it the rest of the way through.  The alcohol is well hidden and kind of sneaks up on you as you finish it.  Really good beer.

Pours dark ruby with no head.  Aroma is sweet, dark fruit with a candy-like quality, yeast and very mild hops.  Vry complex flavor.  Lots of alcohol in the nose.  Opens up to some floral notes and a rougher hop character.  Green apple shines through later on.  You can feel a high abv but I wouldnt have guessed 11%.  Finishes lush and round but bitter.  Wow.

Thanks to rgtravers for this one! Ive been waiting for a while to try this classic. It pours bright amber red with an orangy foamy head. The aroma is strong with solvents, caramel, apple, plums, and grains. The flavor is very strong, alcoholic, and hoppy with brown sugar, peach, apple , plum, pears, caramel, toffee,  and grains. Very fruity and bitter yet well balanced. Just very potent and a bit spicy. Great complexity that will probably improve with age.

2008 Bottle - Pours amber with a small beige head...aroma is fruity and thick, brown sugar, caramel apple...flavour is a bit thinner, grainy, bitter burnt sugar, cherry, hop bitters and caramel...floral hops and sticky brown sugar...tasty...

Bottle dated 12/2005 received from Todd1. The color is a tawny red with almost no head, only a couple bubbles running around the rim of the glass. It smells like alcoholic candy and makes me think uh, oh this is gonna be good. The mouth-feel is slightly effervescent. I am not sure what I am tasting but it is really good. I am going to savor this one and sip it slow. I really hope Colorado gets this beer since we get all the other Victory beers. This would definitely be worth laying down a case for several years. A truly outstanding barleywine.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-07-2007 16:16:51
Too sweet - but tast. Like a darker, more caramelly iipa. Tastes like brown sugar super malt. Deep in there, something weird, though - vegetabley funkiness.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2010 Pours a copper-red haze with not much life.  Thick head that breaks down to a medium head.  Much lacing.  Aroma of fruit and caramel, bit of pine.  What a taste.  A creamy mouthfeel, medium to full bodied.  A sweeter beer, but well balanced with the bitter finish.  This beer has more of an IPA feel to it than other barleywines Ive had.  Really good beer.
bottle thanks to cavie.  ruby/copper pour with a cream head.  nose is hops, slight fruits and caramel.  nice thickness with a great piney hop flavor tagged with dried fruits and caramel.

Pours a light cranberry orange colour with a bubbly, off-white lingering head that slowly recedes into a soft halo around the rim of my glass (12oz. bottle): Aroma of candied fruits (Jolly Ranchers), grapefruit, and resinous hops. Flavors are robust and malty. Crystal malts, marachino (sp?) cherry, and a kick of spice. Fair alcohol presence coupled with a back of the throat warming sensation. Drinkability: Sweet malted and strong. Rebuy: Yes. #270 on 05022010, DG.
Bottle from Cavie.  Smell has lots of brown sugar, dark fruit,  and roasted malts.  Taste is brown sugar, hops, caramel, and hops.

Bottle courtesy of RCL. So I rated this one twice in the same night without realizing it, and wrote down the exact same numbers both times, so thats pretty cool.  The first time all I wrote was, "kick my fuckin SSS." The second time I actually rated it. Hazy reddish pour with a ton of headyness in the glass. Flavorful aroma with a rockin taste.  The last sentence is awesome, "Slightly sweet flavorful sweetfukswwt sewer flVkr fukkk as dl ke."          Apparently I liked it. :)

( 12oz bottle thanks to cavie) Pours clear deep rusty orange with nice creamy head and great lacing. Nose of chlorine, citrus hops. Taste of cream, light alcohol heat, fruits and bitter citrus oils. This beer will probably be fantastic with some age, but honestly the hops dominated this one. I think the one we had was 2-3 months old, but Id love to try this at a year.

Bottle.  Pours hazy, deep ruby and copper, with a very thin tan head that dissipates quickly.  Aromas of sweet citrus and resinous pine hops, plums, figs, brown sugar, English malt, and alcohol (and sour fruit as it warms).  Taste is bitter hops, sweet brown sugar and dried fruit, with a sweet alcohol and slightly bitter hop finish.  The aftertaste is malty, sweet,  and tangy.  Palate is rich, crisp, thick, oily, and warming; very pleasing.  The 11% is dangerously well hidden.  This is very good, and grows on me with each sip.  Highly recommend.

Pours deep burt-amber/brown with a beige head. Smells of fruity, piney, resinous hops and caramel, candied fruit malt with light citric character. Flavor is rich and malty red fruits and candy, hints of bitter citrus and flowers with a warming finish. Body is viscous with alcohol that gradually accumulates. Skillfully crafted and well crafted. Great price points and character. A must-buy.
dark amber with a beige head & thick lace. bold, bitter citrus nose that develops into a subtle mix of grass. definitely enjoyed.

What an assault on the taste buds!  Complex flavours of sweet malt and resious hops.  The taste scale is genuinely balanced at about fifty/fifty.  Beautiful nose of pine, toffee, and booze.  This is one dry brew that has my face flushed after just a few sips.  As I roll this around in my mouth, each zone of my tastebuds are treated to a different sensation.  Props to Brian at Truevine for acquiring this fantastic elixir!

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2011 Along with  Olde Curmudgeon, this is simply one of my favorite barleywines. Lots of citric and dark fruit complexity, along with a definite spicy character, and a luscious, almost syrupy body. There are plenty of piny hops interwoven skilfully into this nectar, and they dry it out just enough in the finish for near-perfection. I loved it ten years ago, and I adore it even more today.
This is the best Barleywine style Ale Ive tasted.  I havent rated them all on RB but I had to give this its props!  IF you havent, you have to!!!!!!!!

12 oz. bottle poured into a snifter. Pours a clear amber-copper with an average off-white head that dissipates quickly but holds a nice thin cover. Fair lacing.  Great floral hop aroma with a malty sweetness, and faint alcohol. Flavor is a balance of sweet maltiness, caramel, dark fruits, and a piny hop bitterness. Very subtle warming alcohol. Hints of pepper. Full  bodied. Really nice.

Bottle. Courtesy of HogtownHarry (thanks once more). Nice reddish-amber pour with a thin white head. Syrupy hop aroma, lots of cookie dough sweetness here. Taste is pretty hot, lots of caramelized malts here with good hop bitterness, good complexity. Palate is nice and full, quite enjoyable.

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2010 Tons of  hops, honey, biscuity yeast, light fruits, and sugar in the nose. Similar taste with a nice balance between the sweet malty barley and the citrusy, piney hops. The pour was murky brown with a red hue in it. Small amount of off white head and minimal lacing. This is a really great, really cheap barley wine. Hard to find though, at least in Seattle. Tends to sell quickly. Thanks Victory!

Bottle.  Pours a hazy deep brown with a ton of sediment on the bottom.  Smells of honey.  Some subtle fruit in the taste, but mostly just a strong honey sweetness.  I think its this years batch, and its a little too hot still....wish I wouldve given it more time.
bottle courtesy of JRedmond.    Tons of hop, honey, biscuit and graham.   Awesome balance... great brew.

I thought that the 10.5%ABV wouldnt be too much to handle, but for this one, at least to me, it is pretty damn strong. Aroma has notes of fruity,barley, and alcohol. Sits very heavy on the tongue. Sort of overpowering really, but still a good sipping beer.

(bottle). Ruby color with light cloudiness. Large off white head. Sweet bread and floral hop aroma. Moderate sweet flavor with light pine hop and bitterness. Avg duration. Light bitter, light alcohol finish. Slick texture. Soft carbonation. Spare lacing.

where not quite a bigfoot, this barleywine is a great one.  pours dark amber with think off-white head.  a heavy beer that you nearly chew through.  taste is raisen and bread dough, perhaps a bit of banana.
Another great beer from Victory. This style is hit/miss with me. This one is very tasty. Nice balance and very little of the abv comes through.

From bottle.  Pours dark mahogany with off-white head. Aromas of malt, molasses and earthy hops. Alcoholic bite mixed with caramel, dark fruit and a dry hoppy finish. Medium-full body and carbonation.  Will improve even more with age.

Draft at Victory. Poured dark amber in color with a small off white head that left little lacing on the glass. Aroma of sweet caramel, toffee, light hop aroma. Tastes of caramel malt, toffee, peppery, light fruity, pine, bread, and a mild alcohol warming in the finish. A very solid barleywine.

A: Pours a nice ruby red hue with moderate carbonation. The head rises and falls and leaves behind no lacing.

S: Big pungent aromas. Tons of citrus, some pine, some fresh sweet fruit and a bit of sugary spiciness.

T: I taste some apricot, grapefruit, caramel, vanilla, & pepper. It is both bitter and sweet in such a wonderful way. The hops are there as is the malt. What a wonderfully crafted complex brew. It is a big brew with alcohol to burn. It is to be drunk in the winter, but man did I enjoy this baby on an early October evening.

M: Full bodied brew that is thick and chewy.

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a stemmed glass.

The color is a cloudy orange color with about three fingers of foamy off white head, some thick lacing.

The smell is bit grassy hop flavor. Some dark fruit flavor with some banana and grape flavor.

The taste is is a bit hoppy like an IPA but it does have some bite. It is warming with some fruit flavors coming across in the background. Some malt comes across late but not very much.

The feel of this beer is medium but strong, with 11% ABV this beer has a kick and does show it on the way down. It has a warming, medium feel but does not give off too much alcohol burning.

12oz bottle best before Nov 6, 2014.  11% ABV.  Pours reddish brown with a big light tan head that maintains a small cap.  A lot of head for a barleywine.  Minimal lacing.  Aroma is rather hoppy, earthy, a lot of malt, and sometimes a bit funky.  Flavor is sweet caramel malts up front, citrus and rensinous hops.  Alcohol is well hidden considering the %.  Mouthfeel is a little sticky but not too bad for the style.  Pretty damned good.  Like it better than the Third Coast Old Ale I had earlier tonight.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2010 (br-btl bk-lbl, 11%)

lct-br, thin-tan-head, no-lace, full-body, ^co2.

aroma: dark-malt cascade-hop.

flavor: caramel T1, hop-bitter smooth-warm-alchl T2, citrus-hop-bitter T3.

the alchl and hop-bitterness do not get overpowering but they limit enjoyment to small quantities.
Poured an amber/red in color. Little in the way of head. Aroma of candied fruits. Taste is pear and candied pineapple. Not overly sweet though. Alcohol is apparent but well-hidden. Great winter brew.
Bottle. Dark amber colour, slightly cloudly, with white head. Mind blowing nose of toffee and spice. Lots of complexity, caramel malts, dark fruit, nuts and dark chocolate, with smooth finish.

Bottle. Poured a rich cloudy amber. Nose was hoppy andalty with some spice notes. Real nice depth of flavor. Very drinkable but fullll bodied. Nice hop notes but well balanced with a ton of malt and nice spice notes. Really good. Another good one from victory.

12oz bottle. enjoy by date of Dec29, 2011. Pours a syrupy dark amber, small lasting head and tons of floaties. Aroma of pine hops, caramel. Sweet sweet initial taste, very syrupy, heavy pine hop finish. Hint bread/yeast. Would never know this was 10.5%, the alcohol is far in the background.
Pours deep copper. Nose is big american hops, citrus, grapefruit, dark fruits, booze and sweet caramel. Flavor is bold fruit esters, citrus, pine all balanced nicely by big caramel and toffee. Nice!

a deep reddish brown beer with a strong malty aroma, a full mouth feel with a nice bitter character on a strong malt backbone.
excellent desert beer to serve with berry tarts, or chocolates.
Bottle. Pours mahogany with a big head and lots of lacing. Tastes like pinecone, caramel, roasted malts. Probs will be better after being aged for 6 months.

Hazy brown pour with a red tint.  Opaque with lots of of bubbles and a thin white head.  Chocolaty malt aroma.  Significant grain and bread as well.  Nice sweetness with honey and caramel malt.  Nutty and port like.  Hints of chocolate.   Goes down easy.
deep caramel and flavors of pine needles, pineapple and roasted malts. the hops bring a special ordeal to this beer. this is a great one to have.

The aroma is hoppy with pineapple, grain husks, caramel, and yeast. The appearance is deep amber with a large head. The flavor is like the aroma with an emphasis on hops but there is a sweet balance. The palate is typical for the style but could use a bit more substance. Overall this is a good beer but just seems less than impressive.

pours out light maroon with a tall beige head that was a sight to look at. the body is a beautiful maroon amber with an ever so light amount of bubbles rising up from the center of the glass.  the aromas are spicy and fruity with a really nice malty backbone.  i wish i had a candle that smells like this beer.  there is some alcohol in the nose also, but it is really faint.  it is pretty much full bodied with a really nice sweet bitterness to it.  had notes of red onion, asparagus, and dark fruits.  nicely balanced and not one flavor killing another flavor, its a symphany in my mouth and i taste every instrument playing.  it has delicate lacing on the edges but they fade right back into the body. the aftertaste is also a another great taste.  it is not in your face and leaves just the right amount of umph in your palate.  cant wait for the next winter to enjoy this bad boy.

2008 bottle. Pours cloudy reddish brown color with beige head. Aromas of sweet malts and some fruitiness .  Carmel malt sweet flavor with some dark fruits and molasses. Medium to full body with mild carbonation and a syrupy mouthfeel. Very good.

It is a complete travesty that I have not rated this beer before. This was the first barleywine I ever tried years ago before I started rating beer. I have had the beer many time since then and must have been convinced that I had already rated it. This is still the barleywine I compare all others to. Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a hazy red-brown color with a huge creamy red-orange had that lingered. The aroma was sweet and had a strong fruity hop presence and undertones of candied ginger and caramel. The flavor was sweet and bitter with toasted caramel, fruity hops, light pine, nut, cocoa and rum.  A touch harsh. The finish is long with fruit, pine and caramel lingering. Full bodied. Excellent - an American classic.

ruby red pour with quickly reducing head. aroma is mostly malt based with strong toffee notes. flavor is more well balanced with big, puckering pine finish. balance is evident behind giant syrupy burnt caramel notes throughout. mouthfeel is just a touch slow and seeping. big alcohol and bitterness end.

Pours somewhat cloudy orange with a thick beige head. Aroma is grapefruit, pine, honey, tangerine and earthy malt. Taste is a great balance of sweet thick malt and brutal bitterness. Medium thick body with smooth carbonation. Quite a bitter finish.

2007 version. Very nice, balanced aroma.  Dark amber color with copper tapering off at the bottom.  Nice appearance.  Thick and oily mouthfeel  Dark fruit and black cherry taste.  Perhaps my favorite barley wine that I have tasted but Im not a fan of barley wines.

An incredible example of a barleywine. Spot on for style with all the expected aromas and flavors, including bubblegum, raisin, caramel, and more. Packs a punch with little discernible alcohol burn, and nicely warming on a chilly night. I can only find fault in the palate which seems to me a little thinner than other barley wines Ive had. And its expensive--17 bucks at my store. But well worth it.

mahogany in hue, similar to that of a doppelbock, but a thicker head.  roasted molases, subtle salinity, subtle yeast, and maple syrup nail the aromas.  lighter than expected on the nose.  wow what a body!  contrary to the nose, the flavor still hits the bwine style, just in a lighter manner.  more dominant madeira notes hit the palate, almost mirroring a simple tawny port with excess carbonation.  toffee, heat, and maple sap shine through the fullest.  I still stand by the aroma leading to a lighter style (less robust than most bwines).  Nonetheless, quite a tasty pour.  *Note* - As the brew warms, the mellowness is achieved, and the anise begins to dominate.  cellar temp may be a bit too chilly here.

Bottled. red with a yellow/orange head. aroma is sweet hoppy with notes of citrus and booze.  true hopheads dream beer to end a night with. Total night cap brew. flavor is sweet hoppy, caramel malt, and  citrus orange. Stinging big hop palate. I love it!

Awesome freaking orange red color. Very unique and pretty. Sour fruit and floral hop nose. Going well so far.     Upon tasting: Long lasting flavors. So complex yet elegantly balanced. "Its perfect" says Jabo. It would be hard to disagree with him. Its truly a stunning beer. Just try it. If youre reading this, youve got to try this beer. Quite an experience trying it for the first time. All tasters in our room impressed.
Pours a lasting ring of tan head with a clear, copper-amber body.  Aromas of bubblegum, anise, citrus, and pine hops.  Flavors of bubblegum, mint, pine, citrus, honey.  Dry, bitter, sticky finish.

Bouteille de 12 oz. Arômes de sucre dorge, de fruits rouges et de houblon fruité. Très belle robe rousse foncée, effervescence faible et légère mousse. Bien maltée, le sucre dorge montre une belle complexité. On remarque également des notes de whisky et de fruits rouges. Finale alcoolisée et relativement amère.
19th August 2008. Good aggressive barley and a good hop profile, smooth easy drinking Barleywine but not up there with the best.

ENJOY BY: NOV 29 12

Dark golden brown liquid with ruby highlights. Small creamy tan colored head of foam. Okay retention and okay lacing.

Big malty nose. Smells like buttered caramel. A little bit of brown sugar and vanilla. Slight hint of candied apricots. Very slight hint of earthy hops.

Nice caramel malts are out front. Hints of buttered bread with peach preserves. Toffee. Slight kiss of hops. Not prominent, though. Slight earthy spiciness.

Fairly light bodied for a barleywine style, I think. But, maybee thats just me. It is smooth and creamy, though, and thats a plus.

This one is very drinkable, IMO. Grab a case and come on by. Lets see how many we can drink.

#20. Pours a very dark, opaque amber with a small beige head, more than youd expect for this strong a beer. Smells of cinnamon, ginger, lemons, and that pre-rain smell. This is nice and hoppy, my type of beer. Offset well by sweet flavors of caramel, and also carries nice spiciness--like pumpkin pie--and citrus, very little alcohol taste. Finishes clean with just a touch of bitterness. Quite simply, awesome.

12 oz. bottle. Colour... copper-amber with no head. Nose... pretty hoppy but the malt is there too. Palate... burst of carbonation and hops, light brown sugar, golden raisins, moderate booze, dark corn sirup, toffee and a creamy mouth feel. Nice! Another one of those, "Gee! Why didnt I try this sooner!", beers.

12oz bottle, a year old. Pours a ruddy amber with a creamy tan head. Nose of rich caramel, some fruit, a little booze, brown sugar. Flavor is rich malt, sweet, brown sugar, some figs, a solid bitterness and some strong alcohol towards the finish. Creamy, lush carb with med-heavy mouthfeel. A sipper for sure.

Oh boy what a good beer.  Poured with a thin tan head and a fruity/citrus/delicious aroma and had a matching taste.  Creamy, tasty, and delicious.  Hides the high alcohol content well.  Great flavor, great beer.

Thanks to Strykzone for this superb beer.  From a 12 oz bottle it poured a deep garnet color with a moderate light tan head and good lacing rings. The nose is caramel malts with ripe fruit, citrus, and alcohol.   Very rich and creamy mouthfeel and a medium to heavy body.  Lots of tantalizing flavors with ripe fruit and moving to a nice bitter citrus finish. A simply sublime American Barley Wine.

Bottle pours amber brown with a thin white head.  Aroma is heavy on malts, caramel, raisin, and cherry.  Taste is caramel sweetness initially but finishes with a nice floral hop bitterness and a roasted malt flavor.  Body is medium-heavy.  Flavors are balanced incredibly well,   Well done!

Draft. 5 oz flight. Pours amber with a thin, tan head. Aroma of sweet fruits, cherries, malts, barley, and hops. Medium bodied with a smooth, delicious mouthfeel. Crisp, dry finish. Excellent barley wine. Recommended.

Garnet pour with a smallish white head. Aroma is outstanding even before going in for the first sniff. Lots of fruity esters, port, caramel, orange peel, and alcohol. Hop character is above average for the style. Flavor is luscious- copious caramel, toffee, and fruity sweetness, accompanied by some vinous quality and a very subtle roasted barley note. Again, hop character is high, yielding citrus and nectar. Palate is thick, silky, velvety, and rich. A slight effervescent quality sits on the tongue seemingly forever, eventually retreating and leaving behind a slightly warming boozy slippery smacking mouthfeel. Balance of flavors is incredible, every facet is covered amazingly.

500th rating, been looking forward to this brew for a while now. Dark garnet pour with a thin white veil of a head. Aroma holds raisin, caramel, wheat, fruity esters, dark vinous notes, and a bit of citrus. 10.5% ABV is certainly apparent on the nose; I expect it to be prevalent in the flavor as well. Flavor is delicious; starts with caramel sweetness with supplemental notes of raisin, wine, nectar fruit, and even a bit of roast. The second half of the flavor has a really nice hop character with a dry, bitter citrus note, followed with a bit of grain and definite booze at the finish. Complex flavor overall, a really solid American barley wine on that front. Palate is quite full and sticky, and the alcohol burn is subtle and welcomed. A really nice brew on the whole.

Bottle served in a snifter. A slight haze in the auburn-brown body. Minimal head. Sweet aroma sweet, caramel, over-ripe banana, and raisins. Creamy mouthfeel amonst little carbonation. Substantial body (medium-full) followed by plenty of hops. The finish, which is not real heavy, is a little bitter and lengthy.

Dark cherry color, mahogany red with hints of brown. Short lasting head. Glassy and shiny, but also thick and murky.

The smell is heavy sweet red wine. Some sweet (but grainy) barley too. Hints of liqueur, but not sharp or unpleasant.

Taste is heavy sweet barleywine flavor (heavy on the "wine" part). Has the tart, sour pungence of a sweet red wine. Also the grainy barley base. Strong! But well-balanced. Has some hard liquor.

Feels thick and chewy. Alcohol bite on the way down, a real burn. Its a strong beer, but limited in that its heavy and loaded with alcohol taste (11%).

Pours a deep murky dark amber with a frothy light tan head. Big malty aromas of raisin, caramel, some dark fruits, light pine hops, and a little candy. The flavors start with some raisin, dark fruits, and caramel, then some hops take over and an alcoholic bit! Sweet, bitter, and slightly rich. A warming beer from head to toe. This one will keep you warm in the winter :)

12oz bottle. Pours deep amber, nice off white head that lingers. Lacing is moderate. Aroma is fruity and sweet. Tastes of nice ripe fruit and hops. Alcohol taste is present as the brew warms, but doesnt take away from the enjoyment. A great representation of the genre.

12oz bottle in Seattle.  Definitely in the American style with the hops appearing in the aroma and flavour, but not overpowering.  Sweet caramel and a touch of bourbon also there.  Really didnt notice the 10+ ABV.

Bottle thanks to nqualls.  Dated Nov 29 12.  Dark brown-orange, some floaties, with a thin beige head.  Aroma is prunes, brown sugar, dark fruits, light alcohol heat, raisins.  Taste is more brown sugar, raisins, rum, alcohol warmth

A ruby/maple red pour. Tastes of roasted malt, on the darker side with a more caramel/chocolate end thats not strong but isnt overpowered by the alcohol that was present more towards the end of the drink. A favorite of mine in the barley wine category.

I tend to like the Old Ho with about 2 years on it. Mellows enough for me and is great. Aroma has some hops, pine, caramel and nice sweetness. Flavor if pretty big. Pine and citrus hops, caramel and molasses and nice body.

Light brown with Light red woody highlights.  Aroma is Caramel, citrus, grapefruit hop aroma, bit of candy sweetness.  a bit of fruitiness and some boozy wood.  Flavor is hot all the way through, woody sweet caramel flavors, sugary sweet but nice hop ballance and some great fruit.  A delightful sipper.

Pours a delicious light brown.  Aroma is good, but I cant quite place what the smell is other than hops.  Taste is mostly of lightly toasted malt and hops, but not real strong.  Alcohol is there, but not overpowering even though it is 11%.  Very good, one of my favorite barleywines.
Ruby red/dark amber pour with a beige head. Aroma is nice-caramel malt, sweet sugary aroma, fruity. Nice malt taste, sweetness, fruity. A little heat/alcohol at the end. Nice lacing on the glass.

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy reddish copper with a medium sized frothy tan head.  Aroma is  caramel, pine, citrus, and some alcohol and its all sugary.  Flavor has some caramel, honey, citrus, some fruity hints, and a medium bitterness that creates a very nice balance.  Full bodied with a generous amount of carbonation.

From a bottle thats about 8mo old.  Poured into a snifter with about an inch of thick white head.  Head disappeared quickly and left no lacing.  Smells of alcohol and fruit.  Mostly dark fruit like plums and apricots.  Taste is slightly biting hops and alcohol with more dark fruit underneath.  Alcohol isnt by any means overpowering and adds a lot to the flavor.  My mouth and lips feel sticky when drinking due to the sugar and all around richness of this beer.  Very nice barleywine.  The more I drink the more flavors come out and the more I enjoy it.

(Bottle, Monks Café, Wallingatan, Stockholm) Reddish amber colour with frothy, beige head. Malty, fruity nose with notes of red berries, dried fruit and caramel. Vinous and sweet. Malty, fruity taste with caramel, dried fruit, blood orange, orange peel and a generous citrussy bitterness in the finish. Full body, sweet and warming. Very nice beer.

Poured copper and hazy with big tan head from a very vigorous pour aromas of malts,hops, and pine, taste is pine hops up front with a sweet malt backbone I will be cellaring the rest and hope the hop flavors move well into the back ground

Bottle at Monks café, Wallingatan, Stockholm. Pours out in a deep reddish amber colour with a small bubbly off-white head. Rich and really potent aroma of figs, plue plums, resin, dried apricots, flowers, brandy and peppery alcohol. Full-bodied with notes of flowers, blue plums, figs, oranges, black currant, grapefruit and alcohol. Long warming finish of sweet blue grapes, blue plums, raisins, garpefruit, mild resin and alcohol. Heck, quite a masterpiece, this!

Pours a dark copper/amber color with one finger, yellowish-beige foam head that lasts throughout, leaving chunky lacing all over the glass. Leather roasted malt aroma with a very nice citrus hop presence along with some lighter crisp fruit notes and sweet alcohol. Much hoppier than I expected(which was very pleasant) which compliments the leathery, roasted maltiness and sweet alcohol warmth very nicely.
Nice warmer, lots of malt, caramelize brown sugar, presentable hops with the necessary ABV for a Barley wine

Aroma is cardboard oxidation, sweet sugar, and faded hops.
Taste is earthy, piny hops, a bit of cardboard, caramel malt, and bitterness.
Yum. 2 year old Old Horizontal. Very solid.
Finish is subdued, but slightly bitter.

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2011 Barley wine très riche. Cuivrée-brune, elle offre des arômes de malt et dhoublon, ainsi que de fraises. Alcool au palais, avec une belle combinaison de malt-houblon en bouche. Finale de confiture aux fraises et dalcool avec une forte dose dhoublon. Bonne bière complexe et intéressante a boire. Gagne à se faire vieillir, ne serait-ce quune année.

12oz bottle into a snifter.  Aroma is metal, dust, and sweet. Flavor is huge sweet with a touch of alcohol and significant hoppage. Not bad, but I didnt think it was as good as some American barley wines.
