12oz bottle, smells sweet, tastes sweet and leaves a sweet residue on the lips very sweet, no taste of alcohol which is refreshing at 10.5% however i get no hop profile as other people have mentioned.. a darn decent barley wine.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2009 12 oz. Bottle from 2006, drank in 2006.  Pour is ruby amber with a bigger off white head then I would have expected for a Barley Wine, though it went away fairly quickly.  Aroma is malt, with some fruitiness.  I would say it is cranberries and raisins.  Taste has a bit of hop to it, and a nice big malt body.  Finish was a bit hot, I will be cellaring the remaining from the 6 pack.
This one I like a lot. aromas of prunes, raisins, dates and in the taste that seems to heighten ten fold moderately sweet. the after taste is of bitter alcohol.
Taste is an explosion of banana, bubble gum, and dried fruits (dates, hint of apple) shot through with crisp citrus hops.  Delicious.
Had on DLD.A.sweet and ruby colored beer with fruity overtones and hop finish to it and alcohol is strong but good.CHEERS!

too bad its not lovejoys old horizontal.  appearance is red as your moms cooter will be in forty minutes.  shes a demon in the sack.  surprising amount of head, a caseous brown mustard color.  so malty compared the barleywines ive had recently.  actually some bockish sweet malt.  lots of it.  some resiny hops.  nuts and honey.  actually some bockish flavors without being lagerish.  hard to describe that.  closest i can is comparing to the sweet fermented plum rinds you get in a dopplebock.  i may have let this warm up too much, but i still like it.  i liked it a lot the last two times i had it, too.  probably my favorite victory.  bottom of the glass now.  still kinda lagerish.  the alcohol is both helping the flavor and overpowering the beer.

Excellent, but perhaps a little young. Dark amber pour with a fruity malt nose and a dash of hops. More hops than I expected in the flavor department; still, nice, lightly spicy character and fairly well balanced for such a strong beer. Very nice.

Bottle, pours a clear ruby tinted dark amber with an ample yellowish tan head, minimal lacing.  Aroma of plum, dark fruits and caramel.  Not too strong on the nose, but subtle and interesting just the same.  Flavor is malty and pleasing, with a bit of hoppiness and slight astringency; some alcohol warmth.  A nice barleywine even young, and no doubt it ages well; recommended.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2007 Yet again, thanks to boboski.  I felt as if I needed to have my feet propped up in front of a roaring fire, whlst wearing my double billed tweed hat.  What a great barely wine.  I have grown tired of the hop bomb barleys.  Aroma is malty, fat and rich.  Flavor is warming and voluptuous.  Amazing bottle.
One of my favorite barley wines! Very good beer to sit and relax with. I wish i was able to get my hands on an older one. I bet it mellowed out wonderfully.
Rated this one late.  Recorded the numbers, but not much description.  Looks like I liked it a lot.

bottled dec 06. Aroma of oranges and grapefruit. nice two finger head that subsides to a thick lace. soft mouthfeel. deep amber color. Very nice, mellow malt flavor with a very nice alcohol warmth. Overall, a great, great barleywine. Perfect to savor at the end of the night. I bet this is amazing aged for a few years

UPDATED: APR 22, 2007 Bottled December 04. Malty aroma with hints of hops. Cloudy amber color with large pieces of sediment. Malty start with a slight hop bitterness finish. Strong alcohol burn. A little creamy palate.

Bottle.  Aroma of caramel malt, alcohol, and some dark fruit.  Initial flavor is of sweet malt, followed by some spice and alcohol, and finishes with grapefruit like bitterness.  A little too peppery for my taste.

Bottled Dec 29, 2004
Red-amber color, small off-white head. Bready, hoppy and slightly fruity aroma. Full-bodied, bready, hoppy. Alcohol punch and sweet fruits (+grapefruit) in the aftertaste (together with hops). Nicely balanced, bitter but "not so hard to drink" barley wine.

Bottled (bottled 29.12.2004, thanks heemer77!). Nutbrown colour with beige small head. Leaves lace. Aroma is toffee, caramel malts, some spices and a bit of alcohol. Flavour is spicy, fruity, slightly yeasty and some caramel malts. The alcohol is hidden oh-so-well, it just shows as a bit warming feeling while drinking. In the aftertaste the alcohol gives a nice sticking feeling on the tongue, while the flavour is flowery hops and some toffee. A very wellbalanced beer!

Thick off-white lacing head, reddish amber in colour.  Slightly malty and spicy scent with a hint of alcohol.  On first sip the alcohol will bite your tongue.  But the malts and sweet pear or grapefruit taste comes next.  Considering the alcohol content this beer is quite nice.

The aroma was malty and spicy with an alcohol presence. The beer was fruity with a strong malt character of dark caramel and rich malt. The fruity nature contained citrus and a nice spice. The beer poured into the glass hazy amber brown with a low off-white persistent head which lasted to lace the glass. The flavor was malty with a grapefruit citrusy flavor and a well balanced bittering to accompany the malt. The malt was bready, but not toasty with a candy characteristic. The finish was just dry with a lasting bready caramel and lightly spicy character coupled to citrus into the aftertaste and beyond. The body was full and nicely achieved. A really nice barleywine only showing the presence of alcohol in the aroma and in the warming that occurred post consumption. Well done! 12 ounce bottle. Bottled on Nov 18 03.
user_location: North of Raleigh, North Carolina, USA

text: nice red amber color, very very small head, nice lacing, and retention. aroma is lots of floral hops, and some really nice caramel and ripe fruit. flavor is very much hops, and caramel, very mellow, but strong at the same time. quite bitter in the end, alcohol is present, but not too much, very nice barley wine.

Bottle:  Ruby red color body with tan head.  Nice retention. First sniffs featured fresh apples, caramel, sugar cane, and some floral hops.  Very sweet and nice, a little light though.  In the mouth this is very dense.  Starts out balenced, bitter with a light caramel apple and gum like flavors.  Long bitter pine finish.  Spicy, pine hops and alcohol flavors really hit at the swallow, right after a pleasing milk-like acidity.  Entry becomes sweeter as the beer warms, developing grassy notes as well as increased fruity berry like qualities.  Very good cigar beer.

Wow, wow, wow. This is one seriously tasty barleywine. You know when you get one of those beers that you just want to savor and sip it forever? This is that beer. While it may not be the BEST barleywine Ive ever had, its right up there. Pours out a deep stained wood brown with reddish highlights and a smallish sized head. Aroma that hits you is just incredible. Caramel, pine, brown sugar, alcohol with an overal sweetness that delivers one of the things I love about sweet beers. Flavor is near perfectly hopped for a barleywine for my liking. Sweet with notes of brown sugar, toffee, light fruits and malts. Hoppy with pine coming out to play nicely. Overall, just really interesting, and really tasty. As I said, one of those beers that you just want to drink over and over. Count yourself lucky if you can get this beer whenever you want.

2005 bottle.  The last of a 9 barleywine tasting... so Im not sure if I can trust the rating, but I think it was the best of the night! 
Hazy brown with a very very thin smooth head.  The nose is big with sweet malt, negligible hops and alcohol.  The mouthfeel was big and creamy with an average carbonation.  Big sweet malt, alcohol, some caramel, much more malty than fruity.  Probably the fullest flavor in terms of malt of the evening.  Im glad Ive got a few vintages packed away.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2007 I am confused with this beer.  I had a case of it in February and it was delicious, nice balanced malt with lot of Hoppiness.
Then I bought a case in September of this year and I dont know if Im crazy or the aging process effected it alot, but the hops were at a minimum and it was just a very malty and average strong beer.
Earlier this year I rate it a 4.5, now I rate it 3.7.  Leaving us with my current ratng.

Cloudy amber hue, with a tan-colored head, leaving laces, sweet toasted malt nose, with a faint spicy, flowery hop citrusy accent, with some grassy, leafy accents, a mild candied fruity aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a sweet toasted, caramelized malt character, with a floral hop accent, when the beer is getting warmer an evident herbal lavender note emerges, with a hint of leafiness and grassiness, a bit fruity, leading towards a malty, alcoholic, grassy hop bitterness finish. Maybe because drunk too young,  the beer seems to hopped for the style.

Pours brown with a thin off white head.  Strong malt and alchohol aroma, with some fruit and citris in there as well.  Taste is about the same.  Thick sweet malt, alchohol and citris hops on the edge.  Well made but a little hot and a bit cloying for me.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2008 Color was orange-brown; smallish white head.  Aroma of citrus, dark fruit, malt, alcohol, some raisin, and hop peppering.  Good mouthfeel; alcohol well hidden.  Flavor was of caramel malt, brown sugar, raisin, some dark fruit and some pepper.  Nice hop presence.  Enjoyed this, but not nearly as much as 3Floyds Behemoth which i had quite recently.  (+.01 after having it at the Blind Tiger in January 2008).

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2007 Pours a pretty reddish hue with a small off white head. Aromas of Dark fruits and light citrus. Roasted malts, raisins, berries and light hops stand out at first. As the beer warms the alcohol is most apparent. This superb barley wine coats your mouth with a full, sweet, and very smooth finish.

I smell victory.  They make good beer.  Nice aroma, sweet and gooey.  Good lacing in the glass and good alcohol covering.  Dont realize the strength until you stand up afetr a few.  Nice touch of hops and I will have more some day for sure, if I can pull myself away from IPAs

Bottle aquired in a trade with jredmond.  Slightly cloudy red tinted deep amber colored pour.  Moderate frothy light tan head that laces the glass nicely.  Nose is sweet - some orange, candied fruit, a little bit peppery.  Mouthfeel is slick and lightly carbonated.  Nice sweet citrusy flavor with a slight hop bitterness in the end.  A very nice barley wine.

THOUGHTS: I finally tried it. I always think to look for it when its out of season. Very sweet aroma and flavor. Some metallic aftertaste and some alcohol in the aroma, but not bad for the ABV. It was kind of pleasantly warming. Very carbonated. A really good beer, but  Ive had better barley wines. Very malty with a slight bit of chocolate in the flavor.
TECHNICLE: Bottle. Poured  a medium red-brown with a small, white head that mostly diminished. There were also tiny, thinly spaced particles in the body. The finish flavor was bitter with an average duration. The body was medium to full and dry but sticky on the lips with very fizzy carbonation and a light alcoholic finish.

I dont what I love most about this offering from the Dukes of Downingtown. My favorite Victory beer up to this point was having Hop Devil from cask at the brewery. Old Horizontal has it beaten! The color is deep reddish brown. The aroma grabs your attention with its malted, perfumy, alcoholic character. The taste is wonderful, with its lingering bitterness. However, the bitterness is not overwhelming, and reminds me more of an English-style barley wine. The taste of alcohol is not really evident, but one can certainly feel it. Superb beer from a great brewery!

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2011 Opaque light brown body with lots of particles and a small tan head.  If I was to describe its taste in a crude way Id pancake with lots of brown sugar.  Not even caramel or toffee flavours, no, pure brown sugar.  Alcohol was really apparent to say the least.  Subtle leafy hops create a light tartness.  Not very complex.  Overall good but not excellent.  Bought the bottle summer 2006 and while Im not found of aging beers this one felt raw and way too young.  I bought an Old Horizontal bottle I got a Young Horizontal.  This is false advertising.  Do I smell lawsuit?
Mahogany colored ale with thick foam for a head. Aroma is undeniable sweet malt. Body is heavy and maintains a sweet sugary caramel flavor. Very nice.
UPDATED: MAY 19, 2007 Great pour, good head that leaves nice lacing, great amber color.  Good hoppy flavor, nice strong finish.

newer batch. smell and taste were of basically the same things....piney hops with a sweet malt. either alcohol was well hidden or im just getting used to the flavor of these big beers. nonetheless this ended up tasting a bit like a DIPA to me because the hops were so forward. ill be curious to see how this ages when the hops mellow a bit as i like my barleywines a bit more on the sweet side as opposed to hoppy.

12oz bottle, bottled November 2003.  Pours a hazy, orangish-brown appearance; light tan head with great lacing.  Chewy caramel, orange, and 
wet malts in the aroma.  Full mouthfeel, showing wet malts, caramel, tropical fruits, and citrus hops; well-carbonated (even after 3+ years), with light caramel from the oxidation; far more drinkable with some age behind it.  Viscous and satisfying.  Long, sugary and citrus hop finish.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2007 Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a snifter, deep ruby red with no head at all. The aroma was sweet and fruity. The first few swallows were sticky sweet with notes of dark fruits and pine hops with some alcohol bite. The finish was a slight bitterness that lingered. As it warmed, it mellowed with a more malty flavor.

Hops really dominate the aroma,but there is also a hint of dark fruits as well.Pours a deep copper with an off white head.Caramel malts,hops and alcohol make up the flavors.Medium to full mouthfeel with the alcohol coming thru in the finish.

2006 bottle.  A quite hoppy aroma, sweet, a lighter malt scent, and light citrus fruits.  Pours a  darm maroon color with a small short lived tan head that comes down to a soapy rim around the glass.  Nice hop texturesin the taste, alcohol is well hidden but you get some bite on the backend, malt is more distinctive in the taste.  Some what a mixture of plums, pine needles, grapefruit, and a slight coffee like taste.  Pretty decnt stuff.  I like the hoppy stuff so this Barley wine is distinctive and right up my all, but not like the other in the style.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2007 Vertical tasting of 01 - 05. Ratings are an average of the years.   

01: Carmel color and taste.  Rich toffe flavor and mildly sweet.  Excellent beer.

02: Nice toffee and sweet, but some tart fruit in there as well.  Just as good as the 01, maybe better.  These two vintages might be some of the best beer Ive ever tried.  Thank you milkmandan.

03: Hoppy, with less toffee than the previous.  Not as good as the older vintages.

04: Same as the 03 but more hoppy.

05: Massive hop increase with some currant flavor.  Not as good as the 04.  

The vertical started out strong, but sadly headed down a very steep hill.  Would have been a 4.8 if Id only had the first two vintages.

Not as strong an alcohol flavor as Id expect from a beer thats 11% (as the label says).
Fairly amber in color, and a nice, not-too-sweet maltyness.
The aftertaste has a slight roastyness to it that compliments the sweetness in the next sip.
Left a bit to be desired in the mouthfeel, but still excellent.

This barley wine has a strong hops aroma accented with grapefruit. The beer pours an amber brown with a thick orange color and orange tinted head of long duration.  A thick creamy flavor, good, complex, changes a bit in the mouth.  A bitter punch evens out with chocolaty sweet syrup flavors, some pine and grapefruit flavors and a light saltiness.  Creamy on the palate with a honeylike consistency.  Very good and warming.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2008 Egggggcellent. Very very complex beer here. Notes of grapefruit, nuts, cranberries, maple, and many more. The alcohol becomes more assertive when the beer warms. All malty for me, but mine was aged a year.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2009 2006 bottle.  Transparent dark amber / mahogany.  Pretty nice aroma of figs, sherry, and light fruits.  Flavor is sweet but with a hoppy finish, and the balance is perfect.  Rich, lush flavors that linger on the back of the tongue, mostly caramel, berries, burnt orange, and sherry.  Kind of like The Macallan scotch whiskey.  Mouthfeel could be better; it just seems too thin.  Nonetheless, a great beer, and one of the most reliable barleywines Ive had.

From a 12oz Bottle, 2006 Vintage.  Transparent, ruby amber colored pour with a healthy layer of fine bubbled cream head.  Fruity aroma of sherried strawberries and fresh pear flesh dance with some orange zest hops.  Some higher alcohols give it a bit of a varnishy, acetone-ish edge, but isnt dominant enough to get obnoxious.  Full bodied, thick mouthfeel, but not to the point of being syrupy.  Sweet caramel and toffee flavors start off first on the palate, followed closely by some golden toasted marshmellow.  A touch of fresh peaches and cream add some silky light fruity characters just before the hops begin to take over full time.  Some bitter high alpha hops round out the finish with a bold, yet balanced finish, leaving tastes of pithy white grapefruit and a mild alchol heat lingering warmly on the palate.  Very nice rendition of an American style barleywine; almost like a collision of American and English styles - the malt bill has a lot of English qualities, but the hops are distinctly west coast US.  Well done!

12oz bottle poured into sambuca snifter (the snifters were $1.00 each at the spirit haus!) this poured with no head.  the palate is light but syrupy... the flavs include the sugary malt, metallic hops and alcohol... the alcohol does not dominate, it only completes the piney flavor of this dank barleywine
wow this one packs a punch. quite a bit of alcohol in this one and i didnt like how long that lingered. not very thick for having this much ABV content.

Vertical tasting at the 2nd Annual Hell With The Lid Off Barley Wine Festival at Kellys Bar in East Liberty, Pittsburgh.

2004--Hazy apricot, thin white head. Aroma is the best of the three: malt, spices, sour dough, apple, pear. Flavor is malt, grass, bitter alcohol.

2005--Darker hazy orange ruby, thin white head. Aroma is fainter fruit, malt, grass. Flavor is grass, wheat, pine, malt, alcohol.

2006--Best flavor of the three. Clear amber ruby, thin white head. Aroma is quite faint: fruit (banana), malt. Flavor is banana, grass, wheat, plum.

Overall rating is 3.7

Pours crimson bronze with a tan bubbly head.  The aroma has heavily toasted malt with some dark fruits, 7-up like character, some abv warmth, light anise and other spices.  Medium / full body with a good amoutn of unobtrusive spritzy carbonation. The flavor starts with lots of woody / earthy hops with a big ol malt backbone - it is fairly harsh, but not really in a bad way.  The finish adds some spice, but the woody hops still take center stage.  Very nicely done, but not something I would want as a frequently consumed beer.

12oz bottle.poured dark amber brown with decent amount of off-whitish brown head.inital aroma is hoppy and then lots of caramal malttaste has a sharp pine-hop bite with a good amount of malt trying to balance it out although imo, it never really does. there could be a better balance between the two. and the alcohol is evident at 10.5 abv. it does. however, get better as it warms...all in all though, i would prefer a more balanced barley wine.

Poured from a bottle into a regular glass this one not so much very alcoholic smell and taste.  This one was hurt the stomach.  I know it was rich in character but a character I do not like.  Just not my style but do respect the taste.

Bottle.  Pours a brownish red with a limited head aboard.  Nose is lovely, fruit-filled of dried plums.  Flavor is strong and alcoholic.  A very intense barleywine.  I prefer them lighter with more sweetness.  This one was prommising based on the nose, but fell flat, limited carbonation, upon tasting.

bottle- was going to let this one age a bit but, im a bit to curious for that just now... pours cloudy deep rust color, with a somewhat foamy offwhite head. pretty good retention. oof this smells strong. alcohol... some citrus and cherries in there,it is quite fruity. holy hell this is a beast of a beer. it is strong... citrus up front grapefruit, very sweet as well but not too much. it seems quite hoppy for a barley wine it almost seems to start as a barley wine and finish as a double ipa. *note to self buy another one and age.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2008 Nice hops balanced with just the right amount of sweet malt.  Thin head with a nice copper red color.  Overall nice balanced barleywine.
Re-rate: Tried it again last night.  Flavor is bigger than I remember with a great lingering finish.  Excellent beer.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2007 From a trade with Immy.  Thank you!  Poured a rich brown with lots of copper and ruby highlights.  The head was relatively thin head that is gone in a flash.  The aroma was a combination of hops, brown sugar, citrus fruit and a touch of alcohol.  The flavor was sweet with a bit of maple and cherry (or raisin?) that was quickly taken over by a hoppy finish.  Alcohol is definitely noticeable.

12 oz bottle at Cole Barleywine Festival.  Dark amber, didnt have as sweet a flavor as some of the barleys I had, light head, smooth taste.  Out of the beers I tasted this didnt stand out as exceptional, but I also didnt find any of the brews bad at all.  Would put this as an average exceptional barley.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2008 2007 bottle.  This starts with the piney nose of northwestern hops.  It pours a cloudy reddish-amber, with just a lacing of an off-white head.  The flavor is surprisingly sweet, with just a finish of hops.  The alcohol content in this is dangerously hidden.  Several bottles of this have been cellered, and I will re-rate upon opening them.  (One from the cellar)  The hop nose has faded away, going with a bit more sweetness.  Still pours with a large foamy tan head, and the same cloudy dark red.  Hop flavor has almost completely disappeared, leaving a balanced sweetness, hints of brown sugar and dark fruits predominant.  Very nice.

Pours a hazy reddish copper, topped by a scant head of tan foam. Nice lacing. Malty aroma - sweet with raisin and brown sugar and alcohol.

Very malty flavor with earthy maple, toffee, caramel, brown sugar, and alcohol. Bitter hops, black tea, leather, oak and alcohol in the finish. A full bodied ass-kicker. Softly and fully carbonated
Sweet hoppy spicy aroma. Taste is sweet alcoholic, hoppy bitter, fruity with a long bitter hoppy finisch.

12 oz bottle.  Pours bronz with a slight light brown head.  Aroma is oily with  hops, and molasses prevelant.  A really interesting aroma.  Taste is a thick syrupy sweet maple with alcohol present.  Very complex.  A good beer.

Very sweet this one, somewhat the opposite of the ridiculously bitter Great Divide Old Ruffian.  Supposedly this would benefit more from aging.  Some head, rapidly dimishing to zilch.  Aroma kinda there.  Taste is thick and syrupy and sticky sweet but in a really good way, and it goes down smooth smooth smooth.  Subjectively this is a solid 8, though the silly "objective" scoring system downgrades this for so-so aroma and appearance.  I really did enjoy this more than the initial 3.8 would suggest; maybe Ill find a way to manipulate it up a bit.  Okay, manipulation done.  (1 point each for aroma, flavor, and overall.)
Currently playing: Sibelius 4.

Umm, wow.  This is a huge beer.  Brown pour with no head.  Thick aroma of malt, caramel, pine, and alcohol.  Heavy taste of the same, with maple, sugar, oily hop resin, and a big alcohol warmer.  This knocked me on my ass, but it was well worth it.

The first time i had a barleywine was a SN Bigfoot. This one is quite a bit smoother. Pours a nice dark amber color. Nice thick head :unsure: . But the drinkability for 11% is freaking great. Just a solid brew. JTG, :hifuckingfive:

Dark amber colour with little head; grapefruit, lemon and caramel aromas; sweetish/bitter taste with caramel, dates, citrus and pine aromas; bitter finsih with caramel, toffee and pine aromas.
A reasonable beer, but the malt and hop flavours clash in the mouth. Lacking complexity for a beer of its strength.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2009 Not for chugging. Wonderful flavor, aroma and appearance. Sweet and smooth. As it warms, it becomes more whiskey than beer. Alcohol is evident in smell and taste. Perfect for a cold winter night, if we ever get them in NJ again.

A: Pours a gorgeous ruby red/cranberry color, with a moderately thin head that dissipates quickly, except around the ages.

S: A very interesting scent, the beer almost smells refreshing, like a breakfast cocktail. Its definitely sweet and makes me want to take a gigantic gulp, but knowing what lies ahead, I dont plan on doing that.

T: Woah. I was unprepared for the first sip and the almost overwhelming alcohol presence, sort of like a Jack & Coke thats got flat/watered-down, or a zinfandel that someone stuck in the fridge. It has a very large boozy raspberry or cherry flavoring to it that Im not sure about, perhaps as it warms...and yes, that is the case. The beer gets better as it warms (as would be expected). Lots of complex flavors to this one, though very little, if any, finish.

M: The thinnest barleywine Ive had, its gone from your mouth as quickly as you sip it. I actually prefer my barleys to be a big "bigger" in terms of mouthfeel, but this one actually helps the drinkability.

D: Once youre past that initial burst of booziness, this beer becomes fairly easy to drink. Still not a chugging beer, heh, but not very hard to drink given the very high ABV. Id do more than one of these in a sitting.

Recommended.

Pours a hazy hazy amber, very light white head.  Very nice belnd of hops and matls in the smell, with a little skunky fruit as well.  Nice spice on the taste!  Pretty bitter, with notes of grapefruit and nuts.  Pretty neat combo actually.  Alcohol is quite present, maybe they could have masked it a little better but it is still quite good.  maybe a tad overrated.

Pours thick, even for a barley wine.  Great deep orange and golden color.  Thin head that faded fast.  Sweet and malty nose.  Powerful flavors of caramel and spice.  Great complexity on the palate.  Could sip this all winter!

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2011 Legend is built around the possible reasons why this is called old horizontal.  12 oz brown bottle brewed in my home state.  Aroma is sweetish. Much darker brown than I expected.  Hazy lighter maroon color.  Fine rising stream of bubbles that make me anticipate a creaminess. Fast fading tan head that settles to froth. Very strong alcohol impact on the first taste.  The creamy visual carbonation lies to its actuality, seems a little flat.  I think many rate craft beers with a high alky content high right off the bat.  Very strong, almost unbearable.  Not easily enjoyed if drank like a beer. My uvula is crying about the bitter strength.  I was always curious about this but I will not buy again.  The flavor is enough to knock you horizontal. I am afraid that I can not really enjoy this onslaught.  Just as intimidating as lagunus rown sugga, bells wheat love and blithering idiot.  I will never get used to this style.  Idiot is probably the best tasting of the four barley wines Ive had.  This beer finishes with thick syrupy tacky harsh lingers that hang on for what seems like too long. I probably should have rated this in the dead of night when no body was looking.  My taste buds are just too girlie to appreciate these brews. I must admit, that I feel better now that Ive consumed this!
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Dec 05 12 oz bottle.  Pour is a dark reddish orange with thin off-white head.  Aroma is very sweet.  Fruit, spice, raisins, and caramel nose.  Flavors is fruity and sweet, with caramel, spice, and maple.  Not quite as good as I was hoping, but still a good barley wine.

Pours lightly hazy orange with burgundy tint and a thin beige head. Retention of the diminutive head is commendable throughout the quaff, leaving adequate lacing so as to give me something intricate enough to look at, various geometric shapes. Its like high school on acid. Aroma is spicy hps, caramel malt and overripe fruit, a little spice cake as well. Flavor is near all malt at first and leaves a nice hop resin battery on the back end. Palate is very viscous and very mellow in spite of copious hops. Finishes with a sweet hop tang and a lingering burn from the alcohol and hop oils. Very good. 

One of the greats. Rating a carefully aged version would no doubt result in an overall score at least two points higher, hopefully that will hold true of more recently acquired vintages.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2007 Clean, well carbonated, burgandy colored, with minimal creamy head.   Aroma is of raisins and some carmaely malts.  Certainely a well brewed barley wine.  This still doesnt quite meet my expectation as one of the better ones Ive tried.  While this is quite young, with a perfumey flower like hops taste followed by some ripe fruity esters.  Hop oils saturate and burn the palate.  My kind of beer. This is an immensly enjoyable nite-capper.  I will tsave one of this 6-pack for a year from now.

This beer is courtesy of oldirtysurfer.

Poured a ruddy brown/red into my Troublette tulip, with little to no head at all. (Havent found a head inspiring barleywine yet)

THe nose is lush with hops. This is a big beer! Layers of butter, rock candy, and toast give in to a boat load o hop character, and a touch os spearmint.

The taste is smooth at first, than directly hop ripped. The alcoholic bite is fairly prevelant and is tending to muddle the mouthfeel a bit. A little metallic, too, but I think that it need to sit a spell first and breath.

It finishes beautifully with butter pecan, brandy, and hop.
A very good Barleywine, I recommend it.

Very sweet and strong aroma. I mainly noted a maple flavor in the taste. Alcohol definitely present in the aftertaste. I found that anything more than small sips of this to be overwhelming. This beer would probably be best with food.

12 oz bottle via trade with Kramer17801.  Bottled 2/4/05.  11% abv.  Pours reddish amber with a small but stable tan head.  Even through my clouded nasal passaes I can muster a nice sweet carameley aroma.  The taste is a bit lighter then I had expected on the front of the taste, with a much nicer rich warming feeling that extend throughout the rest of he brew.  The complexity of the flavor is slightly lacking but more then made up for by the fantastic mouth feeling.  With so much good barley wine recieved in recent trades, I could have probably aged this longer, but it was too tempting.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2007 Re rate. Thanks Immy. what its hot as hell......why wouldnt i be drinking barley wine?.....uhhh no date on bottle but i think it was this years batch.....so ya know it has about 8 months or so on it. great clear amber brown copper color. great tan head that fades slowly into a thin film. fantastic solid aroma. toffee raisins with a hint of chocolate and pine. very nice balanced bittersweet  spicy flavor. toffee raisins spicy black pepper and pine. finish medium dry lingering and quite spicy. nice bit of warm alcohol on the finish. quite like bourbon. full body nice moderate carbonation. this rating doesnt do this beer the justice it deserves.......but i need to shut the hell up and enjoy this fantastic beer!
12oz bottle. bottled 12/14/04. 11%abv. Thanks gputty! clear deep amber color with a nice tan head that leaves a thin film. nice warm aroma. rich malty raisins piney hops. rich sweet malty flavor with lots of piney hops and spicy alcohol. hint of cinnamon. warm spicy bitter hoppy finish. full thick rich sticky mothfeel. very good barley wine. very spicy.would like to try this one again. original rating 1/5/07 Score 7/4/7/4/16=3.8

Magenta-amber in color.  Caramel, brandyish aroma with a generous side of piney, kind of minty hops.  Tastes of citrus, cough medicine, sweet maple and wood.  Its strange and kind of interesting how hoppy it is, but I cant really decide if thats likeable or not.  Strikingly underdeveloped.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2008 Bottle:  99/00.  Pours a nice  copper/ lively brown with off-white/tan head.     Malty, hop nose, some citrus also....citrus has faded considerabley but is still there if you search. Full bodied. Some malty sweetness but not overly....to a dum dum quality grapeishness Hoppiness works well with the malt.....hoppiness fell off a bit and swirls withthe malt finish and is now blended more Finishes slightly sweet...now a bit grapey with an oily mouthfeel, some alc. showing itself in the finish.

Cant believe I havent rated this.  Been working on the case that I got last year for Christmas 2005.  Its a year older now and a little better than not bad.  Dense copper body with a nice foamy head that starts to form as I agitate it in a snifter.  Wonderful fruity aroma that continues to grow as it warms up.  Dried apricots and pears.  Wet hay and apples.  The alcohol burn of cheap Communion wine.  So very comforting even in the warm clime of Florida.  Great sipping beer to top off a hard day while winding down for a dream-filled slumber.  And at the rate Im drinking this contemplative brew, Ill have some vintage bottles to carry me on through long, lugubrious times.  Makes me almost look forward to them.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2012 Victorys Old Horizontal is the first barleywine I have tried. A nice winter brew that warms me up on the inside. Great after-dinner-sipping beer. Ive heard its great to have with desert or a cigar too.  This ale is very bitter with a hint of citrus and a kick that hides the 11% alc very well....actually what am I saying...this beer is intense. RERATE: 1998 Bottle split with Simon and Vin. Pours a murky brownish amber body with thick haze and lots of chunky sediment. Aroma is sour, dark fruit, sugar, and molasses. Mouthfeel is nice, the beer feels good with age, with notes of molasses, vanilla, sugar, and some sour fruit.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2008 **New**
Wow! Now that I have a half hearted appreciation for this style I realize that this is AWESOME! Not over the top like a lot of American barley wine. The big thing here (small as it may seem for you Europeans) is the carbonation. Great carbonation, tastes fresh and does not feel like you are drinking old motor oil. Nice sweet malty aroma with a warming alcohol burn but not getting too Vicks Vapo-Rubby with it. The most drinkable barley wine to date for me.

Old rating: A-6 A-3 F-6 P-3 OI-15 Total Score-3.3
Not a bad barley wine from one of my ol faithfuls, Victory. This was a nice take on the genre with a bitterness to it that I havent noticed in barley wines before. I dont drink these often but I would have this one again. Pour was a rich amber with a perfect 1 finger head. The aroma was fruity and the taste was caramelly with malt and alcohol aftertaste. You can feel this one going down. Good job.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: I do not like Victory as much as others on this site, and the same can be said about this beer.  The taste/smell has been summed up by others better than I (typical barley wine taste) and it is very good.  The part where I get hung up is all the hops at the end of the beer.  I know fellow raters enjoy hops, but I dont enjoy them as much as most people.  The ending of this beer (last swallow down your throat) is very hoppy.  This takes away from the enjoyment for me, as I would rather have a BW more balanced, and an IPA hoppy.

A nice copper amber pour with a sticky lacing. An aroma of raisins, malt and light alochol. A flavor of rich sweet maltiness, fruit, and light alochol. A nice lite bitter that really sets this beer off. A beer from a style that I really like a beer that I really like.

Having noticed that each night I keep picking one of these out of my well-stocked fridge (it is the holiday season), I surmise that I must really like this beer. I like barleywines in general but this is one of the smoothest ones with no off tastes or harsh notes. The alcohol is not overwhelming but the result is smooth and warming. I had one at the Victory brewpub several years ago and thought it was the effect of a Storm King that made me enjoy it so. This was the first bottled version I have had since local distributors dont generally carry it. Time to place an order.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2008 12oz bottle dated 12/04 (2 years old now). this was my first drink during the great blizzard of Colorado 06. pours a light brown with sustaining head around the outside. looks lighter than most BW. aroma is rather unpleasant with weak malty sweetness with some citrus from the hops. flavor has that typical barleywine flavor, big malt presence with still a good amount of bitterness (even after 2 years). flavor also has a slight hint of a chocolate covered clementine (i swear!). hops also provide a nice grapefruit flavor. alcohol is very well hidden. in the end this BW doesnt do anything to offend me and yet nothing to impress. enjoyable and easy to drink. Ive had it fresh and at 4 years (12/02) and as of now i prefer it was 2 years on it.3.2.

12oz bottle dated 12/04 (aged for 3 years). nose of raisins, toffee, and dark fruits. flavors of sweet toffee, tobacco, and some dark fruits. some hop bitterness too. pretty dry and alcohol warmth finishes. a rather short and watery palate. i think i like this a little more than at 2 years but it really isnt very complex. not sure if more age will help.6/4/7/3/14=3.4 

12/18/07, 2005 vintage dated 12/9/05. cellared for 2 years. the citrusy hops havent blended well with the aged malts as everything seems hard to drink. not the worst aged BW but at 2 years this needs more time. much better at 3 years.3.3.

2/6/08, 2008 vintage, dated best before 1/15/13. bottled 3 weeks ago. on hearing the 08 vintage marks a resurrection for Old Ho I needed to pick up a 6er for myself. and wow. its back! pours dense reddish-bronze with creamy beige head. looks great. aroma is intensely fresh maltiness that will age out, caramel and piney grapefruit nose. flavor is pretty hoppy with floral grapefruit citrus notes combined with red and dark fruits getting hit big with caramel maltiness. a big slick body, long palate, and alcohol well hidden. a bit brash at times right now but really drinkable and somehow the soul of this beer found its way back into this vintage. 8/4/8/5/16=4.1

Thanks to Papsoe. Bottle. Dark amber brown colour with a little head. Aroma of caramel, sweetness and some flower too. Flavour of burned caramel, hops and ends up with a warm feeling from the alcohol.

Pours kinda brownish red with a thinn tan head. With a hoppy nose with a touch of sweetness in the aroma. Taste is big and full of flavors. It starts of sweet and packed with fruit flavors raisin and dark plum flavors. This is all balanced out by some bittering of the hops and a bit of alcohol on the tail end of the sip. Mouthfeel is fairly thick and the beer seems to want to stick which is a nice touch. I like the beer not gonna lie.
Pours murky brown with an almost non existent head. Aroma is fruity with hints of cherry. Flavor is sweet and fruity, with a bitter hop and alcohol finish.

One bottle from JB. Dark rich copper color cloudy with a full light tan well laced head. Rich toffee & carmel aromas some raisens. Rich velvety palate well coated. Flavor is very malty sweet carmels some rich molases.   I have not liked Barley wine ales in the past, but this was good.

Bottled Dec 2004.  Cloudy, deep amber appearance with a large beige head and spotty lacing.  Resinous hop aroma, some citrus, with additional notes of sweet malts and alcohol.  Flavor starts sweet and fruity but evens out a bit as it warms, displaying qualities found in good dessert wines.  Rich, full-bodied, moderately carbonated mouthfeel leading to a warming, lingering, long lasting finish.

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2008 12 oz Bottle from Dec 05 (1 yr old now) via trade (thanks to whoever sent it to me). Pours a hazy dark amber with a small white head. Nose is full of fruity esters. Some apricot, cherries, peach and lots of alcohol. Tastes the same with a bit of butterscoth and lots of citrus hops. A big alcohol burn in the finish. Full bodied. Moderate carbonation. A bit too hoppy and rough around the edges. Sorry i think this one is pretty over-rated. maybe laying this down for another year would help?*********************re-rate 11/01/2008******orig rating from 12/10/06 was 6/3/6/4/13=3.2**************
12 oz JAN 2004 bottle via Bridgeview. 4 years, 10 mos old. Pours a dark reddish brown with a nice beige head that stocks around. Nose is vanilla, fruity esters, earth...taste is caramel/honey, raspberry, orange peal, earthy hops. Body is full, carbonation is light/medium.

November 03 bottle. Smooth, sweet and complex. Cloudy copper. Small off-white head. Strong malty aroma. Notes of ripe fruits, especially oranges, along with sugar, caramel and alcohol. Very sweet flavor followed by warming alcohol and hop bitter. Silky smooth mouthfeel. Moderately long finish. Great mix of flavors, comfortable texture. Excellent.

12/02/06 Walk the Line Barleywine Festival, Dunedin, FL. 1998 vintage. The beer took on a copper hue with streaks of red around the edges. The head of foam was tan. The aroma was classic Barleywine with a dark fruitiness backed up by some caramel and a hint of hops. It was difficult to tell which type of hops they were just from the aroma. The flavor was first rate. The cherry and dark grape fruitiness mixed with the smooth creamy sweet caramel. There was an undercurrent of pine hops and a sense of alcohol.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Pours a hazy, orangey brown with a small, off-white head. Fat aroma of caramel. Very solid and full-bodied with plenty of caramel and notes of overripe fruit. Hoppy - but not overly so - finish. 031206
UPDATED: FEB 9, 2007 Red brown color. Some good fruit flavors, but alcohol taste is even stronger. Excellent body.

Pours a dark copper, without much of a head.  Looks a bit like fresh motor oil.  Very fruity aroma, that seems to have a wee bit of alcohol in it.  Heavy and thick, with a sweetness that belies the alcohol that is obviously there.  I think it is the smoothness that makes this so good.  I will enjoy the rest of this bottle.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: Bottle.   Pours a cloudy rusty ruby color with a decent sized pale  yellow head that rests quickly.   Aroma is malt, vanilla, dark fruit, nuts, and floral hops.   Flavor is sweet malt, vanilla, honey, some citrus pokes through, pepper.   Mouthfeel is thick and oily, very smooth.   Surprised by the hop punch and lack of burn in this one!   Really good!

[12oz Bottle Thanks The Beer God]  
Hazy deep amber color, good thick head.  Very deep dried frit aroma.  A tad high in alochol but this was a very nice easy to drink Barleywine.  A great sipping by the fire barleywine.

[Bottled. Thanks Kramer]
Hazy dark amber colour, good head. Aroma mostly from dried fruits, almonds, butterscotch and loads of hops. Nice. Also bit buttery and alcohol-ish in aroma. Thick, yet pretty smooth mouthfeel with little licorice and a malt sweetness. Fiery. Salty. Peppery alcohol. Long flavour. Hopbitter.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2007 (Bottle, thanks Rickgordon and beachbum25) Pours hazy amber/red. Dried fruits and fresh fruits, hops, raisins, fudge/toffee-ish malt in aroma with apples and oranges. Rich malty sweetness in flavour with fruits and peppery alcohol. A bit salty with liquorice hints. Young taste. Medium mouthfeel and body. Lingering afterbitterness with a light sweetness.

Bottle from Liquid Solutions. Pours  thick syrupy maroon color. No head. Rich malty aroma. Slightly sweet. Sweet fruitiness. Some tart aromas as well. Smooth almost slimey mouthfeel. Thick rich malty, dark fruit flavor alon with some hoppy bitterness. Some alcohol is present as well, but only a little. Finish is hop bitterness and alcohol. Good stuff. My bottle was 11%.

Ah, the old horizontal. You must have it on tap at the brewery, the bottle does not even come close. My first one off the tap had a firm caramel head with a wonderful sweet  aroma. Spicy and pungent with a hint of fruity goodness. The second one was better than the first and after that I realy didnt  notice much of anything. Watch out, it does creep up on ya. All in all a spiritual experience if you ever get a chance to visit eastern PA.
Pours mahogany, minimal head.  Flavor is overly sweet and spicy.  Dark fruits, toffee, caramel with spicy hops.  Alcohol is barely noticeable.  This just isnt a style I like, but this seems good.
12oz Bottle Pours out a amber topped with a small tan head. Very nice sweet and fruity aroma. Very smooth and the alcohol is not very apperent. A very nice BW

Pours a deep dark ruby with a small tan head.  Pungent aroma of fig, molasses and caramel maltiness, perhaps a hint of cherries.  Flavor is plums, figs, a touch of orange peel finishing with spicy hops layered over a smooth caramel malts.  Thick chewy but smooth body.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2007 Pours a deep amber with a nice tan head. Huge fruity nose with berry hints (raspberry preserves, strawberries) lemon-rind. Beautiful fruitiness in the flavor as well. Flavor parallels the aroma. Chewy, with hints of berry like sweetness, a touch of lemony tartness, strong grapefruit bitterness and a roasty warmth. Well balanced and nice.

Poured a delightful shade of cloudy dark brown with orange highlights and a medium head, with minimal lacing.  Aroma is very fruity, quite pear-like actually, but theres a caramel sweetness to it as well.  Balanced aroma.  Taste is sweet and malty at first, but theres a dried fruit flavor there too.  Hints of hop bitterness are already present in the taste, and its a welcome twist IMO.  Finish gradually converts the lingering sweetness into a woody hop flavor that is bitter, but not overwhelming.  Very good stuff, makes me think of Old Stock Ale, but with a stronger hop flavor and bite in the finish.

Bottled December 22, 2005. Cloudy burnt orange with small light brown head. A hoppy aroma with a hoppy and warm alcohol taste. A very good barley wine. Very smooth and warming. Great for a cold nights. You need to watch this one it will sneak up on you!

This is a very nice beer.  It pours a hazy dark amber color with a  rather sparse off white to tan head.  The aroma is great with nice strong aroma of floral and citrus hops present.  The flavor is sweet but not unplesantly so initially dominated by fruity hops and great malt balance.  Some toffeee present and you can taste the alcohol.  Its presence however is handled well and all in all this is a nice and balanced beer

dark rich copper color cloudy w/ a full light tan well laced head.  Rich toffee & carmel aromas some breads, plums, and raisens.  Rich velvety palate well coated.  Flavor is very malty sweet carmels some rich molases.  Good stuff.

(Bottle 12 Fl oz) Shady red orange color, tan head. Citrus hoppy scent, some butter. Sweet and some alcohol as well. Thick mouthfeel. Alcohol taste, warming. Sweet and malty. Sweet aftertaste. A little bit grainy. Medium bitterness.

Bottle courtesy after4ever. Pours a hazy dark amber with warm red highlights and a thin but lacy yellow head. The aroma has some nuts, fruit and toffee with lightly floral notes. Medium body. Taste of butterscotch with roasty and nutty flavors behind it. Dry resin and flowers finish. Almost tastes spiced.

Bottled September, 05.  Served in a snifter.  Hazy, caramel-colored body with a small, light brown head.  Aroma starts with rich sweet malts.  Theres a little bit of hops playing around in the nosing, but the malt dominates.  As it warms a bit, theres a touch of whisky in there too.  At first the flavor just pounded my tounge into oblivion, but I could decipher it a bit once my palate accomadated.  Its a lot more hoppy than the aroma hints at.  In the throat theres some alcohol warming, but its not overly boozy.  While barley wines (this one included) are generally a little big for my personal preference, I can still tell that this a well-made beer.

12-oz.; thanks, BeachBum25! This is a pretty confusing beer. And thats actually whats such a pleasure about it. Starts off very barleywine-like, with a thick-looking, fairly still-looking, ruddy amber pour with ruby highlights and a tan head. The head falls to a psychedelic paisley swirl before you can put the bottle down. Big fruit on the nose, figgy and plummy and sharply boozy. Caramel and toffee are there, too-when its cooler, the caramel is actually borderline domineering: the malt is strong with this one. The attack has the obligatory tawniness, caramel and butterscotch, roast and nuts. The finish is a mystery. What is that? Orange pith? Coriander? Rauch malt? Burning leaves? Its almost a hollow flavor, too. Theres crisp, resiny hops there, but theyre in the minority, and its proving difficult to name the mystery ingredient in the finish. The bodys light for a barleywine, the sugars are quite--and quite admirably-subdued, and the carb is low. Theres none of the usual lapel-grabbing trouble you get from a young barleywine here.

Victory Old Horizontal
12 oz bottle
Best before 01/11, sipped 10/06
Medium pour in an English pint glass


Poured a clear copper with a small mostly diminishing light orange and brown frothy head.

Smelt of  moderate malty sweetness with light sweet spicy banana bread and light alcohol and some resin.

Taste was upfront sweet malt with light caramel and bananas with a spicy cloves kick followed by a biting bitter punch to the face, that dies quickly but gracefully to meld back with the malt sweetness, in a light wet autumn leaves, dried spiced raisins, and resin feel that lingers on a long constantly evoving finish.  Mouthfeel was medium to full bodied, oily, softly carbonated with moderate alcoholic warmth.

Overall, an attractive looking barley wine that punches and  captivates the palate but is slightly disappointing on the nose.

Brown bottle, 12 ounces, purchased on August 26, 2006 while visiting Beers of the world (Rochester) with Dum, Ian and Lubière; eye: looks thick as you poor it, brown with caramel reflections, not much head that leaves a ring around the glass, lacing; nose: hops, caramelized malt, alcohol, pepper, clove; mouth: caramelized malt, then hops that arrives rapidly and stays until the end, supported by a brandy-like taste, finale in hops wrapped in caramelized malt which turns into a hops-malt-alcohol chocolate, midly sweet, quite bitter, full body, slick and alcoholic texture, average carbonation; overall: really good

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 12 onces, acheté le 26 août 2006 chez Beers of the world (Rochester) lors dun mémorable voyage avec Dum, Ian et Luc; oeil : semble dense lorsquon la vide, brune avec des reflets caramels, faible mousse beige qui forme un anneau autour du verre, dentelle; nez : houblon, malt caramélisé, alcool, poivre, clou de girofle; bouche : malt caramélisé, puis le houblon qui samène en trombe et demeure jusquà la toute fin, soutien de brandy, finale en houblon enrobé de malt caramélisé puis qui se transforme en une sorte de chocolat au houblon, malt et alcool, moyennement sucrée, assez amère, corsé, texture lisse et alcoolique, moyennement carbonatée; en résumé : très bonne

Bottle. Pours thick and hazy dull red/amber with a thin head. Candy like aroma, fruity and hoppy. Big malt and caramel flavor, sweet and hoppy. Like sucking on a barly wine lolly pop. The alcohol is not too prominent but is noticable. Mellow bitterness.
Hazy red body, tan head.  Extremely fruity aroma.  Complex flavour involving hops, fruit, alcohol, malt.

This beer will leave you horizontal  no doubt ! For the high alcohol content it is rather smooth. POORS ORANGE, HOPPY SMELL APPARENT. Taste is smooth. I like this alot ! Thanks to the evil elf for this one.
This is a deep mahoghanny color with a white head. It has a sweet, fruity aroma and a sweet flavor with some clove spiciness.

Cloudy dark reddish-brown ale with a lot of sediment. My bottle claims 11% alcohol. Very small head. Aroma of cherries and dark fruit. Alcohol burn hits you immediately like sippin on some brandy. Taste like plums, burnt plums and the alcohol makes it pretty dry, like you would think rubbing alcohol tastes. Maybe Ive just got a bad bottle but this is not very enjoyable.
Bottle. Dark golden in colour with a medium sized head. Malty and sweet with notes of dark fruits, caramel and grass. Hints of cherry (or berries of some sort) and also a bit alcoholic.

This beer came in a tulip glass that looked like an orb of dark glowing cherries with a dark tan head that left some slight lace. 

Smelled of dark fruits, brandy, caramel and a little touch of pineapple and cedar. 

The taste floored me! I took a sip and just sat back for the ride. Tasted of thick burnt caramel and thick dark prunes and plumbs. There was also spicy yeast mixed with cloves and other spices. The flavors went by so fast, it was hard to pin them all down. Around the edge of my tongue, there were dry hop bubbles that swirled around that didnt interfere with the flavor, but complemented it nicely. The finish was dynamic too! Faded from all of this, to chocolate, and then to cherries and left me with a nice warming. Fantastic! 

Mouth feel was a few shades shy of chewy, so it was still very drinkable.
bottle. golden amber color. fresh raisons aroma. lots of raisons in taste. hoppy and grassy. malty caramel.

Pours an orangish-brown color with a thick brown head.  Aroma is of dark fruits, caramel, cherry, alcohol, and probably the most hops Ive been able to pick up on a barley wine.  Very well blended with the flavors of the malts and the hops.  Nothing is overpowering over anything else.  Thick on the palate with some alcohol warming to finish. Very surprised with this brew.  Strongley recommended.

Thank you Secret Santa! Pours orange in color with a small head that forms into a ring and lasts the duration. Aroma is significantly hoppy, mostly earthy citris (think of oranges that have been sitting on the ground a month or so) Alcohol is clearly noticable, not like vodka style alcohol, more like a good port, you know its there and it fits the position well. Sweet, oily and heavy with enuff hops to easily break through the malt fog. Wow, this beer could put you to bed in short order... dangerously easy to drink for something of this magnitude.

Bottle from trade with kmweaver. Pours a deep copper color with a nice tan head. Leaves some nice lacing.  Aroma is outstanding! Smells of floral hops and cognac. Taste of caramel, slightly sweet and a nice alcohol snap to it. This was my first barleywine and I am now certainly interested in trying more.

bottle.  Aroma:  This one smells really good.  Lots of cherry and grape intertwined with a rich caramel.  Some brandy notes remind me that this has alot of alcohol.  A touch of pine peeks out invitingly.  Appearance:  Deep copper bordering on ruby in color and quite clear.  Head was a light sandy color and although full and creamy, dissipated swiftly.  Some nice lacing.  Flavor:  Big, rich caramel malt flavor up front with notes of dried cherries, a touch of pepperiness, and some piney hop flavor.  Alcohol comes on strong in the finish, and is just short of being too much.  Palate:  Full mouthfeel with a slightly oily texture.  Moderate carbonation. Finish is sweet with lots of alcohol.  Nice alcohol warming covers my entire mouth.  Overall:  This is a very good barleywine. Rich and malty, good alcohol presence, and just enough hops.  The perfect nightcap.

Pours a deep copper color with a very slight beige head that none the less shows high lacing. Aroma is fresh a mix of fresh bread, alchohol and banana. Mouthfeel is thick a vicscous, excellent with a nice mix of carmel malt, fresh an not too astringint hops, decept sweetness.  Limited lingering aftertaste you get a sense of the alcohol as it goes down.  Im barley through this bottle and I wonder if Ill be horizontal before I finish it.  Wow.  Great. Special thanks to James Maley for bringing this beer to Panama.
Odor of olives hop and sweet roasted corn.  Nice beer, a sipping beer.  Tasted sweet and hoppy.  Balanced mouthfeel.

Cloudy dark orange pour, syrupy thick with very little head.  Aroma was faint but sweet along with some hoppiness.  Thick heavy mouthfeel, with plum notes at first, then the hops take over.  I had a difficult time discerning any fruit in the palate.  The alcohol is evident, very astringent in the finish, I almost want to say briny like olive juice. Way hoppier than I expected and not too balanced in my opinion.

WOW! Pours a darkish amber with a small head. Strong hop aroma. Great lacing. Flavor is a perfect malt / hop balance. A great sipping beer. I think it would only take a few of these to make a person horizontal.

Pours a thick brick brown into the glass, with a lacing off-white head.  Looks initially syrupy.  The nose is comforting, of raisins, plums, prunes, dark fruit, brown sugar and molasses.  Very syrupy mouthfeel, thick and coating.  There is an initial sweet toffee malt upfront, with huge notes of brown sugar, molasses and raisins.  Then, alcohol and hops take over in the mid-palate, and round out with a slightly alcoholic pepper finish.  This is a unique take on the barleywine style, as Ive had quite a few, and this is the hoppiest Ive noted.  Its not a bad contingency, but makes the mouthfeel suffer slightly.  The contrast, which should cut (via the hops) the palate, instead clashes slightly with the syrupy-oily notes.  Im getting two distinctly different directions at the same time.  Again, this isnt a bad brew, but Im keeping it from cresting the 4-point scale due to inconsistencies in the mouthfeel, caused by diverse flavor palates which affect my overall impression.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2006 Bottle.  Pours a hazy, ruddy orange color with a fine beige head.  Aroma is sugary sweet with a nice hop background with a bit of alcohol; also, nice rounded malt with some great fruit (pineapple) and some vanilla.  Very forward flavor with nice bitterness and some chewy hops following that sweetness I got in the aroma.  I can taste the alcohol for sure, but it works well at the end.  Nicely carbonated, but the mouthfeel is a tad oily.  Overall, a very nice beer

Very cloudy/hazy light reddish brown. Small head goes away quickly. Sweet malt aroma...honey and banana. Big hop bite in the taste. A little bit of fruit. Tasty, but not as complex as I expected. Alcohol comes on strong at the finish. A bit thin. Worth trying, b ut seems a bit overated compared to other barleywines.

via trade with jasonmech77 - Pours a hazy amber color with a small off white head that fades to a film.  Aroma is floral hops and fruity.  Flavor is mainly a sweet fruit flavor.  Nice hop bitterness to balance it out.  Kind of a thick mouth feel.  Very little alcohol warming.  Very nice.  Thanks Jason

I previously wrote a review from the bottle. This is a similar review but the taste on tap is not as green IMO from the tap. So I made a few edits and my ratings are different. 

I had Old Horizontal on tap at Victory last year and I loved it. One of my all time favorite beers. I was looking forward to when I could get it for this (the 05) year. I was a bit disappointed because the previous batch seemed to be a bit more mellow (and I preferred that) but we will see what is yet to come.


Appearance: This beer pours a beautiful translucent amber color with great lacing.

Smell: Crisp and hoppy with undertones of sweet malts. Hints of alcohol peek through.

Taste: MUCH hoppier than I remember. A bit too green in taste (like rabbit food green). The green hops just got right up in my face. Smooth-ish but (did I say) green, layered on top of a very nice sweet malt base. I like the alcohol that shows through. (as a whiskey/wine fan I like alcohol just not the green tongue aftertaste). 

Mouthfeel: Crisp and light for a barley wine. Not very sticky more dry and noticeable alcohol pucker.

Drinkability: What I had last year on-tap was fantastic but this I have to say was bearable but not terribly great! A bit too hoppy for me, but not a bad choice to accompany a meal or to have with cheese on the side.

---
EDIT
I had this again on-tap. I definitely prefer it at Victory on-tap. I did prefer 04s batch to 05s and I hope that 06s will mellow a bit again.
---

Hope this is helpful.
Cheers!

Bottle.  Bottled Dec 29 2004.  Its Victory allright as I pour the bottle into the glass I can already smell the hops!  Even in a barleywine, they stuff it full of that magical green cone... forget the beanstalk, Jack wouldnt have even climbed if it were a hop vine... he would have cut it down as soon as he smelled it,  so he could wet hop a brew.... back to the rating... not much head on a hazy amber color... great nose of sweet toffee, pineapple, some pinecone maybe, nice!  flavor is great, sweet chewy malt with a cookie flavor sneaking in before a bit of hop bitterness and then the inevitable alchohol burn.... I actually like this beer a little cooler than most barleywines, because the flavors seem to be overpowered a bit by the burn as it warms.  Great mouthfeel as this one is silky and smooth... still some good chunks rolling around in the bottom of the glass as I continue to quaff this beauty.... another great one from the dirty side of Pennsylvania... great job Victory!

Bottle best by Jan 24 11. You got to be kidding me. How can someone even keep a beer arround for five years without trying it. Its got a stong alcohol aroma along with barley grain and pine.
Barley wheat flavor and some alcohol punch. Definently a body warmer. Good thing it wont break 100 today need some water for hydraysion.

UPDATED: FEB 29, 2008 Nice pour, sweet, hoppy aroma.  Flavor alternates between nice sweetness and fairly bold, piney/sweet hops.  Very nice, even finish that stays around but not in an annoying way.  I see a common theme with these victory beers - great, almost IPA-ish hop flavor in other strong ales.  Much like storm kings great hoppy flavor, this one satisfies and leaves you longing for more.  Alcohol barely noticable at 10%+.  Wonderful.  ****** March 2007 head to head of 05 and 06 vintages.  2005 has mellowed well, but still boasts a substantial hop flavor that mixes well with the malty sweetness.  2006 looks darker and has almost Doppelbock-like qualities in malt flavor and aroma.  Newer vintage is obviously stronger and more alcoholey, but still complex and rich.  


2/29/08 - its re-rate day!  Somehow I lost my rating of the 2000 bottle of this - I remember it being a tad thin and oxidized but still damn good.  I decided to try an 05, 06, and 07 back to back tonight - I still find the 05 to be rather sweet and grainy, but with some very good honey sweetness.  06 is my least favorite - not all that great right now.  07 is pleasantly suprising, probably the best of the bunch with some time under its belt - nice hop usage with a light fruit tartness.  I took this down a few points, but its still an old standby and one of my favorites - not as good to me as it was as a newbie rater, but still my favorite Victory beer.

As I love barleywines, Ive been trying to track this one down for a while.  Found it in Marcy, NY.  Quite nice, one of my favorite barleywines.  Not much of a head, but it did have good lacing.  Aroma was of sweet malt and fruity.  Taste was quite sweet and thick mouthfeel.  I was a little unimpressed.  Maybe my expectations were set a bit too high.  Good, but not great.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2007 Bottled 12/29/04.  Nice amber/red color with caramel and plum aroma.  Had small amount of off-white head.  Tasted somewhat sweet, yet bitter.  Finished bitter with slight taste of alcohol, but certainly not overwhelming.  I found myself liking this more and more with every sip.  Ill definitely be saving the rest of these to see how well it ages. 9/4/9/4/18

Re-rate 12/08/06: Same vintage.  Though its only been about 5 months, this has held up quite well.  Interestingly, I was greeted with a hoppy aroma before the familiar caramel and dark fruits.  Poured with no head, yet the carbonation was still very lively.  A bit thinner than I remember though and I probably overrated it the first time.  8/3/8/4/15

Bottle 2005. Aroma malty,light spice,brown sugar.  Poured a brown color with a light cap.  Flavor was pine and sugary giving way to a tad of fruit and grain.  Palate was good a little tough on the hot side though.  Overall good.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2007 12oz, Bottled Feb 04 05.  Pours a hazy orange brown with a tiny light tan head.  Aroma is lotsa brown sugar, molasses, burnt caramel--not to the point of bad, but toasted caramel?--and raisins.  I do get some nuts and a hint of vanilla as well.  As far as hops go, I get some pine and earthiness.  The taste is very cereal and grainy.  To save typing, the taste is much the same, the cereal is fairly dominant in the finish.  Alcohol is noticeable, though doesnt seem quite like 10.5% (my bottle says 11%).  Nuts and burnt caramel are the strongest up front, vanilla still there as well.  Soft carbonation, full bodied.  Very good, though the cereal grainy-ness I dont really like.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Cloudy brown color.  Smell of friut, malt, alcohol, hops, spice and nuts.  Taste of spicy hops, fruit, malt honey, alcohol and a bittersweetness at the end.  Particals at the bottom of the glass.

Pours a medium brown that you cannot see through, with a medium tan head. Intital aroma is spicy, peppery, and piney hops. As it warms, more malt based flavors of some dark fruit become noticeable, and the aroma becomes more and more complex. Rich, full mouthfeel with very light carbonation. Sweet flavors of brown sugar, and some burnt caramel are followed by a light roastiness.Alcohol becomes more and more evident, and bBitterness comes on gradually and leads to a dry, lingering finish. This is really very drinkable, and very nicley balanced. Im glad that I have another two bottles.

I had been searching for a place that sold singles of this for a long time and I finally found a bottle from feb 2005 at belmont in dayton. Pours a slightly cloud brown color which reminded me of a belgian ale for some reason. Aroma of strong alcoholic malts and some piney hops. Flavor was very malty with a little bitterness on the back of the tongue and slight alcohol burn, but the alcohol wa actually hidden very well. Also got a little dark fruit flavor in the after taste.  This was very good but I was expecting to like this a little more than i did.

OK. Dont remember much because I was drinking other beer before and didnt give this the proper tasting that it deserves.  There was definitely a lot of flavors in the nose and the tongue. Sweet toffee, syrup, carmel, dates, etc. The alcohol wasnt as prevalent as I might have thought.

Bottled. Dated 12/22/05. Beer is a dark mahogany with a small, frothy, white, totally diminishing head. Odd smelling a BW when its 90 degrees outside. The aroma is malty with moderate notes of toasted grain, cookie and caramel; Hoppy with a light note of resin/pine, moderate notes of dried apricot and herb; Yeasty with a light note of dough, trace of cellar; Miscellaneous notes of moderate-to-heavy alcohol, moderate notes of dried stone fruit, raisins oak and vanilla, apple , light note of cinnamon. The flavor is heavily sweet, lightly-to-moderately bitter, lightly-to-moderately acidic with a long, warm, moderately bitter/grippy, lightly sweet finish. Caramely retros. Heavy-to-harsh alcoholic feeling in the mouth, sliding all of the way down the gullet. A bit much to be cozy. The body is full, the texture is velvety and the carbonation is soft.
Sampled at LCRBM 05. Extreme wooden aroma. Cloudy red brown. Wooden cognac flavors, quite sweet. Wooden dusty aftertaste.

Pours amber with thin offwhite head.  Aroma is floral/resiny hops, sweet fruit.  Taste is sweet fruit and malt up front, but finishes with a heavy bitter hop punch.  Palate is thick and full without being sticky.  Very good.  Nice big flavor.

Bottle - Poured a dark amber color with a light white head. Head dissappears pretty quickly but leave a lacing along the glass. Aroma is fruit and hops. Taste is sweet but not overly sweet, hops give it a nice bitterness. Alcohol gives it a nice kick at the end, with a little woody taste. Excellent, drinkable, delightful barleywine.

Bottled 12/11/05 Nose is of caramel, with malts, and dark fruit note. Hazy, amber-red with a small off-white head; flavor is of caramel, not too sweet with some hoppy bitterness, and a little of the 11% (as per the label) alcohol leaving a nice alcohol finish with an oaky tone along with the alcohol.

Bottled on 12/9/05.  Pours a good looking amber color with a light head that dissipates with a bit of lace.  Some decent looking carbonation (a bit surprising).  The aroma is sweet caramel and full malt aromas.  A bit nutty with some dried dates and wood.  Fairly light aroma though.  The flavor is different than I expected.  And actually, after having the new hair of the dog, Ive noticed that these Barley Wines that are rated so high are much woodier and dryer than other barley wines.  Perhaps this is a stylistic difference that I am not used to, but thus far I have not come to fully appreciate it.  Anyhow, I got some wood, earthy hops, bourbon hints and burnt caramel initially.  There was some malty/caramel/sweetness deep down that I found myself wanting more of.  There are also hints of dry coco/dark chocolate and dark dry fruit that linger and the finish cuts to a dryish bitterness that is earthy.

wow, big thick, syrupy, alcohol all over the place.  its intense to say the least.  big alcohol content, very fruity, almost winelike.  Syrupy sweet.  tasty and fun.  This one will give you a headache if you arent careful.

"Victory Old Horizontal is one massive beer. Not what I expected at all for this style. Very subtle fruitiness, and more hoppy than I expected. The taste here is big and the mouthfeel is very heavy. I got plenty of caramel in the nose and flavor, and you can sense the alcohol--especially once it warms up. The alcohol plays well in the flavor of this one somehow though. Cant wait to get into the rest of this batch."

Unlike the cloudy mess of HOTD barley wine, this one pours a beautiful clear deep red amber.  Its aroma is sweet with hints or brown sugar and hops.  Rich flavor on the palate with a nice balance between hops and sweetness.  Incrediblely smooth beer, without noticing the high alchohol presence.
Very rich in malt and fruity flavours also. A hop taste at the end. Very tasty, one of my favorite.

12 oz bottle-Pours a nice reddish/amber color w/a small off white head. Sweet malted aroma. Sweet fruity, vanilla taste w/roasted molasis. Reminds you somewhat of a nice smooth glass of brandy. Long smooth finish w/traces of hopps. Dont really taste the high alcohol. A good sample of a Barley Wine

Victorys beers are fantastic. This one starts out with a rich, molasses nose that is more malty than hoppy. Rich, reddish amber color with a small white-tan head. Tastes like it smells. Finish is somewhat hoppy and very good. Hops come out increasingly as it warms. Surprisingly drinkable for an 11%abv. An excellent beer.

dark amber with a small off white head.  Aroma is of citrus hops, alot of malt, and sweet vanilla.  Taste is slightly bitter up front and very malty but smooth in the middle, with notes of wood, and vanilla, and some fruity notes.  Decent lasting bitter, and warming finish.  Alcohol seems to be very well masked in this barleywine, i need to buy a couple of more bottles.

Light brown pour with thin head offers a nose of intense malt sweetness containing licorice, brown sugar, and plum. Palate is luscious, smooth, and layered in a truly remarkable way. Flavor is deep and rich as a good barleywine should be. A chewy molasses character dominates with revolving shades of sweetness ebbing and flowing. This is excellent and the alcohol is masked completely with only a little aging.

Pours a dark amber color, with a  off white head that had some lacing power.  Aromas of citrus, sweet malts, and some alcohol.  Flavor isnt as sweet as I was led to believe.  You can taste the alcohol from the get go, what follows is a nice mellow brown sugar (I Guess) sweetness that finishes with a nice bitter hop.

12 oz-12/3/04
  Pours a light brown with a small tan head. Hoppy,malty, with a touch of caramel.

12 oz Bottle (thanks to kramer):  Pours a hazy ambery-orange color with a thin, but stiff and strong yellowish head that dissapates into a nice ring around ( a better head and Id have given appearnece a 5).  The aroma is initaly malty and finishes floral hops.  Some alcohol, fruity citrus, and brown sugar aromas as well.  The flavor is very sweet up front, with an alocoholy almost port finish, yet some how also a bitter hop presense hidden somewhere cehind all that syrupy, creamy sweetness.  Also some caramel, toffee, brown sugar, molassas (more than in the aroma), and flowers (not floral hops, but actual flower petals) flavors.

Not much different about this one over many other barleywines out there. Rather malty base that was balanced out by a strong hoppy presence. The flavor was accented by somewhat of a grapefruit touch, but the mouthfeel was slippery and thick (oily / syrupy). Not my cup of tea, but suprisingly not overhopped.
Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours dark amber with a tan head. Aroma of alcohol, caramel, and citrus. Flavor is smooth, sweet, and caramel. good body, great brew.
looks great when poured.  a bit creamy and very good beer.  It doesnt seem like its over 10% but it is.  a couple bottle will sneak up on you.  Perfect for the style. and great overall!

Dear Victory Brewer, thats quite the luscious barley wine you got there.  Not too sweet while still reminding me that any more than a couple bottles and old Mr. Hyde would appear.  Mighty tasty, my friend.  You did a good job.  Heres a pretzel for you, Mr. Victory Brewer.

Wow, this has some high ratings. What a surprise, it has over 10% alcohol by volume. This beer is good, and its good  for its style. Maybe my bottle was too young, but I think we need a reality check.

The beer poured clear amber with a thin tan fizzy head. The first whiff is an assult of fresh fruity citrus hops, orange and lemon. After recovering, malty notes are dectecable, mainly caramel, oak, and vanilla, which are also present in the flavor profile. The mouthfeel is soft and smooth, carrying fruit beneath bitterness of a magnitude I wasnt expecting. This bitterness lasted long into the finish, forgetting the nice malty underbelly. The alcohol was very noticeable by mid-bottle.

This is a good barleywine, but not the best. I think its a step below the examples from Sierra Nevada, AleSmith, and Stone, which are not as rough around the edges.

From a 12oz. long neck brown bottle with a stamped bottled on date on the front label.

Made a decent appearance, poured a cloudy orange hued amber with a foamy pale tan head that settled into a thin bubbly lacing, minimal amount of sticking, moderate carbonation.

Had a grapefruity and caramel nose with whiffs of butter toffee and alcohol.

A crisp, creamy smooth fullish bodied mouth feel, good sipping drinkability.

Caramel and toasted malts, a sweet grapefruity hoppiness, a warming alcohol presence through out the taste, a light butteriness towards the end and a dryish grapefruity and malty finish.

A nice barley wine from Victory, tasty with a balanced bitterness.

This 1/11/05 bottled brew from Flemdawg poured a small sized head of light tan colored foamy finely sized bubbles that left behind a transparent brown colored body and a poor lacing.  The aroma was malty hoppy vinous.  The mouth feel was vinous and very tingly from start to finish.  The flavor contained vinous malt hop dough notes and was very good.  All-in-all, quite a good beer that gave me the beer shivers!  And, any beer that can do that is a keeper!

Pours very dark in color with an amber hue to it. Low head retention, but this may be typical of the barleywines. Im new to the barleywine style - this is my second one. Very complex flavor that starts surprisingly smooth with a little fruit and not overly sweet. Then it comes on with the sweetness that I believe is synonymous with barleywines, but not overly sweet. This one will keep me trying barley wines for a while and has restored my interest in the style
Dark almost opaque ruby color with a small tan head. Aroma of dark fruits with a little hops. Flavor of dark fruits, heavy malt and a little chocolate and hops.
Robe rouge surmontée dune mousse beige mince qui sestompe. Arômes de fruits rouges, de caramel et dalcool. Saveurs de caramel, de bois, dalcool et de houblon amérisant.
This is one of the best beers ive ever had. I have shied against rating it because i havent known what to say or wanted to get a better taste but one of the top.
Prunes, raisins, malts, alcohol...not the best Barley Wine I have had but still very nice....nice color, nice flavor

Looks alot like cider, as it pours you can see the yeast streaming along with it.  White head disappates quickly (alcohol).  Nice aroma - apples, malt, yeast.  Palate is a bit nutty with sour yeasty bite, malt, with hops in the background.  A most excellent barley wine.  Sip this by the fire.  Oh what balance!

Bottle.  The first word that came to mind after I had a sip was wow!  It is a dark amber beer with a malty taste.  The first sip can take you back.  The 10.5% alcohol was not noticable, which could be a problem if you do not read the label before drinking!    A good, hearty beer but not something I would try during the warmer months.  Cheers
Bottle. Dark ruby color. Nice head, fruity malty aroma, excellent palate. Bold, malty flavor that is balance perfectly, with what taste like English hops. Perfect barleywine.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2007 
First impression: Sweet scents arising from pour. Dark amber color keeps a well maintained head. Looked great under my lamp resting under a coaster. Sweet malt and hop notes thru out the ale. Same character from first to last sip (which is not a bad thing) Very sweet but not to sweet Barley wine. The 10.5 % is not tasted at all and makes this a very drinkable barley wine. I could drink this year round because its not to heavy of a taste. Cheers!

bottle. smuggled home from NYC.  hazy amber pour.  effervecence with tiny caramal  colored tiny bubbled head.  fruity, caramel, malty, hops aroma with strong alcohol presence.  WOW!
