Amazingly smooth.  Nice apricot clean taste.  Sugary malts come later and linger nicely in the aftertaste with a touch of sweet chocolate.  Hints of oak barrel.  This is one hell of a beer.  Victory!

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2008 Bottle courtesy of, and thanks to Philip, the mid-west wonder! Pours murky brown and topped forthwith by a thin ring of brown froth that subsides to a ring. Theres sediment here, though I suspect there is not supposed to be? Vanilla bean aroma with  heavy caramel malt and roasted brown sugar nuances and then add a touch of chocolate. Very sweet caramel flavours, vanilla extract, burnt sugars, and lots of woody/nutty aftertastes. Skooth and silky, and a pleasure to drink, even if it is 20 degrees Celcius outside. Thanks Phil!

Aroma is of dried fruit and alcohol, primarily.  Appearance in my snifter is an unspectacular coudly reddish brown with nearly no head after pouring.  Flavor is plentiful and interesting.  Vanilla, mixed fruits, and a sweet maple taste.  Carbonation is noticeable on the palate and not extremely pleasureable.  Moutfeel is syrupy and unpleasant.  Overall, the flavor is the saving grace of this beer considering the lack of anything spectacular in the other categories.

On tap at Marker 20, Hampton VA: Candy red but dark.  Served a bit too cold.  Strong candied licorice.  Bitter bite.  I loved the bartender: "Have you had it before?" like he wanted to make sure he knew what I was getting into.  Got even better as it warmed up.

A very strong beer, in every sense of the word. Pours a cloudy amber-brown. Palate is wonderful; thick, creamy, and finishes comes on strong. Flavor is reminiscent of dates, as well as some fruit undertones. Fabulous, although not for the faint hearted.

Pours a clear dark red mahogany with an enormous foamy tan head.  The lacing sticks to the glass and clings for dear life.  Tons of fruit flavor.  Aroma is dark fruit, but not overpowering.  As for taste:  I immediately thought cherry vanilla backed by a variety of citrus.  Maybe even hints of chocolate, and certainly maple syrup.  The sweetness is by no means overpowering and is well balanced by hops, which lend to a pleasant bitterness.  Finish is hops with a hint of those fruit candies that come in the round tins (your grandmother probably had them).  Palate is certainly a bit syrupy, and itll stick to your lips a little bit after its done.  A very smooth, small, soft, and gentle carbonation.  Overall this is a very good, very well balanced barleywine.

There is an aroma of floral hops and some malt.  The color is a golden amber with a light golden head and some lacing.  A mild sweetness  at first that grows to a more hoppish flavor.  The bitterness is moderate a grows slightly in the aftertaste.
An enjoyable BarleyWine style. Not too strong. Good choice for a cold winters night.
A perfect example of a good American barley wine.  You get a hint of the 10.5% alcohol, but it certainly does not get in the way of the sweet & malty flavors.  All this with a nice hint of hops.

What an enjoyable beer.  This strong barely wine style beer has a pleasant if almost sappy and stout like initial bouquet.  Once injested, the barely wine qualities of this beer become readily apparent.   It is made for cold winter nights

Bottle  Victory does it again with another great beverage.  Pours a cloudy brown with a creamy tan head.  Very good lacing and mostly lasting.  Very good aroma of light malts and a nice sweet touch.  I get a toasted honey with subtle fruits.  Has a smooth texture with low carbonation.  Has an almost cider like feel in you mouth.  Has a very smooth palate even with the high abv.  A good duration and a solid aftertaste.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2010 December 05 bottle.  This poured with no head.  The color is dark copper, cannot see through the beer.   The aroma is hop heavy, Im thinking similar to SN Bigfoot.  But the taste is great,  awesome, surprising.  The hops are present and very noticeable. Surprisingly smooth for 11%.  The bitterness of the hops is present at the end of the flavor.  The other barely wine flavors are subdued in the alcoholic taste department but the sweetness is there.  The body is lighter than expected for a beer like this.  The palate is a little lacking, with little texture and no essence of the brew felt.  I am enjoying this with a sweet navel orange.  This is a young brew and I have another bottle of the same batch, which I will re-rate in later. 7/4/9/3/18=4.1 Same batch, same six pack, a bit more than a year later.  Bottle was cellared for about 6 months and closet stored (mostly cooler months) for about 6 months.  There is no head and just a bit of lacing.  Aroma is still full of hops, of course not as fresh, citrus and heavy sweet berry.  Richer and deeper malt flavor seem to come out as well, dark fruits, plums.  But also what seems to be DMS is setting, a buttery thick molasses aspect.  Taste is very light still in comparison to this big beer.  Sweet and bitter hop flavor (think bitter slightly brownish strawberries).  Then comes an astringent hop finish.  After a year seems to be going way downhill.  More ratings to follow. 7/3/7/3/15=3.5Same batch, same 6 pack, cellared for most of the time (about 31 months).  Pours  with a large head that fades to a thick, glass sticking, lacing. Aroma is musty fruit and "sitting out too long tea" British maltiness." Taste is lots of English tea with BW-like fruit accents. Well... I am not more impressed than before. 2.5 years old and its just getting worse. Fortunately, it seems the DMS-like aspects have faded and turned into a weird British-tea like aspect. 7/3/7/3/14.  Last bottle from the 6 pack, 4.5 years old.  Old fruity hops, still decent and a tea-like malts.  No sign of oxidation.  All and all decent.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: A good, but not great barleywine.  The sweetness is underbalanced by hops and becomes overwhelming throughout a bottle.    I feel like victory almost tried too hard to make this a calm, relaxing beer and forgot to balance out the malts.  That being said, it is solid and does a good job of hiding the alcohol.  A good beer when placed in the correct context...occassionally enjoyed and in cold weather.

Bottle (bottled on Dec, 04) from my favorite Finnish expatriate jtw - thanks John! To start with aroma, were getting something else than expected: instead of offensive hops dark fruits, rich caramel malts and sugary alcohol dominate the aroma. Im assuming hops have mellowed with age leading to more complex aroma, which isnt bad at all. As the liquid gets warmer, alcohol is getting more evident in the aroma. Flavor continues on the same trails with sugary, fruity sweetness, warming alcohol, wood and hops (not that much though). Beautiful pour is probably the best part of this beer, body in not so huge. Although I have to admit I was expecting more hop-dominated American barley wine (should try it younger I guess) I found the complexity of this beer quite enjoyable and the warming effect comfortable on this cold winter night up here in north. All in all, the best beer so far from the brewery which hasnt quite lived up to my expectations.
Bottle. Dark amber colour with a big beige head. Heavy malty, caramel, hoppy aroma and taste. Medium to full body with a sweet light dry, light alcoholic finish. Great!!!
Amber color with a tan head. Caramel and molasses flavor. High alcohol content, very thick palate.

Hazy amber colour with a light brown head. Malty aroma with a caramel sweetness, a light hoppyness and hints of alcohol. Malty, light burnt, some fruity notes and a nice hoppy, light citric and bitter finish. Thanx to Rene (sk8viking) for sharing this one.

12oz bottle, 2005 vintage.Major thanks to JHop for this one via trade. Pours a clear dark ruby-red with thinnish white head that quickly dissipates and leaves little lacing. Aroma of PNW hops clashing with intensely sweet caramel malt. Flavor confirms what the aroma hints at -- acrid hop bitterness that often results when piney PNW hops are combined with a darker, sweeter malt base. Thankfully its not as bad as in other PNW-hopped barleywines, as the sugary malt is predominant as it should be with this style. Would have liked more fruity elements in the flavor as well. Nice thick mouthfeel and palate. Pretty good as American barleywines go, pretty average for someone who prefers a more traditional English approach.

Bottle courtesy of HogTownHarry. Bottled Dec.04. Pours a very bubbly murky dark amber-orange with a lasting average size off-white head. Fantastic aroma of sweet malt, caramel, lots of floral hops, pine, brown sugar and alcohol -- lots going on there and its very lovely. Delicious flavour follows the aroma -- it isnt as big as some Barley Wines, not as hoppy or boozy, but in a good way -- its really smooth and goes down really easy. Medium to full bodied. A truly wonderful Barley Wine, one of the best in my opinion, and definitely one of my favourites.

Bottle.
Clear orange coloured with an off white head.
Sweet aroma of malts, caramel, pine needles and hops.
Flavour of malts, caramel, hops and pine needles.
UPDATED: DEC 26, 2006 Poured out a dark reddish amber with a large yet quickly dissappearing head.Some fruity aromas as well as hops and malts.Very thick and intense.

Pours amber with an orange glow.  Fruity aroma with pungent caramel malts and cherries.  Slightly carbonated.  Incredible body.  Rich caramel/ molasses flavors layer the palate.  Really complex:  maple syrup, to whiskey, to raisin, to straight alcohol finish.  Intense.

Pours a redish amber color with tan head.  Fruity aromas of pear or cherry.  I cant figure out which.  Some hints of pine as well.  Slightly carbonated, smooth sweet taste.  First tastes of wood then finishes a little bitter.  Well balanced and really good.

"Hmmm ho hum on this one. Typical barleywine. Poured a brown with red edges little head. Aroma was malty with hops coming in stong. Flavor was a little citrusy maltym Mouthfeel was to think for my licking. "

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2006 Thanks to Fantomas for the trade. Bottled Dec. 9, 2005. Clear dark amber/brown. Hissing soda-like tan head quickly disappears into thin air. Looks dangerous. Big floral, resinous hops and a touch of sweet malt and alcohol - aroma. Dark fruits and sweet malt throughout with big hops in the finish, accompanied by subtle alcohol and werthers candy. Aftertaste is hopped werthers. Full, balanced body. Drinks very easy for 11%. Hop presence grows as it warms adding some citrus notes. Would pair nice with a light cigar. Excellent.

Thanks to zathrus13 for this 05 bottle.  Aroma is full of caramel, vinous and chewy with light pine notes.  Beautiful ruby-amber in color with a thin, off-white head.  Warming flavor, rich and sweet, caramel with a large dose of bitter, metallic pine.  The alcohol is very noticeable.  Nice oily mouthfeel and  a full body.  I really didnt care for the mineral, metallic flavors and it seemed a little hot.

The aroma was flowery and malty with a scent of fruits. I was already won over before the first sip. I still havent found a Victory beer to hate. The first thing I noticed was the alcohol which doesnt seem hidden IMHO. But after a few sips, I detected apple caramel malts, honey-like sweetness, a great balance of hops and a nice warming sensation. Ill take hops in a barleywine any day.

Deep hazy honey pour with a light brown head. Excessively caramel aroma, with some honey thown in somewhere. The favor is full of caramely malt, some apple,and some hops..super sweet...but theres some good acidic and hoppy flavors (though subdued) to give the flavor balance from being just pure sugar sweetness. Malty on the tounge is an understatement, this beer IS malty, with some sugary sour/bitter notes in the end...this beer tastes like Chistmas brews should...warming and full of hidden alcohol. Great stuff!

fuck this beer
it tastes great for an ipa or pale ale but it doesnt really taste like a barley wine. so easy on the hops. i love hops just not in my barley wine. nigga

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2007 Rerate:  I believe I rated this rather early in my rating career.  So I figured Id give it a second look.  Clear pretty red body with a ring of head hovering above.  Aroma is pretty darn complex.  Caramel, spice, hops, plums, raisin.  Taste is heavy on the caramel malts, almost like a tootsie roll.  One drawback may be the fact that there is a slight alcoholic bite, but that can be overlooked.  Still is a top notch barley wine.  The reasons I wanted to revisit this beer are twofold.  One, to see if this holds up against other top of the line barley wines, which it does, IMO.  Two, to see if Victory in general has lost its edge, which is commonly stated in the beer world.  Obviously, I dont think it has.  I may enjoy Old Ruffian or Third Coast Ale more than this, but this beer is still very solid.

Original Rating: Bottle.  Imagine a long cold winter night, perched in front of the fireplace.  Snow gently falling outside while a cold winter breeze gives the air a chill.  Now imagine a complex fruity, caramelly, severely hopped beer being sipped in full enjoyment.  There you have Victory Old Horizontal!  So well crafted, it just sits there and warms your body.  The only glaring negative on the beer is that the higher alcohol is not all that well hidden.  I dont mind; just couldnt put down a lot of these, but then again, thats not necessarily the point.  Its more for enjoying each and every sip!  Aroma 9 - Appearance 5 - Flavor 10 - Palate 4 - Overall 18 - Total 4.6

Poured from a 12oz bottle a cloudy brown with a tan head. Aroma was caramel malts with a touch of dark fruits (figs or prunes). Flavor was sweet malts with a hint of bitterness. This had a very nice scotch type warming down to the belly, a nice sipping beer.

As far as Im concerned this is like the little brother to Bigfoot.  Not that theres anything wrong with it, but Im confused as to why it is rated a good bit higher.  The flavors are a balance of rich caramel malt and fruity, floral hops.  The malt carries a small amount of fig and prune along with it.  Assertive, but not aggressive bitterness in the end to clean it all out and get you ready to start over again.  Nice clean, smooth palate.  rich and complete mouthfeel, but not heavy or full.  This is nothing other than a very good beer.  Victory really will not let you down.

Pour is a murkey brown with a small tan head.  Aroma is strong caramel matls with a nice earthy hop backbone.  Flavor is earthy and fruity with lots of peat-smoke bitterness.  Alcohol is there but not a problem.  Prob one of the best barleywines i have ever had.  Yes it is as good as the hype.
UPDATED: MAR 6, 2006 Great cascade of carbonation when poured.  Nice redish orange body.  Awesome barley taste, caramel and malts dominate. Bitter ending, very nice.

From Bottle; bottled on December 22, 2005

Poured cloudy amberish. Bubbly off-white head, that lasted on the edge of the glass throughout. Nice lacing. Aroma piney, malty, fruity, and hoppy. Flavor woodsy, with caramel and citrus notes, sweet lingering aftertaste. Mild hop bite, with a slight bitterness in the middle. Nice malty backbone. Alcohol well hidden, but with a noticable (not in a bad way) alcohol warming in my belly. Very complex beer, with the flavors meshing well. Good beer for a cold night.

Murky tawny color with a cream-colored head that dissipated fairly quickly. Aroma is very malty, pretty hoppy, and almost a bit dusty too. Flavors are rich and mighty. Very hoppy and very malty. This is a good example of the extra hoppy style of barleywine that I like (I love both the American and European styles, dont get me wrong!). Finish is pretty hoppy too, with still quite a bit of a mouth coating thickness from this beer. A bit of a metallic taste too. Hmm... I do like this beer a lot. Im not sure its top of my list, well, Im sure its not, but its really really good. Id gladly drink this again. Thanks to JHop for the trade.
Aroma is strong, sweet, and fruity.  Thick and cloudy appearance, cider like.  The hops come through in the flavor, creamy and sweet.  Complex beer, very enjoyable.

Old Horizontal. Thats what your gonna be if your not careful.This  is the most appealing Barleywine that I have had to date. Great tasting,  smooth (which to me does not  go w/  barleywine)solid brew. If you have never had a barleywine start with this one. Nice antique coffee finish. Remember shes 11%. Dont put yourself in the hurt box.

(02.09.06) 12 oz brown bottle purchased from DiCarlos, Libertyville, IL.  Bottled on 12/09/05.  11% ABV. Clear red hued ale having a small white head. Soft carbonation. Caramel and alcohol aromas.  Full bodied ale with light malt sweetness and caramel flavors.  Finishes with light malt sweetness and light lingering hop bitterness.  Smooth, creamy and rich.  Definite alcoholic warmth.  A luscious barleywine. Highly recommended after a meal as dessert or as a night cap.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2006 12 oz bottle.   Beautiful looking beer.  Deep ruby red with a small, quickly dissipating white head.  Slightly sweet aroma reminiscent of caramel and cognac.  Flavor is surprisingly hoppy (or not surprisingly, knowing Victory) with notes of caramel sweetness and and finishing alcohol burn.  Palate was not quite as silky as I would have liked.  A very nice beer.
Pours brown and almost still.  Smells of hops and tea.  Tastes caramelly with nice hoppy undertones.

I dont see what is so special about this one. Granted the batch I had was the newest one, this just felt rough around the edges. The alcohol was a little to strong for me, and really seemed to over power everything else. Just not what I expected from something in the top 50.

I found a dusty 2004 bottle at my local liquor store.  12oz bottle poured into a snifter. Appearance was a hazy red/amber color w/ a fully diminishing head.  Aroma of citrus hops, with roasted malt.  Flavor of caramel, toffee,  fruit and citrus hops.  Warm lingering aftertaste. Pretty good barley wine, would like to try some again.

Frankly, I have tired of being a ratings whore...Im tired of drinking middle of the road drek only because I need the rating to stay ahead of the  notoriously devious Frankenkitty in our quest for 1000!   So I went deep into my cellar and opened a 1 year old bottle of Old Horizontal, let it warm slightly, and sipped for an hour of pure unadulterated pleasure...
Syrupy texture, somewhat cloying and vinous...intensely sweet with dried fruits, caramel, toffee, weird spices, and roasted malt.   Enormous grapefruit and pine resin hoppiness lingering in the finish...along with an ever so welcome alcohol signature, most notable in the peppery throat warming...bringing with it a  welcome sense of contentment, inner peace, and  unfeigned forgiveness...oh, and by the way...Frankenkitty,  thou Spawn of Cthulhu, you shall never catch me...

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2013 Rerate from a 2003 bottle at the Richmond Beer Industry Gathering 2006. Frothy tan head on a cloudy dark amber color. Aroma of caramel and molassas with some strong floral hops. Sweet caramel flavor blending with a floral hop background. 

Original Rating: 8/4/9/4/17Growler from Whole Foods on 02/06/2011, 2006 vintage. 
Slightly hazy copper body with a small off white head
Sweet fruit caramel and molasses aroma
Sweet fruit flavor light caramel and spicy hints
Medium full body mod carb 8/4/8/4/16
Pours with a small light brown head on a cloudy brown body. Hoppy malty aroma. Strong hoppy taste with a sweet fruity aftertaste.
Wow really good stuff.  A tad of hops.  But mostly a sweet flavor.  Seems like a caramel/fruity flavor.  Body is kinda creamy,  very good stuff.
Bottle.  Wow, this one has it al.. Great malty sweetness balanced by hop bitterness.  Great alcohol backbone but not overpowering.  Im tired of this style, but I really like this beer.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2006 this bottledec 09 05. OK well i didnt like this one once and another time i loved it... this time i think it is barky and rough a little bitter hop... it is tottal hop aftertaste bitterness. smells sweet and malty, taste the maltyness but the bitterness just bites it the fuck out. aged to be better needs time still that bitterness need to mellow the fuck out

12oz bottle- Wow what a beer. Just bought a 6 pack for $11.99 and feel like going back for more. This beer has an excellent hop malt balance that would only get better with age. I taste a citrus  flavor maybe grapefruit in the middle. The beer starts out sweet but finishes with more of an alcohol flavor. Very drinkable for 10%+. I need to get back to the liqour store before it is to late.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2006 Rerate of a Jan 2001 bottle consumed May 2006. Wow, this entire time I thought it was another 2004. Wow though. Poured the same body, maybe a few more floaties. Nose was just divine though. The grapefruity aroma was still there, but almost brought out a vanillalike (perhaps an evolution of the citrus?) nose. I wanted to fall in the glass. The smooth caramel malts were there too. The flavor was the same, and at 11% was DANGEROUSLY drinkable. Best balance Ive seen for a BW. The hops were there, and very tasty, but not overbearing. Same deal with the malts. Huge flavor profile yet very drinkable. A treat I may never again experience, especially since it looks like the newer vintages suck compared to the older ones. I have never had a new one..

Bottled Dec 14, 2004. Orangish brown body with a small head. Huge, rich hoppy aroma. Pine, grapefruit, citrus, its all here. Also notes of caramel as well. Flavor is the same, huge and complex. I think my favorite American Style Barley Wine to date. Reminded me of a better version of Avery. 8/4/8/4/17

A little bit of a disappointment following a lenghty quest to acquire this one.  Aromas is of apple, caramel, malt and light spice.  Appearance is brown with tawny red highlights.  Flavor is apple with sweet caramel flavored malts and a cider pucker that overpowers a bit at the end.  Carbonation is a bit higher than expected and a little obnoxious.  Slight viscosity overcome by carbonation.  This would be much better without astringent pucker that detracts from overall enjoyment.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Shared this bottle, which was bottled on 1/11/05, with thedm and hotstuff.  A reddish gold body with a tannish head that left some good lacing and some yeasty floaties in there for good measure.  The aroma was hoppy with some fruity malts and a bit of woody in there too.  The taste revealed hops, caramel, a bit of woodinedss combined with a bit of  nuttiness.  Tasty.

Wonderful stuff and a great bargain.  This holds up well for years.  reddish copper pour with a small white head.  Great lacing.  Malty,fruity and juicy nose with wisper of hops.  Everything is in harmony.  Flavor is outstanding.  Thick, warming and not too sweet.  Lots of caramel.  Maybe the best barley wine.

bottle. says it was bottled on Dec. 11, 2005. pours a thick and suductive plum coloured syrup with a small white lacing. nose is of malt, fruit, and a little hops. flavor has a nice malty presence that is not overwhelming with a nice hop bite. yummy. some say this is too syrupy but i think the balance is just perfect for a barleywine. not overly sweet and not overly hopped like some american versions. would like to try a more vintage version, but from what i can discern this is a wonderful example of the style.

Pours hazy auburn with off-white head.  Very caramelly nose, sweet, slightly roasty.  Flavor is overpowering, thick, like drinking plum puree.  Very complex, but very dense. Some bitterness and orange peel on the finish.  This beer was just too thick and syrupy for my tastes, maybe Ill save a couple bottles for a couple months to see if they mellow a bit and become a little less overwhelming.

12 oz. with a 11-21-03 bottling date. Pours a light orange hue with a nice looking off white head. Standard barleywine smell of sweet malts and alcohols. Has a rich, creamy mouthfeel. Taste is caramely sweet with raisons and vanilla. Finishes smooth and dry, the alcohol is nicely camoflaged.
A very easy drinking Barleywine
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: UPDATED: APR 11, 2007 [bottle] Dark, mahogany color.. short tan head fizzes away quickly, leaving a nice ring.  Huge aroma of fruits and some hops. Flavors are rich, complex and very smooth. Impressive hop finish lingers for quite a while. This is excellent.

Bottle 2004 vintage poured a hazy orange copper with a small, diminishing amber head. Aromas of plum, apple and brown sugar. Palate was medium bodied. Flavors of bread with a little fruitiness and a warming bitter finish. Hides its alcohol very well!

Old Horizontal Barleywine pours to a beautiful, deep garnet color with a slight tan head, and a soft carbonation. The nose is just jam packed with aromas. Peppery waves of alcoholic strength marry with aromas of sweet malt, fresh bread, plum, toffee, and a nice back drop of piney hop aroma. The palate is hefty and lush on the tongue. Big flavors of sweet malt, fresh bread, toffee, and vanilla coat the tongue. Old Horizontal finishes with more big malty flavors up front, then ends with a long, soothing, warming burn. 

This is one of the most impressive barleywines on the market today, and it will continue to improve with age. Barleywine gets its name because it approaches the alcohol strength of wine, and Old Horizontal comes in at about 11-12% abv. This is the type of brew that you want to sip and savor, and it makes a perfect night cap. More suited for winter(it is released in December), but great anytime you want to relax and enjoy a soothing brew. Try one just before you go to bed while unwinding reading a book or watching a little television.

a good beer overall, but wish i would have held on to this bottle for a while rather than drinking it fresh...pours dark reddish brown with little head....aroma is quite hoppy with minimal malty undertones (some spices and  sugar present)...flavor was quite the same, and was a tad hoppy for a barley...some caramels and sugars, but nothing too complex....perfect palate once warmed....ill get another bottle and try it again down the road
Excellent beer, very strong. Great dark red color with little to no head. Aroma is alcohol and hops. Flavor is very hoppy, with a bit of sweet caramel malt and a nice palate cleaning alcohol finish.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2007 02/15/07 Aged one year.  Poured into a Maudite snifter.  Tan pancake head with excellent retention leaves creme brulee lacing.  Caramel aromas.  Smooth and creamy with a slight metallic hop finish which detracts slightly. Sticky.  Aroma and overall rating have slipped a point...

01/21/06.  Poured into a St. Bernardus snifter.  Quickly dissipating head.  Deep magenta.  Thick.  Sweet and malty.  Long, bitter hop and alcohol finish.  Will age a bottle to see if it can balance out. 8/4/7/4/17 = 4.
Just wonderful. Barleywine that comes in a six. Another excellent brew from Victory.

Bottle.  Whoa-hop alcohol dark fruit nose.  Smells sweetish and traditional barleywinish.  Taste is full of dark fruit, malt, a mix of light sweet and light bitter, full bodied, that alcohol wallop doesnt mess up the flavor, its barely noticable.  The hoppiness of this barleywine imparts a nice zinginess to the fruits and malt.  Its mahogany brown with a few bubbles on the edge of the snifter.  Good stuff.  I think Ill age a couple bottles too, though itll probably lose its nice hoppiness, Im just too curious.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2006 Pours dark crimson with a fully receding tan head. Aroma of vinous malt, sweet caramel, with a strong note of alcohol. 
Taste is sweet, malty, resinous, hoppy, fruity, all of the above. Almost too much of everything at this point. Give this a few years though and I’ll be in love. Mouthfeel is heavy, syrupy with very little carbonation. This rating reflects a young sample of this brew. When the opportunity arises I will rerate a vintage sample. You can drink Old Horizontal fresh, but I don’t recommend it.

Bottle: Think maybe my bottle was old or had some oxidation. Not exactally a barleywine style to the books, but decent none the less. Big hop nose, which was a surprise, small creamy head dissipated quickly. Fruity, malty beginning with hoppy finish, not much complexity. Okay

This is great stuff.  Huge, floral hop fragrance.  Substantial, sticky-sweet mouthfeel.  So yummy I tend to down them rather quickly.
Hmm...is that a problem?  No!  Quite enjoyable.
This is a beer to have when you want more than one of something strong and warming.  Hell, cellar a case and enjoy them at the beach this summer.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2006 This beer has a wonderfully sweet malty and also  hoppy aroma, beer is copper colored and cloudy, the flavor is extreamly hoppy and malty, but a good balance. the palate is full.  Finishes bitter and warming

vintage 2004: Aged well, the aroma was of alcohol and of sweet malt, tasted more citrusy and biscuity, quite robust, the body seemed to be thicker than I remember, but it was right on.  This is a great barley wine

Pours a clear amber color with a small head and bubbly and slighty sticking lacing.  Aroma is warm and slightly malty with a nose that kind of reminds me of banana nut bread.  Flavor is very good, kind of thick and malty with nut and banana/fruit undertones.  It kind of coats the tongue but sure as hell makes me want a piece of fresh banana nut bread.

Bottle (12oz).  Acquired via trade with MullMan.  Poured cloudy mahogany with a decent sized lasting creamy-rocky tan head.  Nice aroma of oaky malt, alcohol, plenty of rich, fresh, resiny hops, pine duff, almost a hint of paint thinner.  Flavour is an insistent medley of sweet nutty malt, deep resiny hops, warming boozy alcohol, citrus juice, chinese gunpowder tea (dry, bitter, herbal) - starts almost sweet, then the alcohol and hops take off and carry this to a long, bitter, fruity finish. Mouthfeel is juicy, astringent, quite full-bodied for the style.  A solid barley wine, maybe could age for even greater smoothness, but right up there .. as tupalev notes, perhaps it could be a little more complex, but nevertheless I liked it a lot.  So did my wife.

Bottle, thank you Hogtown Harry.  Golden dark brown, foamy off white head.  Sweet deep dark malt, alcohol , and some hops in nice aroma.  Very nice sharp hop sweet taste.  Some dark herbal tea notes in flavour as well.  Medium mouthfeel.  Long lingering hops and alcohol.  Very easy to drink for a barleywine.  Very flavourful.  Lacked a little complexity.  An excellent Barleywine.

Bottled on 1-11--05. Rated at small rating session at flemdawgs in Naples, FL. Thanks for sharing, Jim! Small tan head that mostly diminished, few floaties, sparse lacing, no visible carbonation, cloudy, and an orange brown hue. Aroma was hoppy, sweet, rich and fruity. Flavor was hoppy and vinuous. Tingly, hoppy mouthfeel. Medium body.

Pours medium copper with some chunks of yeast and medium tan, dissipating, ringing head.  Aroma is sweet grass, barley, light citrus hop.  Full flavor is sweet and grassy, malt with alcohol character and lots of hop.  Palate is smooth and creamy and coats the mouth.  Very nice beer that I just cant put down.  1 year old and well balanced.  I need more of this.

Perfect!  The hops and fruity flavor danced around the cup on a thin layer of satin silky lingerie as the alcohol slapped me lightly across my face for lingering too long.  Forgiven, my tongue was fully and utterly satiated and left longing as the single bottle purchased was drained of life left lonely until I I dare secure another seductive and flawless brew.

Got this one in a bar in pennsylvania off tap.  Had a large head at first i think mainly due to the bartender but it quickly diminished.  Murky copper brown body with some reds in there.  Great Barleywine was smooth and the taste held its own against the 10% alcohol.

12oz - Bottled 12/14/04 - Happy birthday to me! - (thanks Jeffin7) Aroma is full of carmel.  Hops, leather, oak, and a touch of dark fruit.  Pours a deep carmel color with a little head and great lacing.  Flavor matches aroma with a bit more alcohol.  Still "toasty" after a year in the cellar.  Palate is sticky and tart, but clean.  First one ever.  Need to try a freshy and one aged longer to figure out my perfect Old Ho.

12-oz. bottle via trade with kramer17801, bottled 02.04.05.  Pours cloudy, murky copppery maple dark brown with a small foamy tan head and creamy lacing.  Fruity fragrant hop aroma to greet and awaken your sense of smell, followed by some sweet medium roasted caramel, maple malt and then finishes up with a perfumey, fusel alcohol nose.  Heavily bitter and acidic fruity, perfumey hop flavor, maple and nutty caramel malt body with some yeast notes.  Medium to full bodied, fizzy and tingling mouthfeel.

Pours a dark brown color with a small head. Aroma is malty and chocolaty. The flavor follows suits. there is bitterness from some hops but most of the flavor is roasted malts. very tasty. Certainly a barely wine Ill be drinking more often!

Bottled 12/14/04.  Bought a case of this last year and I wish I would have kept more of them around.  At almost a year old this has really balanced out and blended nicely, yet the hops have stuck around.  Pours a slightly hazy orange/mahogany/copper with a nicely sustaining/lacing head.  Aroma of dark fruits, caramel, malts, vanilla, cherry and some light hops (grapefruit/pine).  Flavor was along the same lines, just slightly stepped up with more of the hops coming through in the taste.  The alcohol is well hidden.  An overall sweetness to both the aroma and flavor. I think this year Ill pick up another case...maybe two and let a bunch of it sit around for a while.
glowing orange in color.  aroma of citrus, mint, apple, molasses, carmel, and cherry licorice.  thick but sort of oily.  very sweet.  one of the better BWs Ive had.  good work.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2005 rerate - Bottled Feb. 4th 2005. Citrus hops dominate the nose.  Plum comes to mind. Alcohol.   Id say its still a little hot on the tongue, but it does mellow out a bit as it warms.  Reasonably soft mouthfeel.  Has some body to it.  The sweet malt makes a showing, but is outlasted by the hops.  Nice brew.  Ton of hops.


Courtesy of Kramer ~~~ Bottled Feb. 4th 2005.  Beautiful, deep amber color and off white head.  Sweet citrus on the nose.  Wonderful mouthfeel.  Soft and thick.  Sweet malt followed by a soft yet very noticeable grapefruit bitterness.  Quite hoppy and quite delicious. No shortage of sweet malts here either.8.5.9.5.18

Loads of sweet candy like malts in the aroma, lots of caramel, some maple syrup, sweet liquor, a nice spicy, earthy and quite dusty hoppyness to balance out the massive sweetness. Dark crimson body with a creamy and fat off-white head. Flavor starts out with a massive chewy maltyness, lots of caramel, good sweetness with some various fruits, oranges, grapes and plums. Light bitterness in the end to balance it all out, leaves the mouth a little dry. A nice touch of alcohol.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2006 RERATED 2-14-06 Bottle. Pours mahogany with nice off white head. Sweet caramel and perfumy aroma, with some alcohol. Strong caramel and nutty malt profile is the backbone to a predominately spicy and bitter hoppiness. Slighltly watery mouthfeel for this style. Finishes bitter, hot, and peppery. I think this one needs more time in the cellar. Overall a decent barleywine, but there are better examples out there. This one just fell out of my top ten list.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2007 200th rating.  Bottled on Dec 3, 04.  Received courtesy of csbosox.  Maple is the overriding aroma.  Spicey/earthy hops are along for the ride.  I kind of screwed up pouring this and got the slurry from the bottom of the bottle.  Not real worries though.  This baby showcases a creamy off white head that shows no real signs of going away.  Firey oranges, reds and browns.  Inviting.  Warming, but not the least bit harsh.  Maple, pine, the typical caramel and toffee that we all love oh so much.  Silky smooth all the way down.  Pleasantly bitter.  Thanks again Chris.

Bottled Nov 16, 2002.  This has held up very well for the last three years. Dark red with very small pieces of sedimen.  Thin layer of foam on the glass.  The aroma reminded me of Full Sail Boardhead, only because I had that first.  There is  apple, brown sugar, maple syrup, malt, and flowers in the complex aroma. Several flavors and all are good. The first is very sweet fruit, followed by sweet malt.  Next is bitter hops and salt.  Aftertaste is of light bitter hops combined with lingering sweet fruit as if it were a high quality IPA. Very thick and heavy, but also soft and smooth except for the light alcohol bite.  I havnt had this fresh, but it aged very well.

deep mohagany in color small white head, a rich aroma had a mix of sherry notes, hops and some sweet malts.   Initianl flavor had A mild fruit note with some sweet caramel notes a nicly hopped finish complememnted its warming alcohol presecnce.

Bottle poured a dark caramel with a decent head that burned off to a light skim.
Aroma is sweet malt, overly ripe fruits and light alcohol.
Flavor is sweet, caramel and dark fruits with a sweet alcohol finish.

Wow!  What a beer!  True to its labeling, this beer pours very rich and luminous, not just from reflection off the glass, but from an inner vibration, doesnt make much sense, but I know it was good.  Flavorful, very flavorful...taste a little bit of everything in there, although still light in texture.  A wonderful barleywine just in time for the cold weather.

Bottled.  Dated 2/4/04.  Via trade w/kramer17801. Mahogany in color with a sizable ivory head that fades eventually into heavy lacing.  Sugary nose with some pretty up-front hop aromas.  Another one to sniff for a bit.  Slightly spicy with some fruit and pine aromas.  So thick it coats your mouth.  A ton of flavors make up the taste.  Coffee, cocoa, caramel, raspberries, molasses, and toffee.  Big Hoppy bite towards the end.  Nice alcohol warmth.

12 oz bottle, Feb 04 vintage.  Pours a slightly cloudy tawny color with a nice creamy and thick 1/2 inch head.  Resiny hop arome with accents of toffee, caramel, and some alcohol.  Deep toffee flavor, well balanced with significant hop bitterness.  Alcohol makes itself know but not overpowering in any way.  I get alot of iced tea flavor in the long bitter finish.  Thick and chewy mouthfeel with a mouth coating goodness.  Very soft carbonation.  This is a really good American Style Barleywine.  Nicely balanced, hops really cut thru the huge malt bill that could easily have become overly sweet.  A personal favorite of mine.
Paid $2.50 for a 12-oz bottle. Pours ruby-amber with a small tan head. Light, sweet maltiness in the nose. Tasty malty and dark fruts. Not one of the greatest beers of all time, IMO, but its good.

Bottled Feb. 4, 2005.  Pour was an eerie, cloudy shade of orangish-amber with a tall and creamy beige head.  Looked quite nice as the head was about as tall as the liquid.. and it filled my large snifter to capacity.  Extra-fine sediment suspended in there, and intricate lacing followed the liquid down.  Nose picked up adult Christmas candy (move over eggnog)... deep and seductive caramel and molasses sweetness, holiday spices, citrus and darker fruits, and a wonderful floral hop presence... and albeit not explicit, you know theres a solid dose of alcohol lurking beneath your nose.  Somehow, the magnificent interplay of flavors outshined the aroma.  I dont know how it happened, but damn was this good!  Sugarplums, oranges, and grapefruit in there tasted like they were personally squeezed/stomped by a magical beer elf just for me.  Caramel and molasses provided a fantastic medium backbone, with just the right amount of sweetness.  Noble hoppage gave the brew a perfect floral/earthy quality, and was present from first whiff through four minutes after the finish.  Alcohol was there, but only to give the flavor some extra zest, to impart some throat- and belly-warming-ness, and to make me feel quite fine when I had laid this most excellent brew to rest.  Get some!

Bottled Feb 04, 2005, listed as 11%.  The beer pours to a thick beige creamy head.  Clear amber/brown body with visible carbonation.  Excellent lacing.  The aroma is very hoppy.  Citrus and malts.  Maris Otter malts?  The flavor is a nice malt.  Also Maris Otter?  Nice zesty citrus hops and oranges.  Spices.  The palate is creamy, the 11% is hidden well, medium body.  Nice feel.  This is a really good barleywine.  Very recommended.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2006 My 1000th beer rated. Dark amber in color with a limited yellow head. Has a big mouthfeel. In fact, its quite tingly to the tongue. Almost an extracting quality that a chelating detergent might have. MOPS buffer I would say, not that you should ever taste MOPS buffer, mind you. The finishing bitterness is discernable after the first bolus of flavor is long a memory. UPDATE: In the bottle at my 2006 Barleywine tasting. 2005 vintage. Has improved with aging. Flavors are pronounced maltiness, without the unbalanced harsh bitterness. This has a crisp finish to such a complex bolus of flavors. Much better with aging.
Ive had two bottles from the same six-pack on consecutive days.  One poured dark and clear, the other dark and cloudy.  Both were pleasantly sweet and mildly hopped.  Nice, but I prefer Bigfoot.

Pours dark brown with orange and maroon around the edges and a simple creamy tan head.  The aroma is malty and well hopped.  Strong hop put it in nice balance with a sweet malt.  Sweet carmel malts have a full flavor and are closely followed by sharp pine intense hops.  A warmer beer brings a malt sweetness.  Mild, very smooth, toasted malts.  Smooth sweet finish.

12 oz bottle from 12/14/04.  Man This is a good Barley Wine.  Brown pour with a head that foamed and left.  Aromas of molassas, dark fruit, and other super rich maltinesses.  Flavors were the same with a great balance in hops to finish it off.  Alcohol was masked well.  Delcious Stuff.  Thanks SuIIy for this bottle.
Nothing to write home about. Generally, I dont like these syrupy monsters...too sweet and too high in alcohol.
[bottle at LCRBM] sherry notes, lots of malt, molasses, citrus hops. full bodied vinous note long finish.

Bottled Dec. 29, 2004. Pours a cloudy burnt orange. Tan, thin, quickly disappearing head. Nose is sweetly hoppy with a light caramel and citrus quality. Initial alcohol burn is replaced by a warm sweetness, somewhat like brandied oranges. Traces of winter spices show as it warms. Suprisingly clean, crisp finish for a heavier beer. SO easy drinking! Be careful, all that alcohol will sneak up on you! An excellent barley wine. A Victory indeed!

No#34. I think this may have been a few years old but i didnt see the bottle. Aroma is of a fullbodied woody barley wine. Taste is Seriously oaked, theres a good bit of sweetness too, however a dry finish. Paulines second fav beer from the tasting so thanks to whoever brought that one.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2008 Dec 14, 2004 bottle.  Pours murky brown with large chunks of yeast and a thin, fully diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is citrus hops and caramel. Flavor is initially resinous pine hops, this gives way to spice, caramel, toffee, and dark fruit. Finish is long and fruity with warming alcohol and a bitter finish. Medium/full body. Texture is smooth with soft carbonation.

LCRBM. 2002-version. Dark beer with diminishing head. Sweet, fruity and spicy aroma. Very sweet taste, agains picy, like speculaas (a bit cinnamon-like). Heavy beer with an alcoholic finish. Better suitable for the winter then a warm octoberday in Antwerp.

Bottle at the RBG Low Countries 2005  tasting session  Amber to black, muddy body.  Fully, diminishing head.  No lace.  Nose of molasses, straw, flowers, liquor, ... Heavly sweet initial flavour.  Moderately sweet long intense finish. Quite good balanced.  Very fully bodied and a little bit astringent.  Lively carbonation.  A little bit to alcoholic and intense for me, but yeah, thats what barley wines supposed to be, arent they?

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2007 Bottled on date of Feb 04 05.

Pours a hazy dark copper with a frothy two finger head that settles very slowly to a thick cap that never really fades, leaving behind a dense webbing of lace.

Smell; a little bit sweet with brown sugar, caramel and toffee. Theres some dark cherries, a touch of candied apples, with a sprinkling of cocoa.

Taste; initially fruity, with cherries and apples, and then is followed by the caramel, brown sugar and cocoa. Theres definitely some hop bitterness, and a little bit of alcohol flavor present. With this being about a year and a half old the hops are a bit more toned down, and the alcohol is not quite as strong in the flavor profile as the fresh ones Ive had before. I think this makes for a much smoother and blended flavor. Mouthfeel is nice and thick, with a good drinkability that would be higher if the abv were not so high.

I dont usually re-review beers, but I previously had a much younger version of this, and I felt with the age of this beer, and its effects it had on its flavor and appearance, it was warranted.

old scores
8
4
8
4
18
4.2

Pours a hazy ruby/brown with almost no head and very thin lacing.

Smell is dark cherries, malt, caramelized sugar with a solid hop presence.

Taste is initially bitter hops, followed by sweet malts and finishes slightly fruity and caramel with just a touch of alcohol.

I really liked this Barleywine. Wish I had more of this for the winter.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: Great slight hazy reddish-amber color with warm orange glow. The froth is very creamy and has a suptile color of yellow-beige with an orange shine. The aroma is at first very hoppy with herbal and citrus like accents. The nose is complex and changes all the times. From refreshing herbs to caramelized sugars over cognac like accents. It is spicey, tropical woody, has hints of agorn, carribian brown rhum, nutmeg, massis banda, cinnamon and loads of sweet barley. Tha taste is also complex, rich and very elegant. It is dried fruitish, sweet refreshing and nobel bitter. The stong point is the balance. Every component is present but non of them are dominant. the great barley wine leaves a great afthertaste that lingers on and on. A Big Thanks Philip (pdhabel) for this fine beer.

Solidly delicious, this one explodes out with a strong hop presence with deep fruity flavors, but is balanced well with heavy-handed maltiness.  This is a big beer, but you can hardly tell, it goes down so easy.  Perfect for winter nights, you cant go wrong with this one.

"Luxirious" is the perfect description for this beer. Aroma is hoppy, roasty, very nice, with a little coffee and malt. Pour has a beautiful, thick head and a nice burnt orange color. On taste you get a really warming, perfect barley-wine like malt fullness followed up with very pleasant hop bitterness. So thick and creamy in the mouth... palate is absolutely perfect.

Love the name!  Have had to have msic. times to rate.  A very solidly crafted barley wine with a complexity of overtones - a balanced hop aroma, some unique fruitiness with steadfast maltiness of taste and flavor.  Want to give more props yet for me the prevalence of the alcohol finish detracts somewhat from an otherwise fine brew.

Pours a hazy brownish-orange with a thin tan head. Lacy. Smells of citrusy hops and rich nutty malt.

Taste is malty first then very hoppy. Caramel, smoke, and big citrusy hops. Grapefruit. Rich malty finish. Big beer, very full bodied and very balanced. Yummy. One of my new favortie barleywines.
i know im rating low on this but once again, not a barley wine fan.  copper color, slight alcohol burn.  spicy but smooth with an oak taste

Courtesy of Slob. Intense malty aroma with hints of fruit, licorice and caramel. Cloudy reddish brown color...large head for a BW. Has an almost citrus lollipop flavor...typical BW feel, but the flavor profile is much hoppier and more citrus-sweet than malt/candy sweet.
Pours deep red with a small off-white head. Aromas of raisiny, bready malts and light floral hops. Very smoothmalty flavor at the beginning, hop bitterness in the finish. No sign of alcohol.

Tried to find something a little special for #400. big fruit malt aroma, almost like a Belgian but hoppier, big swish of rich malt and friut in the taste with a hoppy bitter backbite. Wonderful sipper. glad to hear Victory will soon be available in Milwaukee and I wont have to depend on FedEx to get me fresh beer
Bottle.  Beautiful brown pour.  Translucent with a thin white lace head.  Spicy aroma.  A very crisp taste of hops up front.  The finish is long and lasting.

2004 Vintage. Frankly, Im surprised to see this barleywine being awarded such a high place, when I find Thomas Hardys and J.W. Lees to be much more appealing. In the color and somewhat in the nose, this is a barleywine. On the palate, the hops hit you like a IIPA. Theres some of the stereotypical caramel and toffee notes, but absent is the malt backbone to offset the hops. Im not bothered by the alcohol, but the hops I found excessive. Having said that, I recall enjoying my last 2002 bottle seemingly more back in April (before I rated on RB), so perhaps this just needs time to balance.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2005 Bottle. Pours an amber color w/ light tan head. Some hazyness and light sediment. Nose is light caramel, but something very sweet and almost fruity is hidden in here, some sort of berry. Taste is very bready, doughy and malty. SOme light fruit apparent here as well.
The balance on this beer is what impressed me the most, nothard to drink.  Complex flavors hide the alcohol well when chilled.  Nice hopping.
a very good victory beer.  high alcohol content and a nice copper color.  one of my favorite barley wines.  i have gotten cases of old horizontal just to get drunk off of.

Pours an amber copper color with a thin cream colored head.  Smells of sweet molasses,dark fruit, and hops.  Taste is sweet,quite warm with alcohol noticeable after sipping, and quite hoppy.  Excellent barley wine, yet very strong !!

12 oz bottle dated Jan 6, 2001.  Pours a deep copper red with a creamy whitish tan head that retains well.  Theres lots of yeast at the bottom of the bottle.

The aroma is sweet and spicy caramel and molasses, and some figs with a touch of alcohol.

The flavor is similar to the nose - spicy and sweet caramel with some citric hops and dark fruits.  Some hop bitterness comes out in the finish.  Normally I dont care for noticable alcohol, but this has a strong but surprisingly pleasant alcohol warming.  The mouthfeel is full bodied and very smooth and creamy.

Overall, an excellent barleywine - the best Ive had to date.  Very well made and superbly balanced.  A real treat to drink!  Ill have to try this fresh sometime as Im sure it is much hoppier.  Thanks Probiere!

Bottle.  Numerous tastings, latest was a 1998 Old Ho.  Dark ruby brown pour.  Huge caramelly fruity aroma.  Fresher Old Hos had more fruit, while the 98 was much more earthy.  Candied fruits and sweet caramel malt flavors, some (but not much) hops.  Wowzer, good beer.

Bottle.  Dark and red with a great frothy head.  Aroma is the best part of this one.  Caramel, some dark fruit (plum, cherry, etc), as well as a little bit o hops.  Flavor is a tad too sweet for my taste.  Not cloying, but theres something about it that puts it over the top.  Candied apples, honey, malts and a few hops dominate the flavor.  I never would have guessed that this is 11%!  Very well hidden.  Maybe I drank this one too early, a little bit of aging may do wonders.

Ruby brown beer with a thick rocky white head and great lacing throughout.. Aroma reminds me of candied fruits and hints that this beer will be very sweet. The flavor is not as sweet as I thought it might be but there is a strong malt character and a great warming feeling as it goes down. Tasty barleywine.

bottle. pours a nice red with a light golden hugh. large fluffy off white head. lots of puffy gobs of lacing stuck to the sides of the glass. aroma is malty and hoppy. taste is mellow. subtle caramel, malt and a sweet fruityness. this is a delicious beer and one that i will drink often. i must do a side by side with anchor old foghorn.
this beer goes down smooth and easy.  11 percent is quite well hidden in this great brew.
poured a dark amber with a thin head.  Aroma was sweet and fruity.  The flavor was a fantastic combination of fruit and malts, with a hint of alcohol.  Best barleywine that I have tried.
Bottle. Sorry but I dont know why this is top 50 it tasted really bad to me. Normal barleywine color, aroma, and flavor, but too much alcohol killed this for me. Complex but not my style

12oz bottle bottled Jan 11 05 - obtained in a trade with Jonathan3584.  Thanks Jonathan - Pours a lovely deep ruby with a nice thick tan head that laces the side of the snifter in a grand way.  Aroma is of sweet ripe cherry, caramel malts, citrus hops.  Aroma is quite sweet but pleasant.  Flavor is robust and malty.  Crystal and caramel malts come through as well as some cherry and grapefruit hops also some spices occasionally find their way through the sweetness.  On the palate this is amazing,,  It feels so good in the mouth that I found myself letting it sit on my tongue for a minute at a time before swallowing.  Coats the inside of the mouth and is oh so smooth and balanced.  There is absolutely no sign of the 11% alcohol in this one.  It is easy to see why Old Ho stays in the top 50.  Great Barleywine!
12 oz bottle-pours a tan, rich head.  Color is a deep cloudy reddish-orange.  A hoppy with citrus aroma.   Taste is alcohol, then sweet-malty & hopscome through.  Not to my taste.

I read here earlier..... "one damn fine smooth barleywine for someone who doesnt know anything about barlewine"  Very good beer, easy to drink which can be dangerous.... lacks a little on the palate from more traditional barley wines I have had.

Lucious taste and smooth as anything.  Not too sweat like I feared given the rather syrupy/malty nose.  Beautiful golden-brown-ruby color.  Incredible beer.  Not as stunning as the JW Lees I think, but this is one damn fine smooth barleywine from someone who dont know nothing about barleywines.
Lovely burnt-orange color with a thin head.  Mild aroma of hops with some caramel malt sweetness.  Very smooth and well-balanced-- a little sweet and quite bitter with a very nice alcohol character.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2005 Bottled.  Pours a deep reddish amber with a small quickly dropping head.  Aroma is majorly malty: toffee and caramel and cereal.  Hops are also very apparent in the nose: spicy and earthy.  A moderate ester profile is also present.  Flavor is also big and malty.  Sweet with crystal malt and breadiness.  Hops are spicy and citrussy in flavor with plenty enough bitterness to back up the syrupy sweetness and hop flavor.  Some slight fruity esters comes through with flavors of citrus and a bit of apple and cherries. Body is very full and silky smooth and syrupy, coating my snifter with every sip.  Excellent American barleywine.

2003: Pour is cloudy light brown with a big tan head complete with big yeasty floaties...smell is beautiful complex malts with sweetness and some earth fruits...grapefruit wraps it up nicely...what a fantastic BW...taste is just wonderfully creamy with delicate malts and heavy hard ones too...fruity and sweet...very sweet...warming with lots of caramel...alcohol comes out a little in the finish...wow...
garnet brown with a small tan head.  Nice malty aroma.  Wonderful full mouthfeel and taste of caramel malts with hints of chocolate, slightly sweet and warming in a very pleasant way. well done.
UPDATED: SEP 28, 2012 Wow! Very strong and tastes that way. Huge malt flavor! Could use more hops, but still a great beer.
What a yummy beer. The good news is I have four more. The bad news is they sat in my hot car for a week. Do you think theyll be okay?

bottle. copper body with a small white head. malty, yeasty cheese, and citrus hop aroma.  this is a pretty hefty beer and is my first barley wine of the fest (actually, as Im entering this rating it may have been the only barley wine I had). bold malty body, sweet in the middle...hoppy throughout and pretty much just the right amount of hops. some cheese and chocolate notes. very nice.

Rougeâtre aux reflets brun pale, mousse beige.  Moyen à faible dégagement gazeux.  Figue, dattes, raisins secs et alcool samourachent du parfum des agrumes du champs voisin.  Sucré en bouche, texture huileuse, abondance de résine houblon, quelques notes de houblon floraux également présentes.  Manque peut-être dun peu de complexité et de support de malt pour être un typique barley wine américain.  Échantillon, mondial de la bière, Juin 2005.

12 oz bottled on Dec 3rd 2004
Poured into my glass,its a nice deep ,warm chesnut brown with a tiny tan head..that doesnt last long but leaves attractive lacing.
Very pleasant a complex aroma, mostly of dark caramel malts and dark fruitiness..with hops showing through.
Taste is rather sweet and tasty, sweet like blackberries,black raspberries and luxurious dark chocolate. Some demerara sugar and coffee detected ,quite "winey".Alcohol taste is pleasing, like a nice sherry.
Nice on the palate and enjoyable mouthfeel throughout and a lovelly alcoholic warmth.
I found this barley wine very easy to drink..wish I had bought more to cellar for a year or so.

Wow, hold me down and kick my ass!
Beautiful beer. Amazing color. Healthy head. If not for the alcy burn, Perfect!

12 oz. bottle.  In corsendonk tulip glass, the beer is a dark brown-red liquid with very little to no head, even when agitated.  Aroma is of sweet apple orchard, supressed alcohol, fruit mix.  Flavor is of roasted grains (barley?), sweet fruits, and ends very hoppy, very dry.  Mouthfeel is initially very tingly from carbonation, but then is very smooth going down.  With time, this beer may get better and better.  Sampled slightly chilled, and as it warms.

Thanks to Lumpy for this!! Pours a dark ruby/brown color with a small off white head.  Aroma is lightly hoppy and heavy on the sweet malts with a fruity character.  Flavor is lightly hopped with a heavy sweet malt, Raisins, spices and some alcohol.  Medium mouthfeel with good carbonation.  Great lightly hopped barleywine!!

Has a root like beer appearance...plenty of big rising bubbles and next to no head. Sweet nose with liquored notes and some fragrant hops. Nice mouthfeel, fairly thick and sweet with the ABV coming into play, although to be fair the impact is in context. Good underlying ale notes add some complexity.

12 oz bottle.  Bottled January, 2005.  Deep garnet colour with a thin, fast fading tan head.  Aroma is quite subtle and well balanced.  Sweet malty aroma, light fruit, caramel/honey malts, port-like vineous character and light spiciness as well.  Some citrusy hop aroma.  Flavour is sweet up front, with fruit, honey, port, and a citrusy flavour.  Silky smooth body.  I cant believe this is 11% ABV.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2006 my favorite victory beer, and it will leave you horizontal, good taste for 11%
smooth with a bite. pours a light bronze color with small light tan head that quickly disapates, aroma of malt, alcohol, hops, and citrus. Flavor reflect aroma, great brew.
Strong malt backbone and great hops taste/ smell.  The alcohol is hidden very nicely.  Great Barley Wine.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2007 Bottle:  Bottled January 11, 2005.  Citrus hoppy aroma with banana bread and some malty fruitiness.  Pours a dark transparent amber with a big off-white head with excellent retention.  Very nice lacing.  Malty up front with caramel, fruit, and light banana bread.  Citrus hops in the finish, but not as much as I anticipated considering it only a few months old.  Alcohol covered up very well, a touch of burn is really only noticeable if youre looking for it.  More malt and more fruit compared to some hopped up American barley wines (not that I have a problem with hopped up barley wines). Very nice.  
Same batch as above.  The aroma is a combination of caramel, chocolate, real light fruitiness, and light oxidized.  There is also a moderate alcohol that I didnt get previously.   In the flavor, the caramel has intensified with some light chocolate and banana bread.  Slight oxidation and extremely mild citrus hops in the finish.  There is no burn at all as I noted before.  Nice and interesting to see the difference, but I liked it better when it was more fresh.

Best palate I have ever had in a beer -- balanced, complex, and full mouthfeel.  Delicate finish of sweet, then toasty, barley with some bright alcohol notes.  Back to how the beer looks in the glass -- deep copper and cloudy with some lacing from a diminished tan head.  Aromas are light hops, some soapiness, and some apricot/peach fruit.  Taste is a series of hops, fruit, barley, alcohol, and a toasted finish.  An amazing brew.

Bottle.  I would buy this beer for the label alone!  Pours into the glass a deep hazy red with a small but lacey head. Very nice aroma, especially as it warmed a bit.  Flavor was sweet like honey, along with hops and a bit of citrus. A bit of alcohol bite as it warmed.

Pours a cloudy dark maroon with a thin white head.  Rich deep sweet barley and malt smell.  Wonderful bittersweet barley taste that dominates your mouth for a good long while afterwards.  Palate is creamy and but not as complex as the taste.  Real very nice beer.
Bottle. Poured a hazy dark orange with a medium white head. Aroma and flavor was a complex hoppy and fruity moderate sweet with an average finish. Full body with a light alcohol finish.

Thanks to The_Beer_God for the bottle.    Pours a hazy brown orange color.  Small white head.  Alcohol aroma, with dried fruit notes.  Syrupy sweet nose, followed by big malt flavors and a rather estery yeast imprint.  Some pine and apricot notes in the finish, braced by a noticable alcohol warmth.

(Bottled) Hazy dark orange color with a smallish, tight and lacy head. Very strong, malty and port-wineous aroma with dried fruit, hops and a hint of warm alcohol. Very malty, sweetish, nicely and strongly aromatic-hoppy flavor with orange-peel and mint hints. Alcohol is well hidden. Slicky, very warming and smooth, wineous palate with soft carbonation. A very nice, aromatic-hoppy, balanced barley wine, although its nothing spectacular.

Bottle.  A very nice ultra amber / copper color.  Thin golden head.  Estery, but not a huge nose by any means.  Flavors of good rum, hot nuts, and cereal.  A bit of resin.  Dont get the fruit others have noted.   A long clean finish .  Not terribly complex, but very well crafted.  I would have rated it a "20 " except it was a bit too thin and hot.  Much obliged to DocLock for this wonder.

Pours ruby/ dark brown with a thin off white head. Fruity and hoppy aroma. This seems a little thin almost. Taste is fruity and nicely hopped in the back of the taste. Alcohol warms after each sip. A good beer, but not nearly as good as Storm King from the Victory lineup.
Bottle. Pours copper/brown, with a small head. Aromas are hops, sweet malt, and brown sugar. Flavor is sweet malt, bitter hops, brown sugar, and some fruit. Alcohols pretty welll hidden.

Tap @ Victory. Clear copper w a red tint, nice beige head that fell fairly quickly. The aroma was weak for it was rather cold. Flavor is rich, creamy malt & nice spicey hops w alcohol noticable. Fine, smooth, creamy scotch whisky flavor in with the spicy, complex mix. Nice sweetness, just into full bodied. The flavors rise up to hide the alcohol as it warms.

last year a perfect malt/hops balance
this year a turbo hops beer.
consistently/inconsistent.
a great usa brewery,not many left.

Brownish garnet in color.  Large head for a barleywine - creamy, about 1/4" thick, off-white to grey.  Aroma is sweet floral hops, honey, brown sugar and roses.  Flavor is sweet and hoppy; honey and granny smith apples.  Body is smooth, good levels of carbonation.  Thins and mellows a bit near the end.  Good hops and malts balance.  Finish is mouth watering and light.  Hard to believe that this ones 11%.  Thanks to lamas for the bottle!

from the bottle poured a amber brown, with a tan head that stayed around for awhile and left good lacing. aroma a nice malt caramel, hops, citrus, honey, alcohol as it warms some sour fruits came out. flavor I hope as good as the aroma, got a nice alcohol bite right up front, malts, orange, molasses nice mouthfeel, very good

Bottle courtesy of BuckNaked in trade. Pours dark orange/amber with decent tan head. Aroma is sweet caramel malt, yeasty bread, and some tangy fruit. Fruit really shows up in the flavor. Cant pinpoint it first guess is peach, maybe apricot or mango. Has only a little hop in the finish. Still pretty good overall, just would prefer more caramel/mollases flavor instead of the fruit. But I guess thatts what makes it unique.
On tap at the brewery. A dark amber color with a moderate head. A good syrupy texture with some orange, oak, cherry, molasses. A slightly bitter aftertaste. A nice barleywine.
odor was pure, fruity and hoppy. One of the best barleywines Ive had. I will definitely buy another six pack of this. Ill just say.. they were victorious
2003: Aroma of apricot, peach, cherry, banana and other spicy fruit.  The body is malty sweet, yet satisfyingly hoppy - a truly great combination.

Thank you DocLock! Clear dark Amber color with a small tan head. Hoppy scent with sticky sweetness. Potent alcohol, very sweet and thick, lip smacking. Not as abrasive of a hop bite as I expected. Strong wood flavor, chewy. Quite good but I still prefer Bigfoot!

UPDATED: APR 23, 2005 WOW! What an enjoyable barleywine. Strong yet suttely distinct taste. The alcohol radiates from this ale... very potent! I would definatly love to spend another evening with Old Horizontal!

Considering how thick and malty this beer is, its also incredibly drinkable.  Tangy, fruity aroma follows a dark brown pour with no head.  Taste is strong, bright malts, warming honey and alcohol, with a noticable hop finish.  This would be solid enough without the hops, but wow.  A wonderful, welcoming ale, even when the weather gets warmer.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2005 12oz, bottled Dec 14 04.Served in my NB worthy glass at 42.4°. Pours dark with a 1" cream colored head. Rings and spots of foam stuck around, lurking, and the beer glides down the glass when swirled. The aroma is carmelly malt and citrusy, perfumy hops? (cascade?) and is just wonderful. Reminds me of the Old Backus. The taste is increadibly huge with malt, honey, piney and floral hops. I love the hugeness of american barley wines. This is a winner, Im glad I trade for a few!

Nice.  Deep reddish-amber with a suggestion of a head, this thick drink has an aroma of sweet malt, a yeasty fruitiness, strong floral hops, and the ever-present alcohol.  It tastes sweet and malty, the fruits reduced to a hint, the alcohol increasing in its presence, and the hops blaring through loudly, especially in the dry, bitter finish.  Nice.  Im definitely cellaring some of these.
At first, I did not enjoy the strong odor, but this beer got better and better with each sip.  Definitely worth a try.

Not as impressed as I thought Id be. Looks beautiful, with a mahogany body and large khaki head. Spiderweb lacing. Complex aroma: sour malt, floral perfumed hops and a touch of wet dog. Lots of alcohol up front in the nose. Flavor is moderate malted sweetness along with a vinous sourness. Not great... simply good.

<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Beverage Depot<font size=-1>

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2008 Tap at Brewery- Huge hops, deep red color, Nice foam head. Huge hops, big malts, huge hops. This is a hop monster. Tastes very similar to Bigfoot, but with better balance. Id love to have this laid down for a couple years. Mellowing of the hops would do this wonders. Still, one of the best barleywines Ive had, ever. Very very nice

2002: Thats right the first time I tasted this beer it was aged for two years. The aroma was absolutely delectable. It poured a nice copper color and offered a very smooth taste. Simply put this is one of the best beers I have ever had.

Plum colour with a big, foamy off-white head. Apricot, grape and vinious in the aroma followed by a spicy effervescence. Some hops burst out as well.  The flavor starts sweet, with light molasses and fruit sweetness but moves into a strong pine, pepper, hop bitterness to a nice dry and hoppy finish.  Well made, tasty and very easy going down, just like a great barley wine should.
Very strong and difficult to drink a lot of, but a good barleywine.  Malty with a hoppy finish.  Surprisingly, not one of my favorite Victorys.

Cellar Temp. Red amber with mostly diminishing head. Smells hoppy. Flavors are subtle but not thin. Somewhat sweet with dark fruits; most notable is cherry and rose hips. Luscious mouthfeel. Finishes with a pleasant burn, like a good bourbon. A very drinkable barleywine (although by no means a session beer.)
A very strong beer, with a noticeable taste of alcohol.  Overall pretty decent, with a bitter finish.

In competition with Dogfish Heads Olde School for my favorite barleywine.  Not as hoppy as OS, but has a better malt character in my opinion.  Borders on overly sweet, but it has enough hoppiness to keep it under wraps.  Solid beer.

I first tried this right out of the bottle and was disapointed.  This needs to breathe for a while.  Then its very fruity and sweet, almost too sweet to drink alot of.  Would make a great desert beer or just lazing about beer.  deep amber/red in color with a fluffy brown head that lasts.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2009 Very good, but not great.  Not much of an aroma; kind of like Michelob Amber Bock.  An off sweet, citrusy flavor yet quite clean tasting/feeling.  Listed as a barleywine, but tastes lagered to me.  Enjoyable malty, hoppy aftertaste.
tap.  deep amber color. little head. definite fruity aroma with  full flavor of hops, malts, and hint of alcohol that follows. well balance beer on the best of barley list.  good social beer.

A little harsh for me. I think it confused my stomach a little, considering i had a ketchup soaked Pats steak (provi with) in there which i consumed 15 minutes earlier. I recognize its a good beer, I justdrank it at the wrong moment.

Old Horizontal pours with light, ultrafine carbonation, deep amber color, and marked viscosity.  Hops, alcohol, and yeast (diacetyl) artifacts dominate the aroma.  The malt, hops, sugar, and yeast synergize almost perfectly, leaving only a slight dry hop aftertaste.  I actually prefer more dry hop character, but this is a minor criticism.  Well done, Victory!
(bottle 12/29/04) deep amber with almost no head. Aroma is fruity with definite alcohol. Fairly well balanced, fruity, solid malt backbone with a hops finish.

bottlen 12-04 Zis bier zhould buried be. Aged like zat it vill be tasten wery better. Ya, it ist gut now, but better it becomes mit age.Earlier Rating: 3/6/2005 Total Score: 3.7bottle dated 12-04, nice looking beer with little head, medium bodied ale with fruit and caramel flavors, very easy drinking beer as the alcohol is well balanced with the malt and hop flavor. This beer was definately too young to drink, yet was surprisingly good.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2005 Bottled Dec. 2004.  Nice!!!  Deep copper colored with a sparse white head.  No lacing.  Very nice blend of hops and caramel malts in aroma.  Medium bodied.  Full flavors of malt and hop.  Very nicely done for a young barleywine and the best offering from this brewery.  

03 bottle consumed on 11/05.  Rich amber brown color with a fantastic beige head.  Wonderful lacing.  Full, heady aroma.  Moderately oxidized, plummy, still full of estery goodness.  Full bodied and smooth.  Fantastic balance with just a hint more malt showing.  Nice light alcohol bite.  Really superb.

Ive got to hand it to Victory on this one, I had a Storm King the other night and was a little dissapointed but this brew excels.  Sweet fruit aroma coming from a dark syrupy brown pour with less of a head than Id like.  Taste is reminiscent of some Impy stouts but lighter.  Raisins, sweet roasted chocolate coffee, malt and little apple, I think.  More apple, in fact, as it warms.  I cant believe the alcohol is 11% its hidden to perfection.
Beautiful golden amber beer. Smells and tastes sweet, rich and tart.  This beer makes me appreciate balance, no one flavor dominates but all blend to create a fantastic drink

2003 Bottle.  Pours an opaque burnt orange body with minimal tan head. Aroma is very nice....cascade hops, lotsa sweet malts, with strong alcohol presence.  Taste is even better, an Intense blast of sweet malts, hop bitterness, and some alcohol to boot.   As it warms, you sense the great tasting  malt backbone a bit more.   Finishes with a pleasantly warming alcohol burn.  Its easy to see why this is on everyones "favorites" list.

cellar temp, pours a nice clear dark red/brown with a frothy tan head. aroma is caramel, hops, sweet. oh, and alcohol.  nice caramel, fruity, spicy flavor, with a good amount of bitterness and alcohol at the end. good mouthfeel, and very drinkable.

Bottle Jan. 11 2005. Beautiful clear ruby red pour. Nice cream colored head, that mostly diminishes. Lacing maintains. Hoppy apple aroma with pineapple and pine wafts. Complex flavors with raising, rum, and cinnamon. Like a fine bourbon, but with more angles. The alcohol is well hidden. Palate is crisp and bright with a soft cherry aftertaste. Top Quality!
Body is a brownish ruby, with a cream head that lasts.  The aroma is dried fruit, chocolate, and honey.  Taste is sweet with butterscotch, caramel, chocolate.  Very nice barleywine.

Pours dark amber with a 1/4 inch tan head that took a minute to diminish.  Aroma is noticably sweet and plums.  Initially it had a hoppy surprise yet kept the sweet fruit flavor underneath.  Finishes with a lasting spicy thickness. The creamy mouthfeel wants me to stop typing and take another drink. ...Alchohol doesnt seem like 10% at first but its catching up with me.

Pours deep amber with a small amount of yellow-tan head. Sweet and spicy aromas, with deep orange hoppiness. Ripe plum fruitiness and alcohol show as it warms. Rich, sweet and fruity tastes, with a nice clinging hop bitterness. Pleasantly warming. Mouthfeel is big and chewy without being syrupy--a tough thing to pull off in this style. Generally, Im not a huge barleywine fan. So many seem overly sweet and one dimensional. This however, is a superior brew, full of interest and very well crafted.

As with most victory brews, I am less impressed with this than most tasters, though its still very good.  A nice dark burgundy color and thin head accompany a VERY easy drinking, hoppy and spiced BW flavor.  Good...just not the greatest, in my opinion.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2005 Bottled Nov. 18, 2003.  Oh boy.  This is some good stuff.  Murky amber pour with minimal head.  Caramel malt nose.  Exceptional aroma.  Some hops still breaking through.  11%?  My palate begs to differ.  Rich, malty, fruity, fantastic flavors.  Slightly sticky in your mouth.  This is one hell of a barley wine.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2005 Sometimes I get my barleywines mixed up from the past because I could swear this had some hop character in the past, but I could be wrong.  Caramel malts and alcohol are out front with the alcohol being a bit strong for me.  A run of the mill barley-wine that I can not figure why it is a top 50 beer.  Very average IMO.

Wonderful aroma from the moment the bottle is opened. Smelled of nuts with hints of fruit, almost a tangy/spice smell.  Taste was quite a pleasant surprise as it was not as sweet as I anticipated.  The feel was balanced with a decisive punch of alcohol on the way down.  An excellent beer that can be enjoyed more casually than many other specialty beers.

Brownish red in colour, with a large fluffy head. My first b/w and wasnt expecting to enjoy, I was wrong. Taste is hops, wine, and a mild caramel sweetness. Was expecting something too sweet or bitter but this was just right, wish I grabbed more than a single bottle.

Bottled. This was really unlike any other barley wine Ive had. It poured a rich, burnt sugar amber, and even pouring it at an arms length, I could still smell the hops and sweetness. The sweet nose is deceiving, though. I was really surprised by the strong bitterness brought on by the hops, which is a characteristic unlike any b/w Ive had. It lacks the treacly character that often dominates and blights the style. Indeed, the biggest element I took away from tasting this was the hops. Excellent.

Red/amber, murky beer, with a white frothy head. Aroma is hoppy and flowery, with honey sweetness and a touch of pepper. Flavor is sweet honey and caramel but hoppy as well, lemon and grapefruit, but nothing too overwhelming. Finishes with a smooth slightly smokey aftertaste. Alcohol is very well hidden. Not my favorite barley wine, but still a very good one.

pours a beauteous amber and garnet, with a small head.  the aroma is intense, like tons of caramel malts, raisins, pineapples, figs.  deeply-hidden hops in there, with a touch of hops in the finish as well.  more bitter in flavor than in the aroma, but its not over-the-top bitter, very appropriate use of hops.  this is a phenomenal beer, probably the best barley wine ive had.

Deep ruby/copper.  Bright hop and floral aroma.  Surprisingly rich mouthfeel.  Hops and alcohol content extremely well-masked under sweet grain/mild hop finish.  Im sure it will be even better a year from now.
a decent barley wine.  hoppy and alcoholic, this beer is well balanced.  my bottle is relatively new, so i dont know how this beer ages.

Big caramel toffee aroma, with some interesting hoppy notes. Ruby dark gold. Sweet caramel flavour in start, with a suprisingly hoppy citric finish. Bit of pine there too. Full bodied and warming. Interesting!

Pours copper in color with a small tan head.  Aroma and flavor both are very mellow in the hops and malt.  This is a very smooth Barleywine, which was surpising since it was a young 2004 bottle.  Even though it is mellow, it has good complexity.

Sweet fruity aroma, mahogany colour, no head. Very thick beer with an almost imperceptable flood of bubbles that tingle my lips as I sip. My mouth gets coated by this beer. It almost seems like candy, very sweet with a hint of hops. I can see why this beer is in the top fifty.

Bottled at The London/Joet Gathering Chez Chris_O.  A reddy brown coloured beer with no head.  The aroma has blackberries butter and alcohol.  The taste is extremely smooth with lots of warming tasty alcohol and rich fruity notes.  Very very drinkable for such a strong beer.  Good stuff indeed.

The Kilburn Gathering. Im not a fan of big beers, especially barley wine - but this is so soft and gentle and so very beautiful it is difficult not to become bequiled. There is a pleasant oily hop aroma along with wood wax and pine resin. Its a very inviting and compelling aroma. Tipping the beer into the mouth is very pleasurable - its thick as slow glue.
